title: Penn State wrestling continues to Big Ten schedule, hosts Indiana
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
After a trip to the Midwest last week, Penn State welcomes a team from the Midwest in Indiana for a Friday night dual meet to continue the Big Ten season.

The Nittany Lions will host the Hoosiers at 7 p.m. Friday in Rec Hall before the highly anticipated Bryce Jordan Center dual on Jan. 30 against Nebraska. The teams last met in Rec Hall where Penn State came out on top 46-0.

Here’s how this year’s dual matches up.

125: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 12 Jacob Moran (IU)

Luke Lilledahl jumped to No. 1 in the InterMat rankings while maintaining his undefeated record. He’s controlled many matches this season, keeping up with his “lightning” pace.

On the other side, Jacob Moran has just one loss on the season. He fell by major decision to Nic Bouzakis of Ohio State, who’s currently the No. 2 wrestler in the country.

Despite a potential early feeling out process, Lilledahl’s result could be similar to that of Bouzakis’ win over one of the Hoosiers’ top wrestlers.

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. Logan Frazier (IU)

Marcus Blaze escaped his first major test against Iowa and will face an unranked opponent in Logan Frazier.

Frazier fell by tech fall to Ohio State’s Ben Davino, who’s ranked above Blaze at No. 2 at 133 pounds. With the Nittany Lion’s blazing ability to score, a bonus-point victory is very much in the picture.

141: No. 11 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 25 Henry Porter (IU)

Braeden Davis dropped his first match of the season in his second dual match of the campaign. He’s now the permanent starter at 141 pounds and has an opportunity to earn a ranked victory over Henry Porter.

Porter holds a 9-3 record, and has dropped all three matches to ranked wrestlers. His matchup with Davis will be one of his bigger tests after showing off his ability to stay on top of a wrestler.

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. Joey Buttler (IU)

Shayne Van Ness is the start of what could be the most dominant part of a lineup in wrestling history. He’s the second No. 1 wrestler of six for the Nittany Lions and has ended matches early against unranked foes.

Buttler has a 9-7 record and will face his toughest opponent. The Hoosier will have to get off to a strong start, as Van Ness has been prone to give up an early takedown. Despite this, Van Ness often responds, still ending matches early despite going down early.

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. Bryce Lowery (IU)

Similar to Blaze, Duke also faced a major test in Carver-Hawkeye Arena and came out victorious. He’ll take on an unranked Bryce Lowery for another likely easier battle.

Lowery is 7-5 and with Duke’s speed, he could get back to a highly offensive matchup and score in bunches, leading to an early finish.

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. No. 19 Tyler Lillard (IU)

Mitchell Mesenbrink won’t have wrestled in a dual in a week since the Iowa matchup when he takes the mat against Tyler Lillard. Mesenbrink won by forfeit on Sunday against Northwestern as the Wildcats didn’t weigh in a 165-pound wrestler.

Lillard will be facing a machine in Mesenbrink, who, like Duke, scores a lot of points and very quickly. This season, Mesenbrink has added an emphasis to back points and attempting to go for falls, as he continues to prove he’s far ahead of the rest of his competition.

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. No. 29 Derek Gilcher (IU)

Levi Haines also has pushed for back points, utilizing many different positions to get the nearfall swipes. He’ll take on Derek Gilcher, who’s 9-5 on the season.

Gilcher is in his first full season at 174 pounds after wrestling at both 165 and 174 last season. Against the top wrestler in the weight class, he could be in for a very quick night with Haines’ constant aggression and overpowering ability in his second season at the weight.

184: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. No. 15 Sam Goin (IU)

Rocco Welsh is the new No. 1 wrestler at 184 pounds after defeating then-No. 1 Angelo Ferrari of Iowa in tiebreakers. After a much slower-paced match, he got back to his offense against Northwestern. Despite this, when he faces ranked opponents like Sam Goin, he has a tendency to be on the more defensive side.

Goin’s chance to win will be solely on if he can finish on his attacks. Welsh has given up minimal points throughout the season, which has allowed him to be less offensive and still be successful.

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 14 Gabe Sollars (IU)

Josh Barr has proven he’s in a tier of his own at 197 pounds, and could be in for a big postseason after finishing as the national runner up a season ago.

Sollars sits at 8-5 with his losses piling up after the Big Ten schedule began. In the dominant conference, Barr has continued to shine while Sollars has started to fall, potentially a sign of how the Friday night matchup will go.

285: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. Caleb Marzolino (IU)

Mirasola is riding high after some major victories in his last few matches. He’s back up to No. 12 in the rankings and will face yet another unranked wrestler.

When he takes on an unranked wrestler, he’s much more offensive and can showcase his quickness and IQ, something he takes pride in.

Not only is Caleb Marzolino unranked, but he’s also closer to the size of Mirasola, who’s considered an undersized heavyweight for the class. That should play to the favor of Mirasola as the potential closing match of the dual.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Can Penn State replicate the Indiana formula under new leadership? | The 1-0 Podcast
author: The Daily Collegian Football Staff
description:
The “1-0 Podcast” co-hosts Avery Hill, Lyle Alenstein and Will Horstman hopped in the studio days after the conclusion of the 2025 college football season to discuss Penn State football.

The crew started their discussion looking at some early rankings regarding the Nittany Lions.They then talked about the trajectory of the program, most notably mentioning whether or not head coach Matt Campbell can win as fast as Curt Cignetti did at Indiana.

The trio then highlighted five-star recruit Kemon Spell before taking a brief look at a new addition to Penn State’s 2027 schedule.

MORE COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s gymnastics takes on neighbors Maryland in Rec Hall on Sunday
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s gymnastics is back home on Sunday, taking on its neighbors to the south, Maryland. The Nittany Lions are looking for a great meet in Rec Hall after a successful week 2.

Penn State has started out their Big Ten schedule with a win after a showdown with Illinois. A 196.075-194.100 win got the Nittany Lions into the No. 4 spot on the Big Ten rankings and No. 17 in the NCAA rankings.

There is confidence with the Nittany Lions; now the question is whether they can continue to use it as they go through the rest of their season, facing Big Ten opponents, especially ones like Michigan.

The Terrapins are also going into this meet very strong and having a lot of confidence. They are coming off four-straight wins, with three of those being in the Terrapin Quad. Maryland’s most recent win was against Washington, beating them 194.265-193.575.

Vault has been a really strong apparatus for Maryland, with it having a very successful week 2 in the event. Three standout gymnasts that not only excelled on vault, but also really stepped out for the Terrapins were Katrina Mendez-Abolnik, Rayna Engelmayer and Taylor Rech.

Mendez-Abolnik put up a great performance and landed a 9.850, and Engelmayer and Rech both put up a score of 9.825.

The blue and white also have a history of being strong on vault, with most of its lineup excelling on the event. Against Illinois, Jessica Johanson scored a 9.825, and in its opening meet against Yale, multiple 9.800 and above scores, with standout performances by Ava Cash, who put up a 9.850, and Allison Kaempfer, who put up a 9.825.

The uneven bars might be an area where Penn State could excel, with Maryland looking at scores in the 9.700 range so far this season, and putting up an average of 9.750 last season for most of their gymnasts. The blue and white have a history of excelling in the uneven bars rotation, and bars were where a lot of points were racked up against Illinois last Friday. Ava Piedrahita scored a 9.925, and Dani Latronica scored a 9.875.

Beam will be a rotation that both teams have looked at improving on, and both teams have leaned on rotating their lineups, trying to find gymnasts who can really focus and excel on beam with an opportunity to get those scores up.

Maryland had an average of 9.6408 on beam in 2025, and that score is looking the same so far in the 2026 season. Penn State had an average of about 9.7480 in the 2025 season, and, similar to Maryland, are looking to be in that range so far in the 2026 season. Beam will be an event to watch with both the Terrapins and Nittany Lions being equally equipped.

Floor can be a crucial part of this meet, with a lot of great routines from both sides being brought out. The Terrapins’ Madeline Komoroski had a great night on the floor against Washington last Saturday, scoring 9.875. Rech followed closely behind with another standout score of the night, 9.850. Penn State’s Latronica also put down a great routine, with a score of 9.875, so seeing a Latronica-Komoroski matchup could be very interesting.

These teams have a lot of talent, a lot of it being equal in quality. They can put on a great show on Sunday and get a lot of important points going into the rest of the Big Ten season, and the 2026 season as a whole.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s gymnastics heads to Sarasota for Sam Mikulak Invitational
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s headed to Sarasota, Florida, to compete in the Sam Mikulak Invitational. The Nittany Lions are set to take on multiple teams, including fellow Big Ten member, Illinois.

This is the last meet for the blue and white before it begins the Big Ten season, which means that this invitational can be a great opportunity to finalize their lineups going into Big Ten territory, and also figure out what needs to be fixed.

Penn State is also looking at qualifying chances for one of their all-around gymnasts, Landon Simpson, who just punched his ticket to the Winter Cup, which is a qualifying event for the 2026 Xfinity U.S. Gymnastics Championships.

The Nittany Lions are looking at success going into week 3, with a win against Army in week 1 and first place in the West Point Open in week 2. They have the confidence to do well in this invitational and have the opportunity to really start off strong against their fellow conference teams.

The blue and white can also get a step up on Illinois, who it will not only cross paths with this weekend but also in the Big Ten opener on Feb. 1. The Fighting Illini have been falling short of a win so far this season, coming in third at the OSU Open against Ohio State, Michigan and Greenville University.

Penn State will also face off against two club teams: the Florida Storm and EVO Senior Men’s Elite team. These two club teams consist of multiple gymnasts not competing for a university, but are competing at a collegiate level.

Illinois had a consistent 2025 season, with floor, highbar and parallel bars having consistent team scores across the whole season. Matthew Vu Nguyen is a really strong gymnast for the Fighting Illini, having high scores of 14.250 on vault, 14.050 on parallel bars and 13.400 on high bar. Garrett Schooley is another great candidate for all-around high scores, as he has a high of 14.300 on floor and 14.450 on vault.

Illinois needs to gain its confidence back this meet, but the Nittany Lions are looking at continuing their winning streak. The blue and white have had two standout gymnasts these past two weeks with one being Simpson, and the other Matthew Underhill. Both have put up high scores that pushed their team above its competitors.

Underhill’s scores of 13.350 on floor, 13.750 on still rings and 14.300 on vault contributed to a large gap in the cumulative team results of the meet.

Both collegiate teams will be looking at each other this weekend as a way to set the tone for their future matchup. There is competition awaiting them both in the form of the club teams also participating, but both the Fighting Illini and the Nittany Lions will be focused on handling each other.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Column | A personal Renaissance
author: Annelise Hanson | The Daily Collegian
description:
Olivia Dean sings about having no one to text when the plane lands or when it’s taking off.

I think about that as I leave, about what it means to step into something new without a witness.

I love to imagine what exists on the other side of the door of opportunity. Who I will become after all is said and done.

By bus, plane, train and car, I am leaving far beyond.

I’m leaving the country where I’ve spent twenty years exploring corners unturned, tides unexplored, walking in the footsteps of Florentine philosophers, artists, poets and astronomers.

I’m becoming someone new without anyone there to see my departure or my arrival. Will the city of the Renaissance become a home for my own rebirth? Will I recognize ambition in its birthplace?

Florence, to me, feels both like a test and a teacher. A place I’ve known through books long before I ever knew it through my body. Its history has lived in my mind across hills and valleys, waiting for me to arrive.

I consider this my renaissance, a return to the classics, a return to myself.

Will I see Venus’s mark on a city built on beauty? Will I walk where Machiavelli once did and learn what ambition truly demands? Will I look into the same night sky as Galileo and feel the courage it takes to question the universe as it’s handed to us?

If I close my eyes, will I understand how Michelangelo painted creation itself, or how Leonardo da Vinci imagined a final supper before it was ever sacred? In my opera class, will I sing in the language of romance and longing, hoping to recreate something close to what Mozart once intended? Perhaps I will trace the strokes of Botticelli’s “Birth of Venus” and feel the reverence for beauty in every curve.

What if what waits on the other side of this door is a love I cannot take home with me, only clinging to the memories of a place I know my heart will belong to? What if I cry in a vineyard, learn what’s hidden inside the grapes each glass of wine is made up of?

Soon, I will roam streets with soulmates I have yet to meet, embark on adventures I’m only just beginning to book. My soul longs for the familiarity of a place I have never experienced in this body.

What awaits me in a city that does not yet know my name? Will I uncover the secrets of my own small universe, the way so many before me once did? What lessons await me in Piazzas that have seen centuries unfold?

As I revel in the heavens, look out on the balcony at terracotta roofs, I will picture the life I’m leaving behind for a short while. I hope to embrace these weeks and carry them along in memory.

I believe there’s a new temporary life waiting for me upon my arrival. Just me and the endless horizon from the train window.

I have found solace in Dean’s message, having no one to call or text when I land.

MORE ABROAD COLUMNS

title: Nonconference preview | Penn State women’s lacrosse opens season with strong schedule
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Women’s lacrosse is almost back.

Penn State kicks off its season on the road at Richmond on Feb. 7 before playing a total of eight nonconference games to start the season.

The Nittany Lions have faced the Spiders 12 times over the years, holding a near perfect record with 11 wins. Last year, Richmond edged out the blue and white with a 12-10 win.

The Spiders failed to make it to the NCAA tournament last year after falling in the second round of the Atlantic 10 tournament.

While they lost their two leading goal scorers in Colleen Quinn and Grace Muldoon to graduation,Richmond picked up Syracuse transfer Meghan Rode and Georgetown transfer Rileigh Meyer during the offseason, who’ve made a combined 42 career starts.

Following the trip to Richmond, Penn State returns home to face UMass in its home opener on Feb. 11. The two teams haven’t faced each other since 2013, but the blue and white holds a 9-0 all-time record.

After starting the season 2-3, the Minutemen won the next 13 straight, including the Atlantic 10 championship. UMass then fell to Princeton in the first round of the NCAA tournament, 19-10.

The Minutemen return redshirt senior Kassidy Morris for her final year. Last season, the Washago, Ontario, native finished tied for sixth in the country with 78 goals.

The Nittany Lions will then host Bucknell on Feb. 15 in what will likely be their easiest game of the year.

Penn State holds a 22-0 all-time record over the Bison, including a 16-4 win last year. Bucknell went 6-10 last year with a 1-6 record on the road.

The blue and white’s matchup with Pitt on Feb. 18 is a newer rivalry, having only played four times in program history. The Nittany Lions hold a 3-1 lead in the series.

Since only reaching NCAA status in 2021, the Panthers have seen increasing success from four wins in 2023 to eight last year — including a win over Penn State.

This year, Pitt lost its leading scorer from last year, Jenna Hendrickson, who scored 46 goals. However, it bolstered other parts of the squad, adding St. Bonaventure’s goalkeeper Katelyn Hicks, who made the seventh-most saves in a single season in Bonnies’ history.

After three straight home games, the blue and white travel to Philadelphia to face Drexel on Feb. 22.

Penn State started the series strong with eight straight wins, but has lost three of the last four matchups with a 9-3 all-time record.

After a 14-4 season, which culminated in the Dragons falling in the CAA championship game to Stony Brook, they then lost two of their top-three scorers, who combined for over half the team’s points.

The Nittany Lions remain on the road and travel north to Cornell for a matchup on Feb. 28. Penn State holds the all-time lead 15-4.

For the past several years, the Big Red have been on the cusp of tournament play, but didn’t make either the conference or NCAA tournament last year with a 9-6 record.

While Cornell has seen steady play recently, Colgate had a much-improved year last season. The Raiders — who Penn State hosts on March 4 — went 9-8 last year after back-to-back years of less than five wins.

Colgate will have an opportunity to build on that success with the return of its three leading scorers from last year, including sophomore Aubrey McMahon, who could continue to grow with the Raiders over the next three years.

The Nittany Lions will play their last away nonconference game on March 8, travelling to the West Coast for a game against San Diego State in the teams’ first-ever matchup.

The Aztecs are a struggling team who only posted three winning seasons in the past 10 years. Over the past two seasons, they’ve tallied just seven wins.

Penn State wraps up its nonconference schedule by hosting Princeton on March 15. The Tigers are Penn State’s only ranked nonconference opponent, entering the season at No. 6.

Princeton is also the only out of conference opponent this season that the Nittany Lions have a losing record with, sitting at 14-29 all time.

The Tigers enter 2026 fresh off a 16-4 season with a trip to the NCAA quarterfinals. They will be without last year’s 89-goal scorer in McKenzie Blake, but have Jami MacDonald, who scored 58 goals last year, back for her senior year.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Nonconference preview | Penn State men’s lacrosse set for seven-game nonconference slate
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s lacrosse will play seven out-of-conference games this season, with a few coming against highly-ranked opposition.

The non-conference slate will see the Nittany Lions play four games at Panzer Stadium, two on the road and one at a neutral site as part of The Crown Classic.

While most programs use the non-conference games as an opportunity to warm up in the cold winter months, Penn State may not get that opportunity. The Nittany Lions will play three ranked teams in the opening weeks, each of which is ranked in the top six of the Inside Lacrosse preseason poll.

Colgate

A date with Colgate will open the year at home for the blue and white, an opponent that has become a favorite for coach Jeff Tambroni to schedule as the Nittany Lions’ first of the season.

This year will mark the third consecutive season where Penn State plays the Raiders to begin the year, with the blue and white going 1-1 in those matchups.

Colgate went 10-8 last season, and 4-4 in Patriot League play. The Raiders were led by sophomore Liam Connor with 90 points in 2025, but he’s out of the picture after transferring to Georgetown. Their most productive returner will be senior Hunter Drouin, who recorded 32 goals and 16 assists for the Raiders last season.

Villanova

Next on the schedule for the Nittany Lions will be the Villanova Wildcats, who went 4-1 in Big East play and 8-7 overall before falling in the second round of last year’s Big East tournament.

Villanova also lost its top scorer from last season, with attackman Matt Licata graduating at the end of the year. Colin Michener will be the Wildcats’ most prolific returner, having scored 26 goals and recording 14 assists in 2025.

Penn State has won two straight games against the Wildcats and holds a 21-9 all-time record against them.

No. 2 Princeton

The Nittany Lions will play their first high-level opponent on Valentine’s Day when they take a trip to New Jersey to face No. 2 Princeton.

The Tigers went 13-4 overall and 5-1 in the Ivy League last season before falling to Syracuse in a 19-18 thriller in the quarterfinal round of the NCAA Tournament.

With Coulter Mackesy off to Boston as the Cannons’ No. 4 overall pick in last season’s PLL draft, star attackman Nate Kabiri will step into an even larger role this season for the Tigers. The junior tallied 61 points last season, second only to the departing Mackesy’s mark of 63.

Navy

Penn State will stay on the road after the Princeton game, traveling to Annapolis for a meeting with Navy.

Navy went 8-7 in 2025, with a 4-4 mark in Patriot League play. Last year’s meeting between the Nittany Lions and Midshipmen saw Penn State pull out a 13-7 victory at home in Happy Valley.

Returning senior Mac Haley led all Navy players with 43 points, with Jack Ponzio and William Goers each returning after having seasons of 30 or more points.

Yale

The final day of February will see the Nittany Lions take on Yale at home.

Yale is the Nittany Lions’ only non-conference opponent with a losing record last season, going 5-8 with a 3-3 mark in the Ivy League.

After a subpar season, things may only be getting harder for the Bulldogs as their top four scorers graduated after last season. Senior attackman David Anderson, who recorded 21 points for Yale last season, will be the most productive returner.

No. 4 Cornell

Tambroni will face his former team at his current home when No. 4 Cornell travels to face the Nittany Lions on March 7. While the Big Red are only No. 4 in the season-opening poll, they’re coming off a nearly undefeated run to a national championship last season.

Cornell went 18-1 overall and an undefeated 6-0 in the Ivy League. Its last matchup with Penn State came on Memorial Day weekend, when the Big Red defeated the Nittany Lions 11-9 in the NCAA Semifinals.

Perhaps the biggest reason the Big Red are ranked No. 4 after an almost perfect season is the departure of CJ Kirst, who scored an NCAA record 247 goals at Cornell. 82 of those goals came last season on the way to a 115-point season for Kirst.

Junior attackman Ryan Goldstein will have a chance to match Kirst’s 2025 numbers after an already impressive 93 points last season.

No. 6 North Carolina

Penn State will close its non-conference slate on March 14 with a neutral-site game against No. 6 North Carolina in Charlotte.

The Tar Heels went 10-5 in 2025 with a 3-1 record in ACC play. North Carolina made an appearance in the NCAA tournament despite a 14-7 loss to Duke in the ACC tournament, but it lost to Richmond in the first round.

Attackmen Owen Duffy and Dominic Pietramala will return to Chapel Hill this season, a duo that combined for 112 points last year.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Dueling column | Should Penn State fire men’s basketball coach Mike Rhoades?
author: Will Horstman & Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
There’s only been one season in Penn State’s 130-year history when it failed to earn a conference win.

It happened in the 1935-36 Eastern Intercollegiate Conference season in which the Nittany Lions went 0-10. Yet nine decades later, Mike Rhoades’ squad is on track to become the second conference winless team in program history.

With a 0-8 Big Ten record to start the 2025-26 season, Rhoades’ seat seems to have warmed up in Happy Valley.

Will Horstman: If Penn State wants to move on from Mike Rhoades, right now presents an opportunity

Rec Hall lacked energy as Wisconsin earned a 98-71 win over Penn State on Thursday night, dropping the Nittany Lions to 9-10 on the year and 0-8 in Big Ten play. Some fans online have voiced displeasure with Rhoades, who’s in his third season leading the team.

If Penn State’s administration also wants to move on from Rhoades, I believe an opportunity to do so is right now. This year’s start has been subpar, and trends dating back to last season don’t provide a positive outlook on Rhoades succeeding in the future with the Nittany Lions.

Penn State won nine Big Ten games during Rhoades’ first season in Happy Valley with another conference win against Michigan in the Big Ten tournament. The Nittany Lions started the 2024-25 season 12-2, including an upset over No. 8 Purdue.

Since then, however, the Nittany Lions are 13-23 after Thursday’s loss to the Badgers. To make matters worse, only four of those wins are against Big Ten teams, which all came in the latter portion of last season.

The other nine wins are all Quad 4 victories from this season’s nonconference schedule as Penn State has yet to defeat a power-conference opponent this year. I’m concerned for the Nittany Lions as I feel Rhoades’ tendencies and style of play might have been figured out by the rest of the Big Ten.

What’s also concerning is that Penn State shows a lack of adjustments in games. The Nittany Lions had a 13-12 lead over Wisconsin right before a media timeout on Thursday, and the Badgers came out of it by generating a 50-22 advantage at halftime.

Multiple games this season have seen Penn State get in a similar situation and endure a blowout loss, like Indiana’s 113-72 win on Dec. 9 or Maryland’s 96-73 victory last Sunday.

To be fair, the Nittany Lions have kept some contests against top competition close, such as a 74-72 loss to then-No. 2 Michigan earlier this month. But 13 single-digit losses have piled up since Jan. 5, 2025, and recent results make it hard to feel those moral victories are making any progress toward building a program.

It feels like rock bottom for Penn State at this point in the season, and even though I didn’t have many expectations for this year, the lack of effort on defense exhibited by players at times sort of showcases how the season has gone so far.

I have a great deal of respect for Rhoades — he’s brought success to other teams he’s coached, and it’s possible he could end up guiding Penn State to become a better team than it has been. Rhoades and the Nittany Lions are a finalist for 2026 5-star guard Dylan Mingo, who would help Rhoades’ efforts to turn Penn State around if he were to commit.

Rhoades also gave a good answer when asked about the future of Penn State.

"Building a program is really, really hard. Building a program at a place that doesn't have much basketball tradition is even harder, but I signed up for it, man, and I believe in me," Rhoades said postgame Thursday night. "I believe in how we do things. Some of you guys may not. I don't really care. I never cared before, but I'll figure it out. It might kill me, but I'll figure it out."

However, it’s fair to be concerned about the current state of the Nittany Lions, which is increasingly making it tough to envision a bright future. It’s early in Rhoades’ tenure, but a reset on the program might not sound like the worst idea to Penn State’s administration if it wants to look elsewhere for a coach.

Myles Hannak: He’s on his last lifeline, but it’s too early to pull the plug

Penn State men’s basketball isn’t good and historically hasn’t been.

The program made the Final Four only once, in 1954, and there persists a feeling that the Nittany Lions aren’t a “basketball school.” Yes, that notion is correct, and recent history only reinforces that, yet the man in charge for most of those recent years, Rhoades, isn’t to blame.

Rhoades is in the midst of his third season, and after a pair of season finishes around .500, this year seems like it may end up even worse. However, if you believe those results warrant change, let me attempt to sway things.

Since 2000, there have been five head coaches in Happy Valley: Jerry Dunn, Ed DeChellis, Pat Chambers, Micah Shrewsberry and Rhoades. Dunn went 35-54 in the new millennium, Chellis didn’t post a winning season until his sixth year, while Chambers didn’t do so until his fourth.

The lone boss to endure quick success, Shrewsberry, backstabbed Penn State after his second year to leave for Notre Dame, and left big shoes for Rhoades to fill as the next hire. In his second year in charge, Rhoades posted a winning season, and now, even as the record regressed, he brought in the program's best-ever recruiting class, offering optimism that, if given more time, results will prevail.

Those around the team need to level expectations — what exactly is the goal on the hardwood? It should be to provide little wins, boost optimism and change the program's narrative, all things that, in the historical scheme of things, have already been done during Rhoades’ tenure.

Yes, Penn State now has more talent on its roster than in the past, both a negative and a positive for Rhoades, given he’s able to attract it yet hasn’t immediately translated it into results.

However, the grass isn’t always greener, and ditching Rhoades would disrupt the process of what is being built in Happy Valley. Yes, it’s bad now, but you don't get to sunshine without letting the clouds clear first, and Rhoades is the lone boss out there willing to throw himself into the eye of the storm.

Penn State isn’t an attractive job; the administration will always prioritize the other athletic departments over basketball, it’s just the culture, yet Rhoades is the only man to actually attempt to challenge that culture, not just work within the constraints.

Home fan attendance at Penn State has been a concern. While much of the belief in men’s basketball comes from within the program, if those supporting the team showed the same resilience, fans would see that the team's future is more promising than any win total suggests, as it currently seems to be defined by nothing more than that.

If there were a basketball coach fired, Rhoades shouldn’t be the frontrunner, as women’s basketball coach Carolyn Kieger endured just as tumultuous results, and has been extended the grace of seven seasons with only one with a winning record — Rhoades deserves that same patience.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball reflects on future of program in same place it created history
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
In recent years, Penn State has made it a tradition to return to the venue where it all started, Rec Hall, with its brick exterior, decades worth of team photos and a plethora of banners won throughout its storied history.

The Nittany Lions stepped onto the hardwood with a chance to tap into Rec Hall’s rich history, as the blue and white haven’t enjoyed the luxuries of being in the driver's seat this year.

Yet for nearly all 40 minutes of game action, the opposing Wisconsin Badgers held all the control and continued that disappointing trend this season, eventually drowning the Nittany Lions with an emphatic 98-71 win. With the defeat, Penn State fell to 9-10 and stood winless in conference play after eight games.

“I appreciate the administration and our physical plan for getting everything ready for us to play at Rec Hall and all that stuff, and it's a great game. We didn't live up to our end of it,” Mike Rhoades said.

Rhoades’ teams played in Rec Hall every year of his tenure, in an attempt to cultivate a greater basketball culture, yet every crushing defeat, especially in the same place where the program posted its best season ever in 1954 and earned its lone NCAA Final Four appearance, counteracts that effort. This year’s loss marks consecutive blowouts at Rec Hall, with its only win coming off a 90-89 upset over Illinois in 2024.

“We have to have a level of urgency in the program to move forward, and I'll do that,” Rhoades said. “We've shown at times this year. We played good basketball, but not good enough basketball to win in the Big Ten.”

The Nittany Lions, despite what metric or angle taken, failed to display why they’re better than the record suggests, and it’s shaping up to be a heartbreaking season in the grand scheme of things. Penn State brought in the top Big Ten recruiting class this year, and its highest all-time recruit, yet the outlook for the future doesn’t seem to change the narrative of the past.

Despite it being the third year of the “Return to the Rec” and a White Out, during which students in attendance received free towels, it didn’t seem to fill the stands, as the venue failed to reach 6,000 in capacity for the first time since Penn State added the occasion under Rhoades.

“I've coached a long time. I've been on both ends of this. This right now sucks,” Rhoades said. “I'll tell you this thing, my staff and I will give every piece of every fiber we have to try to right this ship … I'm not a quitter, and I hope our fans and our students support these kids, because they're good kids, and they're working really hard. But you're right, you've got to win.”

While it appears those around the team may have seen their faith fractured, the Nittany Lions aren’t phased, which reaffirms how Penn State has endured basketball success previously. Although the recent memories of Rec Hall are rather bitter for the blue and white, the venue symbolizes the unwavering excellence that the university’s athletics embodies.

“We're on the same team, one team. We know our record isn't the best, we're just trying to move forward and reflect and just come back the next day better,” freshman wing Mason Blackwood said. “We all committed to Penn State for a reason… There's no better way to go through it than together. The season’s not over.”

The Nittany Lions have 12 games left, and they’ll search for any chance to finish with a note of optimism, not just for gratification, but to signal to the masses that they are trying and that history will not define or take away from that effort.

“Building a program is really, really hard. Building a program at a place that doesn't have much basketball tradition is even harder, but I signed up for it,” Rhoades said. “ I believe in how we do things. Some of you guys may not – I don't really care, I never cared before. But I'll figure it out. It might kill me, but I’ll figure it out.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Who are the biggest transfers in Penn State's 2026 class?
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Penn State went to work in the first transfer portal window with Matt Campbell at the helm, bringing in 40 total players with 24 of them being from his former team in Iowa State.

Here are 10 new additions to keep an eye on.

Rocco Becht, quarterback

The first name on the list is an obvious one in quarterback Rocco Becht, who will be the starter next season.

He transfers to Penn State after four years at Iowa State, starting in three of them and winning 26 games. Becht threw for 9,274 yards and 64 touchdowns as well as 27 interceptions to go along with 499 yards and 19 scores on the ground.

Becht follows Campbell, offensive coordinator Taylor Mouser and quarterbacks coach Jake Waters from Ames, Iowa, to State College, giving him familiarity.

Time will tell if Becht will be a full-go or even available for spring practice, as he’s coming off of a 2025 campaign where he had a partial labrum tear in his left shoulder, and an AC sprain in his right shoulder.

He recently posted on his Instagram during his visit to Penn State wearing a sling.

Marcus Neal Jr., safety

Becht is the most impactful addition on the offensive side of the ball, but for the defense it’s safety Marcus Neal Jr.

Neal is coming off of a 2025 campaign where he started as a sophomore, notching 40 total tackles, three pass breakups and two interceptions. The year before, he appeared in all 13 games a freshman where he garnered 18 total tackles.

He was rated as a 4-star transfer per 247Sports, ranking as the No. 143 player overall and No. 9 safety. Neal is more than likely the favorite to replace Zakee Wheatley, who exhausted eligibility and declared for the NFL draft.

Caleb Bacon, linebacker

Penn State brought in a trio of key former Iowa State linebackers who were, but of the three, Caleb Bacon is the one to keep an eye on.

He finished his time with the Cyclones by appearing in 35 games, posting 131 total tackles, five pass breakups and two forced fumbles.

Bacon is a walk-on turned scholarship player as well as a former captain. He was rated a 4-star transfer, the No. 118 overall player and the No. 4 linebacker.

There’s a good chance Bacon starts alongside Rojas next year with Amare Campbell transferring to Tennessee and Dom DeLuca graduated.

Benjamin Brahmer, tight end

Benjamin Brahmer was the first player to transfer from Penn State, and he is a worthwhile addition.

The tight end is coming off of a 2025 campaign where he was the third-leading receiver for Iowa State, totaling 37 receptions for 446 yards and six touchdowns.

He was second-team All-Big 12 a year ago, and recorded 75 catches for 977 yards and nine scores during his time with the Cyclones. Brahmer rated as a 4-star transfer and ranked as the No. 41 overall player and No. 3 tight end.

Brahmer is the favorite to start alongside Andrew Rappleyea at tight end next year.

Brock Riker, center

Penn State lost four of five starters on the offensive line from 2025, but the program grabbed an intriguing transfer who is coming off of a strong 2025.

Brock Riker, a 6-foot-4, 285-pound center from Texas State, pledged to Penn State after a redshirt freshman season where he was a second-team All-America selection by The Athletic.

He was a hot topic once entering the portal, holding offers from Alabama, Oklahoma, Utah, Florida, South Carolina and Illinois.

Riker will likely compete with Dom Rulli, who started in the Pinstripe Bowl, for the center spot. Cooper Cousins is another name who could be in the mix, as he played center in high school, but through his first two years at Penn State he’s seen his snaps at guard.

Siale Taupaki, defensive tackle

Along with other young talent, Penn State lost all three of its top defensive tackles as Zane Durant and Alonzo Ford Jr. are off to the NFL draft while Xavier Gilliam transferred to Tennessee.

Penn State addressed the position with a handful of players — One of those players is Siale Taupaki.

Taupaki, who comes from UCLA, is entering his eighth year of college football.

He’ll reunite with defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn and defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe, who both coached him with the Bruins. During his time there, Taupaki appeared on defense in 33 games, garnering 38 total tackles, three tackles for loss and two sacks.

Brett Eskildsen, wide receiver

Penn State lost Trebor Peña, Devonte Ross and Kyron Hudson to the NFL, but in comes Brett Eskildsen.

A season ago he was the leading receiver in new receivers coach Noah Pauley's room, accumulating 30 catches for 526 yards and five touchdowns.

Alexander McPherson, defensive end

The Nittany Lions lost a talented young defensive end in Chaz Coleman, who transferred to Tennessee, and brought in Alexander McPherson.

The incoming sophomore played his high school ball at national powerhouse IMG Academy in Florida, and pledged to Colorado as a 3-star recruit.

McPherson appeared in 10 games between defense and special teams during his freshman campaign, missing two due to injury, and tallied 16 total tackles, six quarterback hurries and a blocked punt.

Jeremiah Cooper, defensive back

Jeremiah Cooper is an intriguing addition for the secondary, as he was an All-Big 12 selection in 2023.

Cooper started his career as a safety, but transitioned to cornerback for 2025, but only played in four games due to a season-ending knee injury.

In four seasons with Iowa State, he recorded 138 total tackles and eight interceptions.

Cristiano Rosa, kickoff specialist

The Nittany Lions replaced kickoff specialist Gabe Nwosu with a player from a 2025 College Football Playoff team in Cristiano Rosa. He notched 52 touchbacks in two years in the role for James Madison.

He also seems to have ties to Penn State, as he posted a photo on his Instagram of him as a kid wearing a jersey.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Rec Hall Rout | Penn State men’s basketball dominated by Wisconsin in annual Rec Hall game
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
SWH: Rec Hall Rout | Penn State men’s basketball dominated by Wisconsin in annual Rec Hall game

SEO: Rec Hall Rout | Penn State men’s basketball dominated by Wisconsin in annual Rec Hall game

Art: Mike Rhoades or team huddle/timeout

By: Chase Mitchell

X: @thefifthcm

PSU Email: cmm8773@psu.edu

Rec Hall and The Palestra have something in common. It’s not just the fact that they were both designed by the same architect.

Designed by Charles Z. Klauder, Rec Hall was completed in 1928. Just a year prior, Klauder’s other design, The Palestra, opened in Philadelphia.

That’s not where the similarities between the two arenas end, though, as Penn State has now lost in both historic venues this season.

The Nittany Lions welcomed 13-5 Wisconsin but had its Rec Hall reunion ruined, falling to the Badgers 98-71 to remain winless in conference play and fall into a now six-game losing streak

“Building a program is really, really hard,” Mike Rhoades said. “Building a program at a place that doesn’t have much basketball tradition is even harder, but I signed up for it, man, and I believe in me.”

Wisconsin won the opening tipoff, but Kayden Mingo opened the scoring for the evening after a little bit of back-and-forth.

Mingo called his own name again, hitting a step-back jumper to put the blue and white up 4-0 in the early running.

Penn State let the Badgers work it to a 9-8 Wisconsin lead quickly after some soft defense and a three-pointer given up for a one-point deficit that lingered for a while.

Thanks to an Ivan Jurić board that led to a Freddie Dilione V and Melih Tunca connection, the Nittany Lions moved back in front and seized the momentum, even picking up a foul.

A near four-point play became three-straight charity stripe makes for Braeden Carrington, which once again gave the Badgers a comfortable lead at 23-13, forcing Rhoades and the blue and white into a timeout.

The Nittany Lions fell into an 18-point hole after a tough possession from Jurić and Mingo ended without a score, which made Penn State take another one of its timeouts.

It only got worse from then on out for the blue and white, as a three-pointer from Andrew Rohde and another one from Carrington contributed to a 21-1 Wisconsin scoring run that made it a 42-17 Badger lead with just under three minutes left in the first half.

The student section voiced its dismay with boos, “sell the team” chants and other jeers as Penn State went to the locker room at halftime, facing a 50-22 deficit. Josh Reed and Wisconsin’s Austin Rapp exchanged words and got a little chippy after the buzzer.

“We have nothing to lose,” Reed said. “(We’re) just going out there and trying to play as hard as we can every single game and see where it takes us.”

A Wisconsin travel call was the only thing that went the blue and white’s way in the early running of the second half as the Nittany Lions went nearly three minutes without a score.

Mason Blackwood knocked one down to cut it to a 60-30 deficit, but any chance Penn State had of making it competitive was well behind it. There was no shortage of scoring for the Badgers, though, with everyone getting in on the action as three exceeded the double-digit mark.

With just 11 minutes remaining in a game that was already a blowout, a three-pointer from Reed followed by Dilione and Mingo scores at least kept the student section alive.

Some physical defense from Mingo, still donning the face shield, wasn’t enough to stop the Badgers from making it a 31-point game on an extended possession that ended in a Nolan Winter basket.

Wisconsin was shooting 40% from three-point range when a Zach Kinziger three-ball gave his squad a drowning 84-47 advantage. The Badgers ended the night 15-35 from that range for 43% compared to the Nittany Lions’ 8-27, with Reed shooting 100% from three-point range.

“The best way to keep a team from hitting a lot of threes is limiting the number of attempts,” Rhoades said. “My teams have done that, and we’re not doing, and we’re getting really behind. When you get behind, you’re giving good shooters shots, they get going, then they start attacking you.”

The once-excited crowd at the annual game diminished to about the size of a pep rally halfway through the second period, with many sarcastically cheering anytime Penn State chipped away at the 35-point gap.

A Dilione scoop-and-score was one of the few blue and white highlights in the second half, but just a few minutes later, the clock read zeros and showed the Badgers as the victors, capturing a 98-71 win.

“We all came here to play basketball. We all committed to Penn State for a reason,” Blackwood said. “There’s no better way to go through it than together. Season’s not over.”

Injury Report

With Kayden Mingo and Freddie Dilione V now back in the lineup for Penn State, the Nittany Lions are just without forward Tibor Mirtič, who was listed as “questionable” with a knee injury that he is rehabbing.

Up Next

Still winless in conference play, Penn State looks to snap its six-game losing streak when it heads to Columbus to take on Ohio State on Monday.

Tipoff is scheduled for 7 p.m.

title: A major snow storm is coming to State College. Here's what we know
author: Neel Ved | The Daily Collegian
description:
This is a developing story.

The National Weather Service (NWS) has placed State College under a Winter Storm Watch beginning Saturday evening through Monday afternoon.

As of Thursday night, total snow accumulations are too early to predict, but there is a 90% chance of seeing six or more inches of snow across Pennsylvania, according to John Bowen, a meteorologist from the NWS in State College.

The NWS website says 10 or more inches of snow may be possible in the Centre County region.

There is also a chance of getting a foot or more of snow in the Susquehanna Valley in towns such as Harrisburg, Bowen added.

He said there will be a better prediction with later model runs of the high-resolution rapid refresh, a numerical weather prediction model, later today and tomorrow.

Bob Larson, a senior meteorologist at AccuWeather, told the Collegian this could be one of the bigger snowstorms State College has seen in a while.

“There has definitely been a lack of major snowstorms recently,” Larson said.

The last time State College received more than six inches of snow was back in January of 2022, when 6.7 inches fell. The last time 12 or more inches fell was back in 2021 from Jan.31–Feb. 2 when 14.5 inches hit the ground, according to Larson.

Bowen recommends staying inside throughout the weekend and waiting to shovel snow after the storm as the cold temperatures can cause hypothermia and other health issues.

Potential impacts

CATA bus schedule or route changes are possible depending on the impacts of the storm, but there's no definitive change as of right now, Adam Simpson of CATA told the Collegian.

Simpson said supervisors will be on the road and reporting back to dispatchers during the expected duration of the storm. He advises riders to check the CATA website for any alerts.

Class cancellation and other official closedowns are up to the discretion of the university. Information will be shared via Penn State News, the PSUAlert system and WPSU-FM.

Tips

Stay home if possibleStock up on water and non-perishable foodShovel snow after the storm as the cold temperatures can cause hypothermia and other health issuesFill your gas tankCharge your devicesMake sure you have a flashlightNever use grills, ovens or other indoor heaters for warmth due to carbon monoxide risks

title: Two Penn State students charged for posting bomb threat during finals week
author: Grace Levy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Two Penn State students are facing charges after police became aware of an alleged bomb threat during the 2025 fall semester finals week.

Madeline Cole Steczkowski, 19, was charged with three misdemeanor counts of making terroristic threats, one misdemeanor count of conspiracy to commit terroristic threats and three misdemeanor counts of bomb threats while Carolyn Eleanor Kahn, 19, was charged with four misdemeanor counts of making terroristic threats.

Penn State police were alerted to the alleged bomb threat posted to the social media app, YikYak, according to the affidavit of probable cause. The threat alleged there was a bomb in the Forum Building and the person who posted it threatened to “shoot this place up.” This attack was allegedly going to occur at 10 a.m. on Dec. 16.

The Penn State University Police and Public Safety, Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI), Ferguson Township Police, State College Police and UPPS bomb squad responded to the threat and obtained records via YikYak, eventually identifying Steczkowski as the threat’s alleged poster, according to the affidavit.

Officers ensured the “immediate safety of building occupants” and reported finding no suspicious items in the Forum Building, according to the affidavit.

Steczkowski was located that morning and interviewed by police. According to the complaint, she shared that she and her roommate, Kahn, were complaining about finals and discussed sending a threat.

Allegedly, Steczkowski would be paid $10 by Kahn to post the threat on YikYak, which was intended to disrupt an exam Kahn was scheduled to take at noon. \

In her interview, Steczkowski acknowledged the mass shooting that had occurred earlier in the week at Brown University and that “the posting could cause panic/alarm,” according to the affidavit, but she “didn't think the messages would be taken seriously” or “expect the posts to be tracked back to her.”

The affidavit described Steczkowski as “emotional and apologetic” and that she was aware that her actions were against the law.

Police later interviewed Kahn, who allegedly advised Steczkowski that the threat was “a bad idea and that someone would take it seriously,” according to the affidavit.

Neither Steczkowski or Kahn own firearms or had conducted research related to the creation of weapons of mass destruction, according to the affidavit.

UPPS determined there was no threat and all exams were taken as scheduled, according to a Penn State spokesperson. Both students are still currently enrolled and the university has also referred the case to the Office of Student Accountability and Conflict Response for potential student conduct action.

The pair was charged via summons sent on Jan. 16 and a preliminary hearing is scheduled for Feb. 18.

title: ‘It was pretty cool to be a part of' | Penn State’s PJ Duke continues to prove no moment is too big
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
PJ Duke has wrestled all across the world, most of the time without a hostile environment against him.

However, that changed when he stepped foot on the mat in Carver-Hawkeye Arena for what was considered a highly anticipated dual against No. 4 Iowa on Friday.

“It was a pretty crazy environment,” Duke said. “It's like something you dream about your whole life. Iowa has a good reputation for fans and put on a good show, so it was pretty cool to be a part of.”

In the 157-pound matchup, Duke went to battle against No. 12 Jordan Williams in front of the raucous environment. It was his first real test, similar to fellow freshman and 133-pounder Marcus Blaze.

Blaze faced national finalist Drake Ayala. Similar to Duke, Blaze won his matchup 4-2, needing just one takedown to get the job done.

“We both have pretty similar mindsets,” Duke said. “So, no matter where it is, whether it's in practice or an actual match or wherever, just try to be the same person as always.”

Duke faced a wrestler who was on the defensive side more than the offensive. For a wrestler like the Nittany Lion who enjoys putting up a lot of points, it was a much different match than what he’s used to.

Despite this, he remained centered and relaxed, and pounced on the opportunity when it arose, giving him the only takedown of the match.

“I would say I was kind of chasing him a little but he was more defensive, and I would say most of the Iowa teams got more defensive the whole time, and just had to be patient,” Duke said. “I knew an opening would eventually come and once it did, I took advantage of it, took him down and that was pretty much the match.”

The true freshmen have taken the wrestling world by storm this season. Not just Duke and Blaze, but the entire class, including Oklahoma State’s trio of Ladarion Lockett, Sergio Vega and Landon Robideau. Duke and Blaze are in a very strong position to eventually be at the top of the rankings in their respective weight class.

Even with being the top-two ranked wrestlers in the Class of 2025, the success Duke has had wasn’t anticipated. Most freshmen don’t have the capabilities to start 11-0, like Duke is currently. Additionally, most freshmen go the early redshirt route, and in Duke’s case, the redshirt would’ve been an easy path with preseason national title favorite Tyler Kasak at the same weight class.

Despite this, Duke is the 157-pound wrestler for his freshman season and could very well win the national title.

“I would definitely be pretty surprised,” Duke said. “I’m grateful to be where I am now, and I put in a lot of work in the past. I think I hold myself to a pretty high standard, so I’ll definitely be proud of myself.”

With Duke already into the top three in his weight class, Penn State’s team could very well exceed the point total of last year’s record-setting team at the NCAA Championships. The way things are run at Penn State is unlike anywhere else, as the team continues to raise the ceiling year in and year out.

“I would say a lot of teams aren’t like that,” Duke said. “Everyone’s successful and everyone wants each other to get better. Most of the time when people are successful, they break it down. But not here, it’s way different. Everyone wants you to get better, to do better.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Editorial | Students are already using AI. Universities should teach them how.
author: The Daily Collegian’s editorial opinion is determined by its Board of Editors, with the editor-in-chief holding final responsibility for content.
description:
From AI-enabled medical devices to self-driving cars, artificial intelligence has transformed the way we work and live. Yet many universities and professors are responding to this shift with avoidance instead of education, leaving students unprepared to enter an AI-driven workforce and navigate the technology’s ethical complexities.

This approach is ignoring what’s already happening on college campuses. According to Stanford University’s 2025 AI Index Report, 86% of students utilize AI for school work, while 61% of faculty incorporate it into their teaching.

As AI becomes increasingly accessible, universities have a responsibility to equip students with the skills demanded by a changing workforce and to educate them about algorithmic bias, environmental harm, plagiarism and accuracy concerns.

Generative AI platforms like ChatGPT, Claude, CoPilot and Gemini have gained popularity in recent years, but artificial intelligence itself is not new. For decades, other forms of AI have been used for data analysis, pattern recognition and automation.

What distinguishes generative AI is its ability to create text, images and code using existing data. Its capacity to produce original-seeming work has driven concern surrounding academic integrity and sparked conversations over what constitutes appropriate versus unethical use in both classrooms and everyday life.

Despite this, only 39% of academic institutions had an AI-related acceptable use policy as of early 2025, according to Stanford’s report. While Penn State doesn’t have a university-wide AI policy, it implements course-specific policy and provides general guidelines for both students and professors.

Last year, Penn State launched an artificial intelligence engineering major and minor, making it stand out among universities preparing future engineers to build and refine these systems.

However, AI’s influence extends far beyond engineering. This technology is rapidly entering fields across the liberal arts, business, journalism, healthcare and many other disciplines.

Whether we like it or not, this integration is largely beyond our control, as employers across industries are already using AI tools to cut costs, increase efficiency and remain competitive.

What is within our control is how we’re navigating it.

Universities should not encourage students to have AI complete their work for them. Instead, institutions and professors must teach students what AI is already being used for in their respective industries, and when it shouldn’t be used and why.

While universities are still deciding how to approach AI in the classrooms, it’s evident that education on the matter is essential in preparing graduates who will work alongside AI in their careers. Acting as though AI doesn’t exist or banning its use outright is disservicing students.

Fear-based conversations don’t prepare students for life after graduation; thoughtful, honest discussions about the realities and future of AI do.

Understanding both the benefits and drawbacks of AI technology not only prepares students for the inevitable but provides them with the knowledge to make informed decisions about their AI use.

As AI use expands, it is imperative that conversations about misuse, along with environmental and societal impacts, expand as well.

According to Harvard Business Review, the training process for one AI model releases carbon emissions equivalent to those of hundreds of homes nationwide and has caused severe stress on our freshwater resources. These impacts disproportionately burden vulnerable communities.

The rise of generative AI has also intensified ethical concerns around plagiarism, originality and accuracy. Because these tools generate content based on existing material, students must be taught how to use them in appropriate contexts and how to properly evaluate and verify AI-produced information.

AI systems are also prone to factual errors and bias, making human oversight imperative. Without instruction on when AI use crosses ethical boundaries and when it can be used responsibly as a tool, students are left to navigate these risks on their own.

Furthermore, AI bias stems from both explicit and implicit human biases embedded in various stages of its pipeline, from data collection and labeling to model training and deployment, according to Chapman University. The system has already produced unfair and discriminatory bias in reporting, sourcing and continues to reinforce existing biases.

As AI continues to evolve and become used on a wider scale, it’s of the utmost importance that higher education institutions educate their students on how AI is utilized and how to engage with the technology responsibly.

A comprehensive AI education should force people to rethink the way they engage with artificial intelligence.

The Daily Collegian Opinions Editor Teresa Phelan can be reached at tpp5354@psu.edu.

MORE EDITORIALS

title: Stomp Out Stigma event helps students learn about mental health through art
author: Jacob Godshall | The Daily Collegian
description:
University Health Services (UHS), Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) and the Jana Marie Foundation hosted a Stomp Out Stigma event Thursday in Hub-Robeson Center.

During the event attendees discussed the stigma around mental health and helped create a “stomper statue art installation.”

The event was part of the larger Stompers Project created by the Jana Marie Foundation, where community members connect their mental health to art, and go through educational workshops to better spread awareness of mental health struggles in their communities.

While they have these conversations, the attendees paint parts of old shoes and sneakers to later be assembled into a human statue, or “stomper.”

The group worked through several activities, discussing personal stories in order to connect and listen, writing down strategies on sticky-notes to help both oneself and others and finally working together to paint the shoes for the statue.

Stephanie Stama, assistant director of community education and outreach for CAPS, said she wants to help Penn State “stomp out the stigma,” of mental health struggles.

“I think one of the greatest stigmas that we notice at the counseling center is students who maybe don't feel like their problems are concerning enough or problematic enough,” Stama, one of the organizers of the event, said. “They (may have come) from a family or culture of ‘Do it yourself, you can take care of it,’ or a culture where mental health maybe isn't considered a problem.”

Emotional and psychological health are “just as important” as physical health, according to Stama.

Stama revealed the final stomper will be displayed on the ground floor of the Student Health Center.

“That way, anyone coming in for health services or for counseling services in the building, they will be able to see the hard work that people have left a legacy for,” Stama said.

Jason Yoder said both education about mental health stigmas and creating visual representations of mental health struggles are important.

“Once this is up, as they are walking by, it will just always be there 24/7, but I don't think that's the takeaway from all of our other outreaches,” Yoder, a CAPS chat coordinator, said.

CAPS wants to spread the message that it cares about students, and they always have resources and people available to them on campus, according to Yoder.

Meet Raje said he attended the event in order to support his friend back home.

“If I were to make something or learn something, I could bring that home to him, and since he is a dear friend of mine, that would mean a lot,” Raje, a first-year studying chemical engineering, said.

Raje said he’s learned that it’s helpful just to talk, whether you’re struggling yourself, or know someone else that’s struggling.

“That's really all it is — just start talking,” Raje said, “It sounds dumb, but just rambling … makes it seem like they are seen in a way.”

MORE CAMPUS CONTENT

title: Report: Penn State adds matchup with Maine to 2027 schedule
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
A replacement has been found for Penn State's 2027 schedule.

The Nittany Lions will host Maine at Beaver Stadium, according to Matt Fortuna of the Inside Zone.

The matchup against the Black Bears comes in light of Wednesday's news where Penn State and Delaware mutually agreed to cancel their matchup in 2027.

Per Fortuna, the Nittany Lions and Delaware worked together to find replacements, and the Blue Hens will cover the difference in guaranteed cost for the cancellation. Delaware will now face Illinois as part of their 2027 schedule.

When Maine arrives in State College in two years, it'll mark the first time the two sides have played each other.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Former Penn State OL Brady O'Hara transfers to Monmouth
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former Penn State offensive lineman has found their transfer portal destination.

Freshman Brady O'Hara has signed with Monmouth, the team announced on Tuesday via X.

Shore bound 🏖️Brady O’Hara has officially joined Monmouth ✍️#FlyHawks || @_bradyohara pic.twitter.com/xVrALEyk31— Monmouth Football (@MUHawksFB) January 20, 2026

O'Hara didn't appear in any game this past season, so he'll have four years of eligibility remaining.

The Mars, Pennsylvania, native was a 247Sports composite 3-star in the 2025 class. He ranked as the No. 665 player nationally, No. 47 interior offensive lineman and No. 17 player from his home state.

He was viewed as a long-term project after playing tight end in high school, but will now look to develop at Monmouth.

For live updates on Penn State's returnees, transfers and departures, click here.
