title: ‘Stories like Keaghan's gives people hope’ | THON family reflects on journey to bell ringing
author: Emma Naysmith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Parents of 10-year-old Keaghan Faulders, Bryan and Kaitland, describe their daughter as having a “spunky personality” and a “no-quit attitude.”

After receiving a diagnosis of T-cell Leukemia in 2022, Keaghan, just shy of age 7, was scheduled for immediate surgery and treatment.

“We just kind of took it in stride,” Bryan said. “We enjoyed the good days, which that first year was few, far and in between, but we enjoyed the good days. The days that were a struggle, or spike in fevers, she wasn't feeling well, we stayed by her side.”

Soon after the initial diagnosis, Bryan said they were introduced to THON and the Four Diamonds, and a “weight was lifted off their shoulders.”

“In the back of your mind, you're thinking in your head, ‘Well, one, let's get her feeling better,’” Bryan said. “But two, how the heck are we going to pay for this? And how are we going to afford this down the road? And we'll figure it out, but it's going to be a long journey.”

THON is the world's largest student-run philanthropy that aims to provide emotional and financial support to Four Diamonds families who have been impacted by childhood cancer.

In their third year as a THON family, the Faulders finally made it to THON Weekend after watching on TV years prior. Keaghan was “over the moon” to attend live, and can’t wait for THON 2026.

“When we felt isolated as a childhood cancer family at the beginning, and we weren't sure who to connect with,” Kaitland said. “THON really pulled us in. They kind of wrapped us up in their energy, and you don't really understand the energy until you go to THON.”

The Faulders family is paired with the Penn State figure skating team through the THON “Adopt-a-Family” program. Kaitland said they have supported her family through all of their highs and lows.

Ice skating team member and THON Chair Emma Wassel said Keaghan and her family will always be an inspiration for the group, and is the strongest girl they know.

“We have a teammate this year, Lillie Nye, and she has gotten very involved in THON and with the Faulders the last couple of years,” Wassel, a fifth-year studying integrated arts, said. “She's actually skating a tribute program to those we have lost. She will be competing with that program, which is a really cool thing for us to see.”

Throughout treatment, Keaghan demonstrated impressive strength in her ability to bounce back after tougher days, according to her father.

“That little spark there that she has just does not let cancer steal her joy,” Bryan said. “It's just pure key. And wanting to help out where she could, when she could and giving back to the hospital. These kids are resilient … if the kids were feeling okay, they had a smile on their face, not a care in the world, and just powerin’ through.”

In addition to treatment in the hospital, Keaghan spent her time running her own nail salon, playing Uno with nurses and even donated her hair to create a wig for another child fighting cancer.

“Her ability to connect with adults and nurses and volunteers and teachers that came into the hospital just like they're just normal people and even other kids that were battling cancer,” Kaitland said. “It was quite amazing to see both her strength and her personality continue to show through no matter how she felt.”

Keaghan’s resilience was rewarded with remission in 2023 and a long-awaited bell ringing in May 2025 to symbolize the end of her cancer treatment.

Keaghan’s father said it was one of the “proudest days of his life” and her mother said it symbolized survival and a thankfulness to ring the bell and celebrate its meaning after passing by it thousands of times throughout their treatment journey.

“For Keaghan and even for us, it was really more to end the fight that she never asked to face, it is just the strength that we saw behind her,” Kaitland said. “For us, it just symbolized that we survived. We're so happy we got here. We're so proud.”

Wassel said she was lucky enough to be personally invited by Keaghan to support her in ringing the bell at the Penn State Health Children’s Hospital. Additionally, she said the team looks forward to welcoming her onto the ice rink for her first time skating.

“Keaghan's story is just so inspiring for us as a team,” Wassel said. “A lot of us kind of grew up in a solo sport, one where we didn't really have teamwork and like that kind of level of camaraderie, and so the Faulders have such a strong team of friends and family that were and are still backing them throughout Keaghan’s battle, and they show us that there’s strength in leaning on those who love you.

Kaitland said "stories like Keaghan's gives people hope.” Hope to those standing THON Weekend, and hope to families facing similar challenges.

“THON is so powerful because it is very personal for the families of the cancer children, but I hope when they hear stories about a real child like Keaghan, we are a real family, and we've lived the long nights,” Kaitland said. “We’ve felt their fear, we’ve praised the victories.”

MORE THON CONTENT

title: Get to know Penn State linebackers coach Tyson Veidt
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Being the linebackers coach at Penn State comes with an expectation to churn out elite talent from the program known nationwide as “LBU.”

Matt Campbell picked his guy for that job on Jan. 2, bringing Tyson Veidt over from Cincinnati to oversee the linebackers. Dan Connor, who was the linebackers coach in 2025, is set to remain on staff and will do more day-to-day coaching with that position group.

Here’s what to know about the Nittany Lions’ new linebackers coach.

Coaching history

Veidt has spent the last two seasons as the Bearcats’ defensive coordinator, but the initial report of his hiring to Penn State said the two parties mutually agreed to part ways. Cincinnati allowed 25.6 points per game under Veidt in 2025.

Prior to his short stint at Cincinnati, Veidt worked under Campbell for eight seasons as Iowa State’s associate head coach and linebackers coach. He was named the Football Scoop National Linebacker Coach of the Year in 2017 and earned a Broyles Award nomination the year after.

Veidt had all three of his starting linebackers earn All-Big 12 honors in three straight seasons from 2017-19 and helped coach 45 all-conference defenders during his time with the Cyclones.

Campbell originally found Veidt at Toledo, where the linebackers coach spent the 2014-15 seasons. Veidt also served as the recruiting coordinator for the Rockets.

Veidt was the head coach at Bluffton University, a Division III school in Ohio, from 2008-13. He helped his squad break 40 records at a school that had won just one game the year before Veidt’s arrival.

His coaching career began at Muskingum University, where he played collegiate football from 1992-95. Veidt joined as a graduate assistant in 1997 before moving laterally to Indiana in 1999.

A year later, Veidt returned to his alma mater to be the defensive coordinator, a role he held from 2000-03. In 2004, he joined West Virginia as a graduate assistant but returned to calling plays in 2006 for Saint Vincent in Pennsylvania.

Prominent players coached

Veidt coached plenty of successful linebackers at Iowa State, including Willie Harvey and Jake Hummel.

Harvey earned three straight All-Big 12 honorable mentions from 2016-18 and finished his career with 289 tackles, 31 tackles for loss and 12.5 sacks. He signed with the Cleveland Browns as an undrafted free agent in 2019 and is now in the United Football League, where he’s earned two All-UFL team selections.

Hummel played at Iowa State from 2017-21, tallying 228 tackles, 18 tackles for loss, two sacks and three interceptions across his career. He went undrafted in 2022, but signed with the Los Angeles Rams, where he spent three seasons before signing with the Baltimore Ravens in 2025.

Veidt also coached a pair of All-Americans at Iowa State in Joel Lanning and Mike Rose. Lanning was a First Team All-America selection in 2017 after converting from quarterback to linebacker in his very last season as a Cyclone.

Lanning tallied 114 tackles, 11 tackles for loss, six sacks and one interception in his lone year as a linebacker. He signed with the Dallas Cowboys as an undrafted free agent in 2018, marking his lone year in the NFL.

Rose was named the Big 12 Defensive Most Valuable Player in 2020 as a junior and was selected as a freshman All-American by the FWAA. The Ohio native wound up finishing his career with 41 tackles for loss and signed with the Kansas City Chiefs as an undrafted free agent in 2022. He is now with the St. Louis Battlehawks of the UFL.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: 3 key games to watch in No. 7 Penn State men’s lacrosse’s 2026 regular season
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 7 Penn State, after blazing a path to the NCAA National Semifinal game at Gillette Stadium, generally faces a difficult schedule year-after-year. Being a member of the ever-competitive Big Ten, as well as consistently scheduling quality non-conference opponents, there are a plethora of important games to gauge the long-term success of the coming 2026 season.

Here are my picks for the three most important games of the Nittany Lions’ upcoming regular season.

Penn State vs. Colgate | Feb. 1

In the all-important season opener, Penn State will host Colgate at Panzer Stadium to kick off the fresh calendar with a rematch of 2025’s NCAA Tournament first-round matchup.

The Nittany Lions faced the Raiders twice last season, winning both games despite the two being spread out throughout the year. On Feb. 1, 2025, Penn State opened its season with a 14-9 victory over Colgate at home. Then, on May 10, the blue and white defeated the Raiders 13-11, advancing to the National Quarterfinal.

Colgate returned its fourth-highest goal-scorer in Hunter Drouin, who tallied 32 goals and 16 assists last season. However, the Raiders’ top-three producers have since graduated or hit the transfer portal, making their offensive core appear vastly different.

Penn State vs. No. 4 Cornell | March. 7

The Nittany Lions have a chance at taking their revenge on the team that eliminated them in the National Semifinals: No. 4 Cornell per Inside Lacrosse.

Despite falling in the tournament, the blue and white were the only team in 2025 to beat Cornell. And it was a thriller, to say the least. On March. 8, Penn State clawed back from a four-goal deficit with under three minutes left to play in the fourth quarter. In overtime, senior Ethan Long dealt the final blow and secured a road victory over the eventual national champions.

But nothing else mattered in Foxborough, Massachusetts, on May. 24. With a national championship berth on the line, the Nittany Lions fought to a 5-4 lead going into the second half. However, a six-goal third quarter from the Big Red widened the gap too far for the blue and white’s comeback attempt. Penn State lost 11-9.

And that was with Penn State silencing Cornell’s most elite attackman, Tewaaraton Award winner CJ Kirst. However, many of the Big Red’s top-performers graduated as well, including Kirst, presenting a new look for the defending national champions.

But if there’s anything that the collegiate lacrosse world knows about Cornell, it’s that coach Connor Buczek’s teams are tough to beat, no matter who’s on the field.

Penn State vs. No. 1 Maryland | March. 21

The Big Ten is a gauntlet of a conference and although the Terrapins didn’t win the Big Ten championship, Maryland went all the way to the National Championship game before being taken down by Cornell, 13-10.

Penn State will open Big Ten play at Panzer Stadium against Maryland at 3 p.m on March. 21.

The Nittany Lions met the Terrapins twice in 2025, first in the regular season, where the then-second ranked team in the nation defeated the blue and white 13-8 in College Park, Maryland. Then, in the Big Ten semifinals, Maryland defeated Penn State 10-8 in Ann Arbor, Michigan.

After going 14-4 overall last season, the Terrapins were ranked No. 1 in Inside Lacrosse’s Preseason Media Poll. On offense, Maryland retained star-attackman Eric Spanos as well as rising senior Braden Erksa.

Spanos was the Terrapins’ leading scorer last year, netting 36 goals while adding 19 helpers for a team-high 55 points. Meanwhile, Erksa wasn’t far behind with 33 goals and 15 assists.

With the national runner-ups maintaining much of their attacking power, Maryland is set to make another deep run in both the Big Ten and national tournaments. The game against Maryland presents one of Penn State’s biggest tests of the season.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Preview | No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey returns home for series against Delaware
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State earned its first sweep of the new year as the Nittany Lions left New York with two wins over Syracuse. The series featured four different goal scorers for Penn State over the course of seven goals. Syracuse gave the Nittany Lions a scare to conclude the series; however, it could pose as a step in the right direction. After a brief stint of unsuccessful games, the blue and white followed the series with a win over No. 12 Cornell.

Penn State now shifts its focus to its first home series of 2026 against another conference opponent in Delaware. The teams previously met on Oct. 10 and Oct. 11. The Nittany Lions swept the Blue Hens with two shutouts at Fred Rust Ice Arena.

Senior weekend

Several seniors and graduate students receive honors throughout the upcoming series against the Blue Hens. Tessa Janecke, Mya Vaslet, Katelyn Roberts, Katie DeSa, Kendall Butze, Maddy Christian, Leah Stecker and Taylor Lum will all be a part of a memorable moment that will be etched in their lives.

All players successfully did their part throughout the season. From breaking records to being a reliable goal scorer with the puck on their stick. These athletes made their presence known in their final year of collegiate hockey. With a few weeks left in the season and postseason on the rise, expect to hear these names more before the season is all said and done.

Blocked shots bonanza

An interesting stat jumps out when looking at the Delaware team. The Blue Hens led the conference in blocked shots as a team with 616, averaging just under 24 per game. That number sits 200 more than the second-place team.

The defensive unit excelled at defending their net, clogging shooting lanes and putting their body on the line. Penn State suffered a few blocked shots over the season, some of which were taken the other way. This area of their game will need to be adjusted to avoid costly turnovers.

To do so, the Nittany Lions need to elevate the puck and create routine, quick passes to open up shooting lanes.

Possible advantage?

The Nittany Lions played three games in five days over the weekend and into the week. However, Delaware hasn’t played since Jan. 17. This could result in slower line changes and breakouts than a slightly more rested Blue Hens team.

Additionally, travel could play a role, as Penn State’s game against the Big Red was held in New York as well. Ultimately, the Nittany Lions have less time than normal to practice and study for their upcoming series.

Enter DeSa, Exit Janecke and Nicole Hall

Katie DeSa returned to the lineup against Cornell after missing the previous four games with an apparent injury suffered in the series against Ohio State. Picking up where she left off, the senior looked stellar in net as she made 24 saves on 25 shots, only allowing one goal early in the second period.

However, on the forwards front, this series will be the last before both Janecke and Hall depart for Milan, Italy, to participate in the Winter Olympics. The Nittany Lions have been playing without their freshman goal-scorer, Matilde Fantin, for the previous few games. With the addition of two other goal-scorers leaving, the forward depth of Penn State will be challenged in the series to come.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State set for matchup with McKendree
author: George Keene | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s volleyball is off to a fast start, winning its first four matches of the season and dropping only two sets total.

However, the Nittany Lions head to Illinois to take on No. 15 McKendree for their first road trip of the season at 7 p.m. Friday and 5 p.m. Saturday.

McKendree had an uphill climb to start the season, causing it to get off to a slow start, dropping matches against No. 1 UCLA and No. 3 Long Beach State. The Bearcats suffered a sweep in both matches.

McKendree bounced back at the UC Invitational, claiming a 3-1 victory over the University of Charleston and a 3-0 victory against Mount Olive.

This week’s battle against Penn State will be McKendree’s first home matches of the season, where it was dominant last year, winning 13 of 15 on their home floor. On the opposite side of the net, Penn State was .500 away from Happy Valley last season.

Heading into the matchup, both teams have been led by their stars early this season.

Sean Harvey seized the reins so far, collecting 48 kills and only 11 errors through four matches. Gaige Gabriel and Matthew Luoma have also performed well thus far, each with 28 kills. If the blue and white frontline can hit efficiently and keep the pressure on the Bearcats’ backline, they give themselves a good shot.

For the Bearcats, they’re being led by a trio of their own. Tyler Tripp and Bryce Wetjen each have 41 kills, and Sam Hoskin trails them with 36 so far this season. As a squad, the Bearcats struggled on the serve, only creating 17 aces and 60 errors.

Similarly, Penn State hasn’t been dominant in serving the ball, ranking 22nd in the NCAA with 1.50 aces per set. McKendree is a few spots below, at 1.31 aces per set.

Dominating play at the net will be integral in coming away with victories this weekend, as both teams created success by attacking this season.

Penn State is hitting .319 compared to McKendree’s .294; both rank in the top 21 in the NCAA. Penn State and McKendree faced off only one time in 2019, with Penn State grabbing the home victory.

Both teams are hot and come into the double header on win streaks, but one’s momentum is coming to an end this weekend.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Position preview | Penn State softball returns multitude of veteran infielders
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
With the 2026 season just around the corner, Penn State has a chance to bounce back after a rocky 2025 campaign. The Nittany Lions came up short of reaching the NCAA Tournament after reaching it in 2024, following their loss to Nebraska in the Big Ten quarterfinals and finished the year with a 25-27 record.

The blue and white raked in the batter’s box last season and set multiple new single-season program records in batting average, home runs, RBIs, runs scored and total bases. Many of the squad’s heavy bats come from the infield.

Clarisa Crowell’s infield is spearheaded by a few returning players and a lot of fresh faces.

Juniors Kaylie Walters and Michela Barbanente will offer veteran leadership inside the diamond. Walters was an offensive anchor for the blue and white last season as the primary shortstop. The Philadelphia native started all 52 games and had a .350 average with 42 hits in 120 at-bats.

However, Walters must clean up her defense as she committed the most errors on the squad with 10 in the 2025 campaign.

Barbanente was the Nittany Lions’ primary second baseman last season and she produced a solid offensive campaign. The Itasca, Illinois, native started 49 of her 51 appearances and slashed .284, with 33 hits, eight home runs and 36 RBIs in 116 at bats.

Penn State also bolstered its infield depth and brought in graduate transfer Cara Bohner. The Towson transfer is a dependable bat, holding an impressive .292 career average with 128 hits. The Danville, Pennsylvania, native can also flash the glove, with a career fielding average of .947.

The lefty batter primarily played the middle infield positions defensively over her three seasons with Towson, but she can also be stretched across the infield and outfield.

After catcher Audree Mendoza transferred, the blue and white now have a battle for the starting position behind the plate between Kirsten Finarelli, Madison Seidel and Macy Chamberlin.

Finarelli was the lone 2025 recruit for her position in Happy Valley. The Lehman, Pennsylvania, native was a nationally ranked catcher prospect as the No. 41 ranked player in her signing class and No. 21 among catchers. As a three-sport athlete in high school, Finarelli is versatile and can also play across the infield.

The freshman was named the Pennsylvania 3A Player of the Year for her 2024 campaign and earned a Wyoming Valley Conference All-Conference selection in every season of her high school career.

While Finarelli will be a key piece of Penn State throughout her career, the starting position battle is mostly between Chamberlin and Seidel.

After missing the second half of last season due to injury, sophomore Chamberlin is set for her return to action. The Wauseon, Ohio, native started 20 of her 26 appearances in the 2025 season, slashing .321 with 17 hits in 53 at bats. She committed zero errors, but caught just two base runners last season.

However, the starting nod will most likely go to the veteran Seidel. The senior started 33 of her 43 appearances last season for Penn State, after not seeing much of the field during her freshman and sophomore campaigns.

The Hilltown, Pennsylvania, native slashed a .247 average with 23 hits and 15 RBIs in 93 at bats in 2025. While Seidel has committed zero errors throughout her career, she also caught just two runners while allowing 32 stolen bases last season.

The highest-ranked recruit in the 2025 class for the Nittany Lions was Allison Oneacre. The Alpharetta, Georgia, native was the No.19 ranked national recruit, via Extra Inning Softball and the fifth-ranked infielder in the class.

During her career at Milton High School, Oneacre was a four-time First Team All-Region choice from 2021 to 2024, along with All-State honors in 2023 and 2024. Oneacre is expected to be a big bat in Crowell’s lineup as she batted .598 with 101 hits and 84 RBIs over 55 games played at Milton High School.

Freshman Kalli Karwowski will also be a new infielder bat for the blue and white. The Peckville, Pennsylvania, native has championship experience as she led Valley View High School to the 2024 District 4A Title and 2025 PIAA State Championship. She earned NFCA All-Region status after the 2024 campaign and garnered All-Star and All-State accolades in each of the last four seasons.

With plenty of new infielders and some returners, there’s no shortage of bats for Penn State’s upcoming season.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Column | Top Games to watch in Penn State softball’s 2026 season
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
In less than 400 hours, the Nittany Lions step back on the dirt to start off their highly anticipated 2026 season.

After Penn State had two back-to-back record-breaking seasons in program history, the Nittany Lions look to continue their progress even further this year.

Bringing back developed upperclassmen like junior Brooke Klosowicz, while bringing in fresh players to the roster. Junior McKenna Young, a transfer, brings experience and frontrunner for conference play.

The Nittany Lions have 53 games ahead of them, and these are the top games to watch.

Season opening in the Sunshine State

Going into the season, the blue and white face five different opponents in Clearwater, Florida, for the NFCA Classic. Starting their season off with a double header, facing Missouri, then Boston College.

Opening weekend in early February in Florida for the Nittany Lions is a major spotlight on how the rest of the season could play out. Facing teams from the Power Five conference.

The top two games to tune in for are definitely the season opener against Missouri. An SEC conference team that is used to high competitors and Penn State’s performance against the Tigers is an important game to view. The result of the game will be a major outlook of what the season will be.

BYU will be the next must watch. The notorious program for consistently reaching the postseason will test Penn State early, with the game on Feb. 7.

Tournaments in the early season

Penn State is set to play Notre Dame on Feb. 21 in Orlando for the SpaceU Classic. The last time the Nittany Lions faced the Fighting Irish was when they fell short 4-2 in 2025.

Continuing the tournament-filled weekends, the blue and white head to Knoxville for the Knoxville Invitational.

Facing off with home team Tennessee twice, this matchup will be a big one for the Nittany Lions, as the Lady Volunteers had an impressive season with pitcher Karyln Pickens as the leader who took Tennessee to the Women’s College World Series last season.

With the pitching staff like Tennessee's, the Nittany Lions must be more than prepared when they step up to bat.

Big Ten time

One of the most interesting collegiate games has been in the Big Ten conference, and no different for softball.

Starting their conference play in Eugene on March 13-15, the Ducks will make it a very interesting road series to watch as they are one of the major softball programs.

Penn State will continue on the road, as the team faces Rutgers on March 27-29.

The Nittany Lions must get comfortable with road series matchups as they are set to play a total of 13 games away from Happy Valley.

They’re set to play Pitt in a Keystone State rivalry in Pittsburgh. At this point of the season, it’s crucial to keep up good efforts as the season is still far from over in late March.

Closing the regular season with a home series against Nebraska is pivotal time. Amplifying the ability of postseason possibilities, as the Big Ten tournament is just three days after the regular season closes.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey begins tough Big Ten stretch with No. 5 Wisconsin
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten, being one of the most competitive leagues in college hockey, is nothing new, and with that often comes a grueling conference slate, no matter who’s on the schedule. No. 8 Penn State is set to begin a gauntlet of Big Ten contests, facing three of the top five teams in the next trio of series.

The Nittany Lions start by traveling to Madison, Wisconsin, to face the No. 5 Badgers, set for an 8 p.m. puck drop Friday and an 8:30 p.m. puck drop Saturday, both hosted at the Kohl Center.

Scouting Wisconsin

This is the first time the two teams have met since the blue and white swept the Badgers in the midst of its red-hot second half last season.

Wisconsin has been exceeding expectations this season. After finishing with a 7-16-1 conference record last year and debuting at No. 20 in the preseason poll, third-year head coach Mike Hastings has led the Badgers to a consistent top-five spot since late November.

Freshman goaltender Daniel Hauser anchors Wisconsin, posting a .913 save percentage and a 2.10 goals against average in his inaugural season.

The Badgers’ offense is led by forwards Gavin Morrissey and Quinn Finley.

Morrissey paces Wisconsin with a point per game, tallying three goals and 18 assists on the year. The sophomore arrives off a monster first collegiate season, including being named a Hobey Baker Memorial Award fan vote nominee, a top-3 finalist for Big Ten Freshman of the Year and earning a spot on the Big Ten All-Freshman Team.

Finley, drafted No. 78 overall by the New York Islanders in 2022, sits in second place with 19 points this season.

This won’t be the first time the junior has seen a handful of Nittany Lions this year, as he was a part of the inaugural U.S. Collegiate Selects team that competed in the Spengler Cup back in December, led by Guy Gadowsky.

McKenna’s return

Penn State star freshman Gavin McKenna ended the first half of the season with 18 points, and while his 14 assists led all first-years nationally, his performance fell short of what many expected the projected No. 1 overall NHL pick this year to do.

McKenna spent the holiday break earning a bronze medal with Team Canada in the World Junior Championships, where his four goals and ten assists were good for second in the tournament scoring.

Since his return to the blue and white’s lineup, the Whitehorse, Yukon native logged six points in four games, and most recently recorded his first multi-goal game, potting two in the 6-3 win over Notre Dame on Saturday.

The forward’s newfound momentum earned him the Big Ten Third Star of the Week this week, after pacing all players nationally with five points over the weekend.

Injuries loom

Penn State has been hit with the injury bug early in its second half.

In last weekend’s first contest with Notre Dame, the Nittany Lions were forced to skate only 11 forwards after multiple skaters went down with injuries in the series prior. After defenseman Mac Gadowsky exited early after a hard hit, the blue and white entered without an extra skater for Saturday’s rematch.

Charlie Cerrato has been the biggest hole in the blue and white’s roster, leading the team in points before his injury. Guy Gadowsky was hesitant to provide an update for this weekend’s series, labeling him as “doubtful”.

Mac Gadowsky, as well as forwards Shea Van Olm and Casey Aman, who were previously injured, are both still “day-to-day.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Off the record | Graduating Greta: Dating in college
author: Miss Behave I The Daily Collegian
description:
Editor’s Note: Off the record is a weekly column written by a third-year Collegian staffer writing under an alias. It aims to promote a space for honest conversations about love, sex and relationships. Those interested in sharing their experiences or submitting a topic are invited to do so through this anonymous form.

Dearest reader,

This just in, graduating Greta is finding it difficult to feel confident in the dating world as her graduation is quickly approaching.

With no clue where she'll be in six months, committing to “something real” feels nearly impossible. After all, why fall head over heels for someone when there may be a looming expiration date? The mere thought of long-distance with someone she hasn't known that long is enough to make her skin crawl.

“Help?” Well, Greta, you’ve come to the right person.

Here’s the truth no one tells you before graduation: no one knows where they’re going to be in six months. Not you. Not your friends. Not even the 6-foot-5 man in finance with blue eyes, who “already accepted a job offer.”

He’ll probably be crying in a Target parking lot by August, questioning capitalism and wondering why he ever chose to flirt with an Excel sheet instead of you.

Measuring where we’ll be in six months is almost impossible. So much of our lives change from one season to the next and adding in a romantic partner can turn a simple math problem into an algebraic equation.

But here’s the thing: not every relationship needs to survive your entire twenties to be worth starting. Not everyone is meant to be in your life forever. This goes for close friends as well (I had to learn that the hard way).

Some people are just meant to be in your life right now — your coffee date companion or your “want to come over and watch bad reality TV?” person. And that’s OK.

Sometimes dating isn’t about building something permanent, rather it’s about learning what you like, don’t like and how you want to be treated. It’s a reminder that you’re more than just your resume and future plans.

You're still allowed to flirt. You're still allowed to feel wanted. And you're certainly still allowed to have fun.

Truthfully, yes, things may end when May approaches and you walk across the graduation stage. But that doesn’t make them failures. It just makes them chapters, short chapters that still count toward the full story.

You’ll never regret pouring your love into someone when there are mutual feelings involved.

On that note, who decided love needed an expiration date anyway? It's not a carton of milk. The deadline exists only because you're the one placing it there.

If you meet the right person and choose to date with intention, you and your partner will figure out how to make it work, even if that includes a shared Google calendar and an alarming number of FaceTimes.

Love doesn’t end just because graduation is approaching. And neither does your ability to be happy in your romantic life.

So get out there and chase whatever, or whoever, you want. Live in the moment. Make connections and meet people. Develop feelings you absolutely didn’t plan on having, because at the end of the day, emotional chaos is still better than feeling nothing at all.

Those feelings: butterflies, nerves, excitement and even heartbreak are how we know we’re actually living.

Graduating Greta — I’m wishing you the best of luck this spring semester. Here’s hoping you finally receive your romantic desires. Considering my record, it's hard to imagine you could do worse.

Yours truly,

Miss Behave

MORE COLUMNS

title: ‘Connecting people through art’ | Sarasota sings for State College
author: Ashlyn Kafer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Starting off shaking the floors of their apartment with the vibrations from their music, the members of Sarasota went from playing small gatherings for friends to invigorating hundreds at local fraternity parties and bars in downtown State College.

Sarasota is a State College cover band featuring vocalist Adianna Von Wiegand, guitarist Mark Robertson, guitarist and vocalist Jackson Mopsick, bassist and vocalist Ben Swihart and drummer Jacob Cho.

The band got its feet on the ground in fall 2024, beginning with Roberston, Mopsick and Cho jamming out together in the living room of their shared apartment.

“I got invited to live in this house, and I asked Jacob to come live with me,” Robertson, a fourth-year studying finance and Spanish, said. “The house was called Sarasota, and it just so happened that Jackson was also living in the house. We hadn’t ever met Jackson until the day we moved in, and he happened to play guitar.”

Swihart joined shortly after, completing the foundation of the group. Sarasota took its final form after Von Wiegand partitioned the band for a vocalist spot at a performance at the end of the fall 2025 semester, transforming her musical theater prowess into rock and pop-centric melodies.

“Right at the end of last semester, I went to Sig Ep because I was taking my friend on a tour to see all the frats when she was visiting,” Von Wiegand, a second-year studying political science and philosophy, said. “There was a band playing ‘Charleston Girl’ and I was like, ‘Wow, they’re really good, I should totally go up there and make this about myself.’”

After playing with the band to test her skills, the members fell in love with her vocals and she was soon welcomed into Sarasota with open arms to begin the spring semester as a lead vocalist.

The band takes huge pride in audience enjoyment, tailoring its setlist to tracks that people might be listening to on their walks to class or can sing along to with ease.

Tom Petty, Oasis and Bruno Mars are only some of the artists Sarasota pulls from, hoping to ensure its sound can reach diverse audiences and keep listeners engaged throughout the entire performance.

“Everytime we play a show and play a song that everybody in the crowd is singing and having a great time to, it hits me in my soul,” Swihart, a third-year studying advertising/public relations, said. “I could cry seeing that — giving the people the opportunity to have fun and just let loose.”

With Robertson, Mopsick and Cho graduating this spring, the band also tries to ensure that its setlist reflects music the members enjoy producing, translating how they interact with each other during practice onto their audiences when performing live.

“Playing live is such a rush,” Cho, a fourth-year studying materials science and engineering, said. “We can practice playing the song, or practice twice a week, but when you play it on stage, it’s a completely different feeling. In addition to making a fun atmosphere for everyone, it’s really rewarding. All of us enjoying the songs is a super important aspect of it.”

Sarasota values a lively audience, hoping its energy on stage can power the energy in the crowd. Many of its audience members include close personal friends, roommates and family members, who are appreciated greatly for supporting each show despite constantly hearing a similar setlist.

These supporters can be found at the front row of each venue the band plays at, such as Doggie’s Pub, Cafe 210 West, university club formals or off-campus fraternity houses.

As the future of Sarasota remains uncertain, the band members want to spend this semester playing as much as they can. They hope to continue reviving the live music scene around State College.

“When I was a freshman, I didn’t really hear about a lot of live music happening, and I feel like there’s been a big boom of it in the last two years,” Swihart said. “I think if we had any part in that, then that’s really cool just to help that community.”

Each member of the band brings different experiences, from formal lessons to teaching themselves their favorite songs for enjoyment.

Compiling their individual expertise, passion and drive together, the members have strengthened their ability to learn new music and connect to a wide array of tastes or interests present at each gig.

“There’s something about live music that forces a community in the room,” Von Weigand said. “Everyone knows the same song and is singing along with the singer, and it really just brings people together in a different way.”

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: Penn State stays winless in conference play with road loss to Washington
author: Samuel Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
A Husky was barking in the cage, and it forced its way out. After containing Washington for 30 of the 40 minutes, the Huskies broke loose, only to flee from the Lady Lions’ grasp.

After providing an early scare, Penn State failed to close the game in the second half, falling 81-65. This now marks a 0-9 record in Big Ten play.

The site of Alaska Airlines Arena hosted another ranked matchup for the Lady Lions, who faced No. 25 Washington on the road. As the clock pushed past 9 p.m. on the East Coast, the ball tipped and more of the same mistakes followed.

It was a tale of two different teams. En route to its fifteenth win, the Huskies showcased an uncommon threat against Penn State.

Averaging 19.3 points per game and co-leading the team in scoring, Gracie Merkle towered over Washington’s Brynn McGauhy. At 6-foot-6, Merkle easily won the tip over the 6-foot-3 McGauhy; however, she subsequently lost the early duel.

Coach Tina Langley and the Huskies did their homework against coach Carolyn Kieger and the Lady Lions. The attack point shone bright as Washington attacked the post, drawing Merkle out of the lane.

Making her respect the shot, McGaughy's hot shooting sparked a major lead for Washington. Scoring in the double-figures in just the first quarter, Penn State was forced to make adjustments. Making McGaughy the focal point of their defensive effort, the Lady Lions mounted a comeback in the second quarter.

Merkle, who leads the nation in field goal percentage, was quiet in the first frame. Then, a sleeping beast awoke. Behind a string of stops on the defensive end, Penn State began to settle in on the other side of the floor.

Shaelyn Steele, Nyla McFadden, Tea Cleante and more of Penn State’s guards aided Kiyomi McMiller and Merkle in the comeback pursuit. Penn State endured a run that gave the team a short lead before pulling the team within one point at the end of the half.

It was uncharted territory for Penn State – to be within striking distance – and it responded with an aggressive attack in the second half. Some might say a little too aggressive, as McFadden picked up a flagrant one foul.

Nevertheless, the Lady Lions picked back up where they left off at McMiller, who canned a triple and kept close with the Huskies. In a rather foreseen circumstance, the back-and-forth contest began to dwindle as Washington accelerated on the offensive end.

It was a pair of Husky guards that widened the gap early. The Alaskan-native, Sayvia Sellers, led the charge as she tallied 24 points on the night. Exploding in the fourth quarter, Avery Howell got hot from beyond the arc. She finished her night with 13 points and 11 rebounds.

While McMiller sat in favor of the defense, neither McFadden, Cleante or Steele could contain Sellers and Howell. From a one-point deficit to a sizable lead, Washington had effectively broken free.

Penn State didn’t have enough gas in the tank to combat the Huskies’ push. While Washington ranked as one of the better defenses in the nation, Penn State’s guards provided a limited scoring boost to Merkle, who finished with a team-high 19 points.

Unable to close tight games has remained a central theme of the Lady Lions’ struggles.

Injury Report

For the third-straight game, Amiya Evans was out of the lineup. Washington listed Daniella McLean as “out for the season.”

After banging her head against the hoop late in the fourth quarter, Merkle left the game and didn’t return. Her status remains questionable.

Up Next

Penn State will continue with its West Coast road trip as it faces Oregon on Saturday at 5 p.m. Following that, the Lady Lions will head back to Happy Valley to face Minnesota to close out their January slate.

title: CommunENTI encourages innovation and creativity across all majors
author: Alli Satterfield | The Daily Collegian
description:
Clubs and representatives involved in Penn State’s entrepreneurship and innovation (ENTI) minor gathered at the Eric J. Barron Innovation Hub for the annual CommunENTI event on Wednesday evening to connect student organizations based in entrepreneurship and promote the minor to more students.

The ENTI minor helps students develop “innovative thinking, leadership skills and management and planning tools,” according to Penn State Undergraduate Education. It consists of 10 concentration areas or “clusters” that help students develop in different disciplines and areas of academic study, which also helps students learn across academic colleges.

These clusters provide opportunities for engagement in bio-tech, digital entrepreneurship and innovation, energy transition, entrepreneurship as advocacy, food and bioinnovation, hospitality management, new media, new ventures, product innovation and social entrepreneurship. But, they also provide opportunities for students to create their own startup businesses.

Some student business owners, like Hasan Demirgil, the owner of GRND, a protein-coffee company, spoke at the event.

Demirgil explained his process in creating his physical product, protein coffee, and the brand people will associate with it. He said he hopes to start placing his product among branch campuses and other storefronts outside of Penn State in the coming year.

Other students promoted their creations, like tea and utility apps, as well. These student startup speakers served as evidence of the ENTI program in action.

Linda Feltman praised the program's interdisciplinary nature and the ability it gives students to access resources they may not otherwise have. She said many students can have access to the Smeal College of Business they would not otherwise have through the new ventures program.

“A lot of Bellisario students that declare the ENTI minor will take the new venture’s cluster,” Feltman, a lecturer in Penn State’s Bellisario College of Communications, said. “What’s cool about it is that Smeal is very closed for their upper classes unless you are a Smeal student or unless you are an ENTI minor.”

She said the program makes Penn State students more attractive to job recruiters by giving them more experience in other disciplines, which not a lot of students have.

“You may be learning about hospitality, but you want to understand what advertising does,” Feltman said. “You’re earning that credit, but it also makes you very attractive to recruiters.”

Student organizations were also represented through the night’s events. The Society of Women Engineers, the Blue & White Society, Penn State Music Group, Happy Valley Comm, 46 Live, Penn State Media Commons, Nittany Entrepreneur Society, REACH and more were all present Wednesday night.

Amelia Severns, president of the Penn State Music Group (PSMG), was there representing her organization. Although she is not part of the ENTI program herself, Severns praised student entrepreneurs.

“We focus a lot on entrepreneurship with managing artists,” Severns, a second-year student in Penn State’s science MBA program, said. “We have a record label team and an educational team.”

She said the club she represents is also a way for students to be involved in entrepreneurship — especially if they are interested in the music industry — since Penn State doesn’t offer a specific academic program for that discipline.

“We learn about all of the divisions of the music industry, like management, marketing, A&R and production,” Severns said. “We love to have a point where we can intersect music and business here at Penn State.”

Many academic clusters were also represented at the event. The food and bioinnovation group offered information and opportunities for prospective students, including the 2026 Ag Springboard Competition.

Raymond Yan compared the Ag Springboard Competition to the TV show Shark Tank. He said there, students are able to promote their ideas to win cash prizes, and the only requirement is that one teammate is a member of the agriculture college.

“You can go in with any idea that’s related to food or agriculture,” Yan, a fifth-year studying agricultural and biorenewable systems management, said.

This is just one of the hands-on opportunities offered through the College of Agricultural Sciences. They also have a partnership with the United Nations called the Penn State World Food Forum Youth Lab, which gives students the opportunity to interact with their communities and fields professionally.

That’s ultimately what the ENTI minor and Wednesday’s program was all about.

Students also enjoyed business booths, like Happy Valley LaunchBox, which is powered by PNC Bank, that were there as tangible resources for students on the entrepreneurship path. Throughout the event, students milled about, enjoyed refreshments and networked with students, organization leaders and faculty.

“We have a pretty incredible culture at Penn State as far as entrepreneurship, and it’s one of the reasons students come here,” Feltman said.

title: 'You can't be chaotic on offense’ | Mike Rhoades wants Penn State guard Dominick Stewart to play slower
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Guard Dominick Stewart is said to play with a high motor, giving a relentless effort during practices and games.

Penn State tracks players’ heart rates in practice, and earlier this season, Mike Rhoades said Stewart is “always” at the top in workload as he “doesn't take off reps,” citing how hard he practices. Rhoades added that Stewart needed to calm down but still maintain that level of effort, and he revisited the topic at Tuesday’s press conference.

“You can't be chaotic on offense, especially when you're a shooter,” Rhoades said Tuesday. “It's hard. You really rush your stuff, and he's so into it. He's so intense. He wants it so bad. I love it. But there's also, as with experience and more game time, you got to learn to pick your spots. I like to say common chaos and offense and be disruptive on defense, and you just got to slow down.”

During Big Ten play, Stewart has knocked down 3-point shots at a 20% clip on 30 attempts. He’s had five conference matchups where he was held to less than five points.

However, Stewart has reached double figures the past two games, starting with a 16-point outing on 41.7% shooting against UCLA last week. This past Sunday against Maryland, Stewart scored 17 points on 7-of-12 shooting from the field and 3-of-6 from 3-point range.

“It was a nice thing, finally hit some shots,” Stewart said Tuesday. “But I feel like the shots really don't dictate the game. Like a shot, it takes one second to shoot it. That doesn't define the whole 40 minutes of the game. But yeah, as a scorer, I feel like I put that on myself to go out there and have a good shooting night. I feel that really helps us as a team.”

Stewart had all three of his 3-point makes come in the first 10 minutes of the second half versus the Terrapins, which is when Penn State cut the lead down to 10 points despite a 96-73 loss. He added four rebounds and four assists during the game as well.

The sophomore making three deep shots is the first time he’s knocked down multiple 3-pointers in a game since draining 3-of-5 against NC Central on Dec. 29. It was also Stewart’s first time making at least two 3-point shots against a power-conference team this season.

“Probably the most frustrating when you put in countless hours, and the results don't exactly come right away,” Stewart said. “That's the frustrating part. But as a shooter, you just got to keep shooting and keep trusting in the work, and eventually it'll come.”

Stewart is an active defender, but he’s totaled at least three fouls in each of the last five games, including fouling out against Illinois on Jan. 3. He’s tallied 11 steals this season in addition to numerous deflections.

The Ocean Springs, Mississippi, native is averaging 6.9 points, 2.4 rebounds, and 1.4 assists per game through 18 appearances, including 10 starts. He’s shooting 38.3% from the field, 34.2% from 3-point range and 69.2% at the free-throw line.

“The dude cares so much,” Rhoades said. “I'm going to fight with that dude, and we need him to make shots. We need him to make the right plays. We need him to make shots. And that was a bright side the other day, the way he played defense. I think he got rewarded by slowing down a little bit on offense and knocking some down. So we need that from him moving forward.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | Will Gracie Merkle be the greatest center in Penn State women’s basketball history?
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Standing at 6-foot-6, from Mount Washington, Kentucky, Gracie Merkle.

For Penn State fans in attendance at the Bryce Jordan Center or Rec Hall over the past two years, they’ve heard that as she’s started all but three games in her Lady Lion career.

During that time, Merkle transformed herself into one of the best centers in the Big Ten, if not the nation. This year in particular, she’s led the nation in field goal percentage, shooting at 74.9%.

With this accolade and many others in mind, the case has to be made: Can Merkle be the greatest center in Penn State history?

The Lady Lions haven’t historically been known for their centers. They also haven’t had one standing 6-foot-6.

When Merkle joined Penn State in 2024, she immediately played a huge role in the paint, scoring back-to-back 20-point games during her first week in Happy Valley, including a double-double with 13 rebounds in her debut.

That success carried over through the rest of her redshirt sophomore year and into this year as she’s on pace to be a top 20-career scorer in Penn State history, excluding her days at Bellarmine.

Outside of Merkle, only three other centers have surpassed that 1,490 projected point total, including Vicki Link, Andrea Garner and Kahadeejah Herbert — the No. 15, No. 13 and No. 7 scorers in school history.

However, Merkle has found success outside of just scoring points, that have built her case as the best center in Penn State history.

While the 6-foot-6 center is leading the nation by a big margin in field goal percentage, she already has the school record for single-season field goal percentage.

Last year, Merkle shot 67% from the court, going 187-for-279. This year, that number has increased significantly to 74.9%, putting a dominant lead over Abilene Christian’s Meredith Mayes, who is shooting 68.2%.

Based on just previous centers, Merkle also has a large advantage over former Lady Lions in shooting percentage. Former 6-foot-4 center Amanda Brown holds the No. 3 through No.5 spot in single season field goal percentage with 59.9% and has the career record with 58.9% — a record Merkle is on track to obliterate.

To complete the trifecta, Merkle has also been dominant in rebounding over the last two years.

Since joining Penn State, she’s accumulated nearly 400 rebounds and is on track to record 699 career rebounds with the Lady Lions, which would put her at somewhere around the No.15 spot in career rebounds, behind a long list of other centers.

However, the current record book includes Merkle’s year at Bellarmine in her career rebounds number, already listing her at 29th. With another 340 rebounds added to her total, Merkle would finish her career in third all-time with 1,039 boards.

Despite this high number, Merkle still trails Herbert with career rebounds, who recorded 1,103.

While Merkle likely won’t hold the statistical record in every category by the time her Lady Lions days are over, she’ll be far up and have a dominant record with the field goal percentage. In just three years with Penn State, I believe 6-foot-6 Merkle will be the greatest center in Lady Lion history.

title: Michigan man arrested Sunday morning at State College Airport after allegedly damaging property, injuring a police officer
author: Grace Levy | The Daily Collegian
description:
A Michigan man was arrested early Sunday morning at State College Regional Airport after allegedly damaging property and injuring a police officer.

Jeffrey Wayne Roeder, 46, of Ishpeming, Michigan, was charged with four felony counts of aggravated assault and three counts of criminal mischief, along with three misdemeanor counts of recklessly endangering another person, one count of resisting arrest and one count of terroristic threat.

Penn State University Police were dispatched to the airport around 2:15 a.m. on Sunday following reports of a suspicious person, according to the criminal complaint. When police arrived, they saw Roeder allegedly throwing items and damaging computer monitors and property.

When approached, Roeder showed a knife and said he would stab the officer, allegedly refusing to surrender, according to the affidavit.

The Centre County Tactical Response Team was activated and officers attempted to deescalate Roeder. According to the affidavit, He was described as displaying “unstable behaviors," allegedly making references to “ninjas” and claimed to be high on methamphetamine.

Roeder continued to cause damage to the airport and Enterprise and Hertz car rental buildings, using his knife to cut chairs and damage walls, according to the criminal complaint. He allegedly “brandished” the knife at the officer and would “swing the knife wildly.”

The criminal complaint said at 6:15 a.m., Roeder was engaged by members of the tactical response team, who used non-lethal force via a bean bag shot and taser.

Roeder allegedly continued to resist arrest, and did not let go of his knife, resulting in an officer getting a laceration on their hand, according to the complaint.

Roeder was taken into custody that day and as of Jan. 20, he has not been arraigned.

title: 3 Penn State men's hockey players named to initial Hobey Baker nominees
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Three members of the Penn State men’s hockey team appeared on the Hobey Baker award initial nominees list released Wednesday. Goaltender Josh Fleming and forwards Gavin McKenna and Matt DiMarsico represent the blue and white on the 87-player list.

Freshman classmates Josh Fleming and Gavin McKenna along with junior Matt DiMarisco were each named as part of 87 initial nominees for the 2026 Hobey Baker Memorial Award!! 🏒🥅🏆😤#WeAre #HockeyValleyRead ⬇️⬇️https://t.co/4ndUmDenVH— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 21, 2026

Fleming currently paces the nation with a .943 save percentage alongside a high-ranking 1.82 goals-against-average. The freshman is 6-0-0 at Pegula Ice Arena since joining the Nittany Lions and is the first Penn State goaltender to shut out the Minnesota Golden Gophers.

Penn State’s marquee CHL signing, McKenna, finds his way onto the list in the midst of a three-game point streak. McKenna has 24 points in 20 games, good for second in the Big Ten.

DiMarsico scored his third hat trick of the season against Notre Dame Sunday and is the reigning Big Ten first star of the week at the time of the announcement. He leads Penn State with 14 goals and 26 points on the season.

Members of the list will be eligible for fan-voting into the top-10 Finalists, which will be announced on March 18. Last year, current Nittany Lions Aiden Fink and Mac Gadowsky reached the Top-10 phase.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: How a mid-series Taco Bell order has become tradition for Penn State’s Gavin McKenna, Jackson Smith
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Two Doritos Locos Tacos, a quesadilla, a Crunchwrap Supreme, Nachofries, a Blue Raspberry Freeze and a Baja Blast.

That was Gavin McKenna and Jackson Smith’s Taco Bell order last Friday after No. 8 Penn State’s 4-1 victory over Notre Dame.

Ordering a postgame meal from the iconic taco chain has become a mini tradition for the freshmen duo, who entered the 2025-26 season with lofty expectations. And if you ask them, it was key to their combined six-point night in Penn State’s 6-3 win over the Fighting Irish the next night.

“Taco Bell on Friday nights,” McKenna said with a smile. “That’s me and Smitty’s new treat.”

Smith said the Crunchwrap Supreme, Nachofries and a Blue Raspberry Freeze he consumed last Friday powered his three-point night — the first of his collegiate career.

The speedy defenseman wouldn’t commit to making Taco Bell a Friday night tradition. He said it’s unlikely for road games, but when in State College for a home series, expect the freshman duo to devour their same order until it stops working.

“I mean, it worked last Friday,” Smith said. “(Friday) was the first time we did it. We come out the next night, we win and Gavin and I both have three points. It's a little outrageous for sure, but you gotta love it.”

Jarod Crespo said “outrageous” is the perfect word to describe his teammates’ Friday tradition. The Nittany Lions’ alternate captain said he would throw up if he ate Taco Bell before a game, and if he ordered fast food before a Saturday tilt, Chipotle is his choice.

The clip of McKenna and Smith’s Taco Bell order went viral because many hockey fans appreciated the reminder that while the Penn State freshmen are highly touted NHL prospects, they are also 18-year-old kids enjoying their college experience.

But it underscored a deeper connection between the two skaters — one formed amid a shared spotlight. With McKenna, the consensus No. 1 pick in the 2026 NHL Draft and Smith selected No. 15 by the Columbus Blue Jackets in the 2025 NHL Draft, lofty expectations followed the duo into college hockey.

But those expectations have only made them closer. And that connection has blossomed during the Nittany Lions’ five-game winning streak.

“It's been amazing playing together all year,” Smith said. “We’ve been getting better and better in the second half. We've both been really good offensively and defensively … I love playing with (McKenna). He's an amazing guy and an amazing player.”

Their head coach agrees. Guy Gadowsky has noticed the connection between his star freshmen, both on and off the ice.

And as a longtime State College resident — Gadowsky is in his 14th season as Penn State’s head coach — he’s glad McKenna and Smith are making the most of their short stint in this small college town.

“I did see (their Taco Bell order), but I don't know how to relate to it,” Gadowsky said. “It does look like both of them are really enjoying State College and Penn State, and that's important to us. We love seeing that. This is one of the premier college towns in the world, so I'm glad to see they're enjoying it.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: ‘That has really hurt us’ | Mike Rhoades addresses Penn State’s defensive struggles
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
To put it simply, Penn State’s defense is a main factor for its 0-7 start in Big Ten play.

Mike Rhoades said the Nittany Lions have played “pockets of good basketball but not enough to win in the Big Ten.” He cited the defense for those struggles after Maryland earned a 96-73 win over his squad last Sunday.

“The consistency of our defense has been an issue,” Rhoades said Tuesday. “We don't play consistently in half-court defense, just enough to get stops and continuous stops, and when we have, we haven't rebounded a high enough clip, getting clean rebounds and one-and-dones to create greater offense.”

Penn State lacks a shot blocker on the roster as the team is averaging 1.4 blocks per game. Guard Melih Tunca leads the team with five blocks on the year, with big men Ivan Jurić and Saša Ciani behind him at four blocks apiece.

As such, the Nittany Lions have typically used a doubling strategy when an opposing player reaches the interior. But the issue with doubling means that a different player becomes open, and for Penn State’s defense, that opposing player is usually beyond the arc with someone running to cover the open shot.

Rhoades said the Nittany Lions lose the “point of attack” on defense, which is allowing other teams to generate offense.

“What it's done is it's put us in rotation,” Rhoades said. “I don't care at any level of basketball; when you get in the rotation, you're behind, and that has really hurt us.”

During the Maryland game, the Terrapins shot 18-of-34 from 3-point range, good for 52.9%. Guard Diggy Coit exploded for 43 points behind 9-of-15 shooting from deep.

In Big Ten play, Penn State allows 41.7% of opposing 3-point shots to fall. Earlier this season, the Nittany Lions let up 44 points and 10-of-15 3-point shooting by guard Lamar Wilkerson during a 113-72 loss to Indiana on Dec. 9.

“I think it's a team effort,” wing Eli Rice said Tuesday of improving the perimeter defense. “I think sometimes we leave guys to kind of play one-on-one more than helping that guy. So I'll say it's a team effort, from point guard all the way down to the big man position on the floor. So no matter what position the opposing player is, I think it impacts everybody.”

Even if a shot is missed, Penn State hasn’t cleaned up defensive rebounds at a high level. The Nittany Lions average a -7.6 rebounding margin per game across Big Ten matchups.

Against Maryland, Penn State allowed 12 offensive rebounds for 16 second-chance points. The Nittany Lions also let up 11 offensive boards for 19 second-chance points during a 71-60 loss to UCLA last week, which Rhoades said was the reason for the result.

As Penn State’s season continues, the defense getting better remains arguably the most important area to watch as the team searches for its first Big Ten victory.

“We just have to improve with our defense,” Rhoades said. “We have to improve with our half-court defense, and some of it is just continuing to get more experience and helping some of these guys understand the tough spots we're getting ourselves in there and the why of it. And then, of course, when we do have a good possession, you got to finish it with a rebound, and we're just not doing enough of that this year.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's basketball announces White Out for Rec Hall game against Wisconsin
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
White Out conditions are on the horizon.

Penn State's upcoming game against Wisconsin inside Rec Hall will be a White Out, the team announced Tuesday.

⚪️‼️ WHITE OUT REC HALL ‼️⚪️#WeAre x @MIWindows1947 pic.twitter.com/ejXiGpxZZQ— Penn State Men’s Basketball (@PennStateMBB) January 20, 2026

Tipoff is set for 7 p.m. Thursday with gates for fans opening at 6 p.m. The game will be aired on Fox Sports 1.

The Nittany Lions have already played in a White Out game this season, which came during The Palestra matchup against Illinois on Jan. 3. The Fighting Illini defeated Penn State, 73-65.

Mike Rhoades' squad is making a return to Rec Hall for the third season in a row. Last year, the Nittany Lions endured an 83-64 loss to Ohio State, but during the 2023-24 campaign, they upset No. 12 Illinois, 90-89.

Penn State, which is 9-9 and 0-7 in Big Ten play, will look for its first conference win this season. The Badgers will come to Happy Valley with a 13-5 record overall, including a 5-2 record in Big Ten play.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Nittany Lions in the NBA | Players continue growth, Jones leads best team in G-League
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s basketball endured a tumultuous start to the year, yet its alums, who’ve moved on to bigger things, created a new narrative for the program.

Yanic Konan Niederhäuser, center, Los Angeles Clippers

The rookie year for former Penn State center Yanic Konan Niederhäuser has gone about as expected in the NBA, as he’s excelled but only in limited minutes.

On Jan. 14, the Fraschels, Switzerland, native tied his career high, matching his 16 point game logged at the end of 2025. Yet in his recent outing against the Washington Wizards, didn’t miss a shot as he outplayed former 2024 No. 2 overall pick Alex Sarr in the process.

The rookie played the next game against the Raptors, and scored five points, all from the charity stripe, but as starting big man Ivica Zubać returned to action after injury, Niderhäuser saw his minutes decrease.

In the Clippers' recent game, where they again faced the Wizards, Niederhäuser didn’t appear, as Los Angeles returned to full strength. Brook Lopez bumped him in the rotation, as the veteran shoots the lowest field goal percentage of his career.

With Lopez's scoring struggles, he and Zubać are also two of the least efficient pick-and-roll big men, and as the former Nittany Lion begins to blossom, it isn’t far-fetched to envision a larger role.

Jalen Pickett, guard, Denver Nuggets

Since Jalen Pickett earned his first start of the season, he’s posted solid outings for the Denver Nuggets and emerged as a solid piece. The Rochester, New York, native started in the last five outings for the Nuggets, and they’ve won four of those contests.

In three of those games, Pickett notched double-digit scoring, and in the only loss over that stretch, he potentially put up his best game since his 29-point outing on Jan 5.

In the latest game on Jan. 18 against the Chicago Bulls, the Nuggets lost 110-87, yet Pickett had the best plus-minus rating of any Denver starter, behind his 12 points, 7 assists and 5 rebounds.

After Pickett’s stretch of receiving more playing time, his averages increased to 6.2 points per game, 2.7 rebounds per game, 2.6 assists per game and 46.2% from the field, and he hasn’t missed a free throw all year.

Andrew Jones, coach, Toronto 905

The lone member of the list not in the NBA or a player, Andrew Jones III, posted the most impressive year of any Penn State alum.

The former Nittany Lions forward played in Happy Valley from 2007 to 2011, making 134 appearances during that tenure, though Jones later pivoted to a coaching role.

The Philadelphia native had stints as a staff member with the Oklahoma City Thunder, his hometown 76ers, the Detroit Pistons and the Toronto Raptors. In June 2024, he earned his first head coaching gig with Toronto’s G League affiliate, the 905 Raptors.

This season, Jones’ squad emerged as a buzzsaw in the G League, posting the best record at 10-2. His squad holds a 14.4-point differential at the start of the year; the next-highest team in the league posts only a 7.9 differential.

In the month of December, Jones earned honors as the top G-League Coach of the Month.

Jones created a solid squad performance, with many contributors, but his gem has been the development of rookie Chucky Hepburn, the 2025 ACC Defensive Player of the Year. Hepburn posts top-five per-game figures in assists and steals, as under Jones’ tutelage, he’s seen a breakout.

As a squad, the Raptors shoot the best field goal percentage in the G-League and rank in the top three in steals and three-point percentage, emerging as a real contender to win the championship.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Position preview | Penn State men’s lacrosse returns veteran defensive core, adds talent
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Nittany Lions lost many major contributors on the offensive side of the field at the conclusion of the 2025 season, when Cornell defeated Penn State in the NCAA National Semifinal at Gillette Stadium. However, the same can’t be said about the defensive squadron.

Former Nittany Lion — and current member of the Denver Outlaws of the PLL — Kevin Parnham was a considerable loss for the defense. Despite losing their previous captain, the Nittany Lions returned a veteran group of poles in attempts to make another run at the national title.

Defensemen

The two biggest returners to the down-low defensive lineup are Alex Ross and Will Costin.

Ross, a senior from Davidsonville, Maryland, recorded a career-high 31 ground balls through 17 games in 2025, also forcing 24 turnovers. While it isn’t common for defensemen to have offensive presence, Ross scored his first and only career goal against the Big Red on March 8, helping propel a 13-12 comeback victory.

Speaking of defenders who’ve produced points, Costin registered a goal and two assists last season. He tallied a goal in the first round of the NCAA Tournament, where the blue and white defeated Colgate, 13-11. His pair of assists were spread out; the first was notched in the season opener against the Raiders and Costin registered his second in the national semifinal.

Meanwhile, the Nittany Lions also return senior Max Grube, junior Dillon Torggler, redshirt sophomore Patrick Keenan and redshirt freshman Brad Piffath.

Keenan, a Springfield, Pennsylvania, native, appeared in 10 games last season and picked up three ground balls. Grube and Torggler added depth on the bench, each playing in two games. Piffath only appeared in a single game in 2025.

In the offseason, Penn State recruited a trio of four-star freshmen defenders.

Luke Marra, a 6-foot-1 long pole out of Ridgewood, New Jersey, was ranked the No. 73 prospect in the Class of 2025, according to Inside Lacrosse. Marra played club lacrosse for Building Blocks Lacrosse Elite Black, going 24-16 in 2024.

That same publication ranked teammate Paul Bruder, who stands at 5-foot-11, as the No. 94 prospect in the Class of 2025. He previously played for the Episcopal Academy and Team Ten for club.

Mark McNamara, a towering 6-foot-5 presence, joins the list of incoming defensive depth and hails from Darien, Connecticut.

Long-stick midfielders

The Nittany Lions retained their top two long-stick midfielders in senior Ryan O’Connor and sophomore Lucca DiBartolomeo, while adding three new additions to the youthful depth chart.

O’Connor has been a staple of Penn State’s lineup since his freshman campaign in 2023, primarily with his quick retrieval of faceoffs from the wing. In his first season as a Nittany Lion, he scored a goal and picked up 22 ground balls. Last year, he tallied two assists early in the season and scooped a career-high 35 ground balls in 17 games.

DiBartolomeo also appeared in all 17 games, registering 21 ground balls and forced seven turnovers.

Originally committed to Navy in 2022, four-star recruit Jake Anzelone flipped to Penn State in March. Despite finishing out his high school career with the Naval Academy Preparatory School in Rhode Island, Anzelone played three years with his hometown Seaford Senior High School in New York.

Billy Henderson is yet another four-star recruit by Inside Lacrosse. A Springfield, Pennsylvania, native, he committed to Penn State in Sept. 2023. Aharon Bloshuk is the lone three-star recruit from Bangor, Pennsylvania. Henderson and Bloshuk reunite as teammates after both played club lacrosse for Dukes Lacrosse Elite in 2023.
