title: Column | Things to remember on your therapy journey
author: Jadzia Santiago | The Daily Collegian
description:
So, you’re looking into therapy. Congratulations!

37% of students nationwide sought therapy or counseling in the past year, according to the 2024-2025 Healthy Minds Study. You’re not alone.

Maybe you were one of those students, and you want to explore your options. If you’re new here, maybe this was your New Year’s resolution, you’re finally getting off your parents’ insurance, or like me when I started searching, you’re tired.

Unfortunately, after you figure out all the financial nonsense and carve out some time, you’re … at square one. There are so many options, but Pennsylvania (in January, no less) isn’t exactly the mental health capital of the world, so selection can feel simultaneously limited and too broad.

Additionally, there are lots of things I’ve noticed my peers don’t know about the whole process, and as students, we don’t often have time to hunt for insight online. But never fear: your resident columnist who’s been through the wringer is back.

The first thing I’ve noticed is that, although it’s well-known that every therapist is different, therapy itself is still thought of and presented as monolithic and standardized, something that either works or doesn’t.

That’s not the case. There are different modalities and approaches to therapy, and each one might work for different conditions and preferences.

The modality you’ve probably encountered, or will, is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, or CBT. It’s quite common and for me, it was basically what you think of when you hear “talk therapy.”

CBT can be effective for coping with life events like grief and conditions like anxiety, phobias or Obsessive-compulsive disorder, just to name a few, and many people have great experiences.

However, I found it didn’t work for me, which leads to my main point here: if a certain modality or approach doesn’t work for you, you aren’t broken or a failure.

Various factors can make an approach not fit, and even an adaptable provider who can use many different strategies within a modality can’t make it work for you if it’s not right.

In my experience, I found myself leaving even therapists I liked because it just … wasn’t working. And during that time, I started to think therapy would never work for me.

Which, peace and love, sucked.

You deal with enough in these four years; you don’t need to feel doomed on top of that.

But! The human brain is a complex organ, and so is the therapy world.

So, not only are there different types of talk therapy, there’s also somatic therapy, which focuses on the body, music and art therapy and EMDR therapy, which focuses on eye movement to reprocess traumatic memories.

There are also subsets and variations to some modalities and approaches, and different therapists may use varying techniques to apply each one.

There’s no shame in bouncing around to find something you think might work for you.

Personally, my therapist uses Internal Family Systems, or IFS, which I’ll admit I’m still skeptical about.

Like, they asked me to close my eyes and take a deep breath once, and I all but gagged. But instead of getting offended, they asked me why, and I felt safe enough to tell them:

“Honestly, [that request] feels like what people have said to me before insisting essential oils and meditation could cure my eczema. Not implying anything about you, just …”

To my surprise (because I was so sure I’d accidentally insulted them), they said they understood why, based on my past, and were happy to send me scientific literature on IFS. And for the first time, I felt recognized as a whole person by a provider.

This leads me to my next point: you’re allowed to be (healthily!) skeptical. Therapy isn’t about blindly following someone else’s opinion on how you should live your life, and self-advocacy throughout the process isn’t tantamount to resisting treatment.

Honestly, I’d say you should be a little skeptical. I mean, in a February 2025 article, the New York Times reported receiving over 2,700 responses after asking readers if they’ve had any negative experiences with therapy.

Considering my own horror stories, I’m not surprised, but Jee-zus. Needless to say, you're allowed to ask questions throughout the entire process, especially as you figure out what’s right for you.

Not only can you ask about a therapist’s treatment methods, but you can (and should!) ask about anything that’s important to you and relevant to your treatment, like their approaches toward and professional comfort with identity, medication, clients with certain experiences or conditions and more.

There’s nothing wrong with wanting someone who gets you — and you’re not alone in that desire. According to a 2017 study conducted by BARNA, 9% of US adults who sought therapy stated that finding a therapist who was similar to them was the most important factor in their search.

But if after a session (or a few), you’re just not vibing? Well, a good provider wouldn’t pressure you to work with them if you’re not a good fit — or pressure you to do anything, for that matter.

And the people in your life shouldn’t either.

There’s a lot I could say about that, but your girl has a word count, so above all, I’d like to emphasize that you define your healing.

Just like therapy doesn’t look any one way, neither does growth, and you can’t hold yourself to anyone else’s standards.

So, sorry, but your parent who wants you to stop disagreeing with them, your friends who want you to be less of an introvert and your boss who wants you to enjoy working until 2 a.m. might all end up sorely disappointed after your intake session.

The most important question is this: Will you?

MORE COLUMNS

title: A champion’s standard | Kayla Treanor brings a winning pedigree to Penn State women’s lacrosse
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Players sat around the locker room in anticipation on Selection Sunday, waiting to hear their name called for the fourth straight year.

These moments defined coach Kayla Treanor’s four seasons at Syracuse, leading her team to a 59-24 record. After being named the next Penn State women’s lacrosse coach in May 2025, Treanor will have an opportunity to do the same in Happy Valley.

“That drive to be a national championship team will never change for her,” Julia Basciano, a midfielder under Treanor at Syracuse and now at Penn State, told The Daily Collegian. “That is always going to be the expectation and the standard for her.”

Treanor’s championship drive started long before her time coaching Penn State, Syracuse and Boston College. The Niskayuna, New York, native became a star with the Orange as a player, becoming one of the most decorated women’s lacrosse players of all time.

Under the player leadership of Treanor, Syracuse experienced four straight championship weekends, including a spot in the 2014 NCAA title game.

During that stretch, she became the program’s only four-time IWLCA All-American, a three-time Tewaaraton Award finalist and Syracuse’s all-time leading scorer.

“She’s just really inspiring from the player that she was in college throughout her whole entire career,” Basciano said. “She steps out onto the field every day to coach us and motivate us, and she’s very humble about her career. Little does she know that she is an inspiration to probably every single person on our team.”

Following her time at Syracuse, Treanor spent time with the U.S. women’s lacrosse team, quickly becoming the team’s all-time leader in points and goals. With Team USA, Treanor won gold at the 2017 and 2022 World Championships before retiring and picking up her coaching career at Harvard and Boston College. She ultimately returned to her alma mater in 2022.

“My coaching philosophy has changed so much,” Treanor said. “I’ve had really great experiences (at each school) and learned that all the players are so different, so it’s always coming in and trying to understand your players and your team and how they learn best.”

Despite only spending four years with Syracuse, Treanor capitalized on every season with tournament appearances in each of the four years and semifinal appearances in 2023 and 2024.

After falling in the second round of the 2025 NCAA Tournament, Penn State vice president of Intercollegiate Athletics Pat Kraft reached out to Treanor about filling the position left by former coach Missy Doherty. The pair already had a connection from their time at Boston College, and Kraft hoped to rekindle that relationship in Happy Valley.

“In full transparency, I never thought I was leaving Syracuse,” Treanor said. “It’s really just an opportunity that I absolutely could not pass up. This is such an incredible school, amazing administration and amazing team and players with rich history and success and tradition.”

While many teams experience roster turnover following coaching changes, the Nittany Lions held fairly steady, knowing they were getting a high-caliber coach.

“We always spoke about having a championship culture, but this year, you can actually feel it,” senior attacker Erika Ho told the Collegian. “Everyone has a different drive this year, and that’s kudos to Kayla and the rest of the staff for making and creating a winning culture.”

Part of that championship culture comes with Treanor’s coaching philosophy of empowering each individual player and building team passion.

“Everyone’s obsessed with Curt Cignetti right now because he’s an amazing coach and talks so much about one play at a time, and every play is the same and every game is the same,” Treanor said, referencing Indiana football’s national championship-winning head coach. “Nothing is too special or too big of a moment for their team, and I think it's similar to my philosophy.”

Treanor’s philosophy and championship pedigree have resonated not only with the returners at Penn State but also with transfers, including Basciano, who followed her to Happy Valley.

“Coach Treanor is just an amazing person as well as an amazing, amazing coach,” Basciano said. “There really is no other person that I would want to be coached by.”

Outside of Treanor’s coaching style and work on the field, her compassion and care for her athletes have been just another thing that motivated the team to play for her.

“You can tell her, and the entire staff just deeply cares about you, both as a person and a lacrosse player,” Ho said. “Being around the staff, I feel like I’m a better person, and I think I’ve learned so much in only a few short months being under them.”

While this kindness and compassion from Treanor and the entire coaching staff have made the team feel welcome, the same has been felt by Treanor as she’s gotten to know her Penn State team after a few months.

“To be honest, I think this is one of my favorite teams I've ever coached,” Treanor said. “I'm just looking forward to continuing to develop my relationships with players and just continue to get to know them, because they are really a special group.”

Included in those feelings toward the team is that championship-level pedigree she brings to Penn State.

Despite never winning the big game, Treanor has the expectations each and every year to be playing for a spot to win a national championship. If she is successful with the Nittany Lions, it will be their first title since 1989.

“What excites me the most is just how much they care,” Ho said. “It really means so much to me, just seeing how much work they put in, how much they genuinely care about each and every one of us and how much they care and want to be a winning program.”

While it has been nearly 40 years since Penn State’s spot in the history books, Treanor believes that Penn State can make it back and be one of the best programs in the country.

“It’s just a no-brainer,” Treanor said. “This is a place where we can win national championships and be one of the Blue Bloods of college lacrosse.”

title: Column | The Big Ten is currently the premier college football conference
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Red and white confetti rained down at Hard Rock Stadium after Indiana won the national championship against Miami.

One of the historically worst programs among power conferences and a team that Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Fernando Mendoza labeled as a “bunch of misfits” went 16-0 and brought a trophy back to Bloomington, Indiana. It made it the third straight seasons a team from the Big Ten won the national title.

Long gone are the days where the Big Ten played second fiddle to the SEC. Right now, it’s emerged as the premier conference in college football.

Before Indiana, it was Ohio State and Michigan that won the previous two titles. In the four years prior, the SEC won the last four championships with two from Georgia, one from Alabama and one from LSU.

From 2020-22, the SEC went 22-15 in bowl games while the Big Ten went 15-13, showing that across the board the SEC not only won the national title, but reached bowl eligibility at a higher rate.

From 2023-24, the Big Ten was 17-10 while the SEC posted a 13-11 tally in the postseason.This season, the Big Ten went 11-5 in bowl games while SEC went 4-10. When the two conferences competed against each other, the Big Ten boasted a 3-1 record.

The SEC had five teams reach the College Football Playoff, while the Big Ten had three. The Big Ten had two teams with first-round byes in Indiana and Ohio State — the SEC had one in Georgia.

The success from the Big Ten is notable because of the differences in regular-season scheduling — the Big Ten played nine conference games while the SEC only played eight.

Indiana and Oregon became the final Big Ten teams remaining, with the Hoosiers beating the Ducks to punch their ticket to the title game. For the SEC, Ole Miss reached the College Football Playoff semifinal as well, but lost to the Hurricanes.

The SEC views playing each other as superior competition, which should benefit their strength of schedule, but in turn this isn’t a reality, as its teams schedule nonconference opponents to essentially set up four free wins.

The one extra conference win in the Big Ten provides a tougher task than most of the nonconference schedules SEC teams have, and can be the difference-maker in SEC teams making it into the postseason with one less loss.

The aforementioned triumphs are part of the fact that college football’s landscape has clearly changed. There’s a significant amount of money that is being allocated across all conferences with NIL, and the transfer portal gives schools an opportunity to revamp their programs.

Still, Curt Cignetti shut down any idea of that helping the Hoosiers win the national title, saying postgame, “our NIL is nowhere near where people think it is, so you can throw that out.” But, he also hinted not so subtly that times are changing as far as who is the cream of the crop in the sport.

“College football has changed quite a bit, the balance of power also,” Cignetti said.

That comment also applies to Indiana as a whole, as the expectation is the Hoosiers’ run won’t be one of a storybook season. Instead, it’ll be the start of continuous runs to the postseason and label as a year in, year out national title contender.

After all, the program went from the most all-time losses for power conference programs to winning a national championship in two seasons under Cignetti.

The mantra from the SEC is “it just means more.” It means that the play in the conference is above any other league in the country.

That phrase held true for a while. Now, it no longer means more. The SEC had its time on the throne, but there’s been a change of power in college football.

The Big Ten.

title: Column | Giving out Penn State 2025 team awards
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s 2025 season left much to be desired considering the preseason expectations set for the Nittany Lions, but they did end the season on a four-game winning streak with a Pinstripe Bowl victory.

Along the way, some players struggled to meet their ceiling, while others blew past their projections en route to a 7-6 finish with Drew Allar suffering a season-ending injury and James Franklin being fired six games into the season.

Here’s who I’d hand out team awards to.

MVP and Offensive Player of the Year: Kaytron Allen, running back

Kaytron Allen was Penn State’s engine on offense this season, earning All-Big Ten first-team honors after a year that saw him break the Nittany Lions’ program record for career rushing yards.

Allen tallied 1,303 rushing yards in 12 games while averaging 6.2 yards per carry. He put up 195 more yards in 2025 compared to his 2024 year despite having 10 less carries and four less games to play in.

The senior began the season in a smaller role behind Nick Singleton despite outproducing his counterpart, but once interim head coach Terry Smith took over, Allen saw a spike in carries and continued his elite year.

Allen finished the year with three straight games of over 160 rushing yards, including a career-high 226 yards against Rutgers in the final regular season contest.

Defensive Player of the Year: Amare Campbell, linebacker

Penn State’s defense struggled mightily at different points of the year this season, but linebacker Amare Campbell consistently stood out as his position group struggled without Tony Rojas.

Campbell led the team with 103 tackles and 9.5 tackles for loss in his first and only year with the Nittany Lions. He started every game at the MIKE linebacker position for Penn State after transferring in from UNC, providing desperately needed help with thin depth in the room.

The Virginia native has since transferred to Tennessee, but Campbell was a major part of any success Penn State’s defense had in 2025.

Freshman of the Year: Daryus Dixson, cornerback

There was plenty of freshman firepower on Penn State this season, but cornerback Daryus Dixson stood out among the pack.

Dixson appeared in every game this year, recording 24 tackles, six pass breakups, two tackles for loss, one sack and one forced fumble.

The freshman was one of just two players at the beginning of the year to earn a green light to burn his redshirt, and he started two games in 2025, including the Pinstripe Bowl win.

Most Improved Player: Andrew Rappleyea, tight end

A season-ending injury in 2024 derailed any chance for Andrew Rappleyea to have a breakout year, but he came back this year as the No. 3 tight end behind Khalil Dinkins and Luke Reynolds.

Rappleyea wound up making a name for himself and proved to be a must-retain player after a hot end to the year. The tight end had a touchdown in each of Penn State’s last three games and finished with 180 yards across the season.

Assistant of the Year: Anthony Poindexter, safeties coach

Penn State’s coaching staff left much to be desired this season, but Anthony Poindexter led safety Zakee Wheatley to the best year of his career and helped King Mack turn in a solid 2025.

Poindexter also called plays in the Pinstripe Bowl for the Nittany Lions, and the defense performed exceptionally well, allowing just 10 points to Clemson.

The Virginia alumnus won’t be with Penn State next season as he embarks to Tennessee, but he finished his career in the blue and white with a great coaching campaign.

MORE FOOTBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s basketball returns to Rec Hall for third straight year, hosting Wisconsin
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Per a new tradition, Penn State will return to its last venue before the Bryce Jordan Center, Rec Hall, to face the Wisconsin Badgers.

The Badgers arrive off a dominant 13-5 record, while the Nittany Lions sit at an even 9-9.

Beyond those records, the tale of the tape begins to tell a very different narrative between the squads.

Rec Hall rebounding

This occasion marks the third consecutive year the Nittany Lions have hosted the promotion, with an even record in both games.

Home turf remains a fortress for Penn State this season, as it holds the third-highest home rating in the Big Ten.

Last season, it received an 83-64 thumping at the hands of rival Ohio State, and most of the stat figures went the Buckeyes’ way, especially rebounding, where they held a 41-23 advantage.

Although in the inaugural “Return to the Rec” in 2024, results went differently, Penn State upset No. 12 Illinois in a 90-89 nail-biter, yet the trend of opposition domination on the glass continued, as the Fighting Illini posted a 49-25 rebounding advantage.

Rec Hall rebounding looks to go to a foe for a third straight season, as Wisconsin tied for eighth in the conference, while the Nittany Lions sit dead last in the Big Ten in rebounding per game.

Badgers’ 7-footer Nolan Winter leads the approach on the glass with 8.7 rebounds per game, a top-five figure, while his defensive rebounding stands only second in the Big Ten to standout Washington forward Hannes Steinbach.

Wondrous Wisconsin

The Badgers arrive in Happy Valley with possibly their best streak of basketball played this season, as they ride a four game win streak. Over the last ten outings, Wisconsin holds a 7-3 record, with two losses to the top two Big Ten teams, Nebraska and Purdue, and an overtime defeat to Villanova.

Form favors the Badgers, and the results came against both top and bottom-level performers, indicating that Wisconsin isn’t one to play down to opponents. Wisconsin’s best result came three games ago on Jan. 10 when it upset No. 2 Michigan 91-88 to give the Wolverines their first loss of the year.

The Badgers shot under 40% only three times this year, and recently those offensive woes haven’t persisted: they shot over 40% from beyond the arc in their last three games. The defense for Wisconsin remained solid over this stretch, although it can be susceptible to allowing opponents to break expected scoring averages.

Scoring stars

Wisconsin enters Rec Hall with the fourth-highest scoring total offense in the Big Ten, but also has the fourth-most points allowed.

Leading the Badgers' offensive effort is a pair of top-ten conference scorers, Nick Boyd and John Blackwell, who are comfortable scoring both inside and beyond the arc.

Blackwell is prone to hit or miss outings, as he has the lowest field goal percentage out of all top-15 conference scorers. However, the Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, native logged a tied Big Ten second-best single-game scoring mark this season, with his 31 points against Campbell in November.

Penn State also faced Campbell, and while it couldn't match the dominant fashion of Wisconsin's 96-64 win, it also saw a single-game stardom from its own guard, as Kayden Mingo scored 21 points in an 87-76 win.

The Nittany Lions return to Rec Hall with full offensive strength, as both players listed as questionable before the last game, Mingo and Freddie Dilione V, who lead Penn State in scoring, both appeared in its last contest. Dilione may see load management, however, as an ankle injury suffered against UCLA continues to nag him.

Against the Camels, three Penn State players joined Mingo in scoring more than 15 points, while only Boyd and Winter joined Blackwell in the Badgers meeting against Campbell in reaching such a feat.

Tempo in this one should be a big factor, as both Penn State and Wisconsin rank inside the top half in the Big Ten for Evan Miyakawa’s tempo rating.

Don’t expect great defensive teams either, as the Badgers rank the sixth worst in the conference, while the blue and white sit at the bottom, with the only negative team defensive rating in the Big Ten.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State notebook | Cael Sanderson talks Rocco Welsh, program's success
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following a dominating performance against Iowa and Northwestern last weekend, Penn State faces Indiana and Maryland in their final two-dual weekend of the season.

Prior to the upcoming matchups, Cael Sanderson met with the media to discuss how the Penn State wrestling program has seemingly lapped the competition while approaching an 80-match winning streak.

Here’s what he had to say.

No closing the gap

After dropping nine out of their last 10 matches to Penn State, Hawkeyes’ coach Tom Brands commented on how they’ve never been beaten like that. The loss was a metaphor for how Penn State has separated from the pack of elite wrestling programs. Sanderson offered insight for why he believes the program has sustained such dominance.

In a changing landscape of wrestling, featuring NIL and high schoolers reclassifying to join the college ranks early, Sanderson focuses on recruits joining Penn State “for the right reasons,” rather than just searching for a paycheck.

“Our kids know that they are coming here to become the best wrestler they can possibly be,” Sanderson said. “Kids are coming here, with very high character, wanting to be the best wrestlers in the world.”

Sanderson drove home the sentiment, saying that top recruits and their families know Penn State will drive its team to be the best both on and off the mat. He wants that to be the factor that drives commitments, rather than other motivations.

“We do our best to follow the rules,” Sanderson said. “So although (the NIL era) seems like an advantage for others, I think it’ll be an advantage for us.”

Team chemistry

One benefit of recruiting the high-quality characters Sanderson spoke about is developing a locker room culture that he described as “incredible.” He credits the roster as well as the long-term chemistry developed by the program over the last decade plus. Sanderson further credits the families of the wrestlers for raising them into men that make the team as bonded as they are.

“Just a lot of good kids that could have named their price at another but are here because of what the program stands for,” Sanderson said.

During the Iowa dual, the Nittany Lions’ bench was shown throughout the match supporting their teammates inside a volatile Carver-Hawkeye Arena. Sanderson acknowledged his team’s “bigger than yourself” mentality and genuine support for each other. Sanderson concluded by saying that coaching “wouldn’t be fun” without a team like Penn State.

New starters

Marcus Blaze, PJ Duke and Cole Mirasola all picked up marquee victories over the weekend. Forgoing the usual talk after performances like theirs, Sanderson focused on each wrestler’s character rather than technical ability.

Sanderson credited the trio as being able to be themselves when they wrestle and being elite competitors. All three wrestled opponents they can expect to see late in the NCAA tournament, on the biggest stage they’ve wrestled on in their collegiate career and maintained composure.

“The bigger the moment, the better they’re going to wrestle,” Sanderson said. “That’s what they’ve done their whole lives and what we do as a program.”

For Mirasola, Sanderson dove in on his toughness and training. After Josh Barr described Mirasola as “nasty” during a press conference, Sanderson clarified that Mirasola can bring out an animalistic side when the whistle blows, while remaining a good person and wrestling within the rules. Sanderson said it boils down to Mirasola having to fight for everything he’s earned to this point.

“There’s never been a great athlete that didn’t have to fight for things,” Sanderson said.

He also dove deep on Mirasola’s training, crediting Lucas Cochran for his relationship with his weight-class partner, as well as former Nittany Lion Greg Kerkvliet and “the heavyweight tamer” in assistant coach Casey Cunningham for their roles in developing the redshirt freshman.

Despite the praise, Sanderson doesn’t expect his wrestlers to get complacent, especially after just a dual victory. His focus is keeping the roster focused on the future, improvement and larger accolades later in the season.

“I don’t think anyone’s patting themselves on the back or anything,” Sanderson said. “As much as seeing what we can do better.”

Rocco Welsh

After his tiebreaker victory over the former No. 1 Angelo Ferrari, Rocco Welsh staked his claim at the top of a loaded 184-pound weight class. Sanderson spoke about his time recruiting Welsh out of Pennsylvania prior to college and seeing his potential. The coach specifically acknowledged his ability to listen, his preparation and his toughness.

However, Sanderson didn’t speak too deeply into the victory itself, focusing on the next steps as he always does when asked about Welsh’s No. 1 status.

“You can’t win Nationals in January,” Sanderson said.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Former Penn State DL Enai White transfers to Oklahoma State
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
After one year with Penn State, Enai White is heading to a new school.

The ex-Nittany Lion defensive tackle has transferred to Oklahoma State with one year of eligibility remaining, he announced on Instagram on Tuesday.

White transferred to Penn State at the conclusion of the 2024-25 season after three years at Texas A&M. In his lone season in State College, he appeared in eight games, notching three tackles and a sack.

The former 4-star from in-state Imhotep Charter and top-50 player nationally has appeared in 21 games during his time playing collegiate ball, tallying 14 total tackles and three sacks.

The Philadelphia native transitioned from defensive end to defensive tackle during his time with the Nittany Lions, but lined up at his original position during the Pinstripe Bowl.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: No.4 Penn State women's hockey thumps Cornell despite missing key piece for international duties
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
After remaining at No. 4 in the USCHO poll for another week, the Nittany Lions concluded their seven-game road trip against the twelfth-ranked Cornell Big Red as they finished their home-and-home series of the 2025-26 season.

The blue-and-white did so without its lone goalscorer from their game against Cornell just before the end of the 2025 calendar year, Matilde Fantin. Fantin was recently named to Italy’s Women’s Hockey team for the 2026 Winter Olympics, joining fellow Olympians Tessa Janecke (United States) and Nicole Hall (Sweden).

However, what Penn State lost in Fantin, it gained in goaltender Katie DeSa, who made her first start since Jan. 2 when she left after the second period with an injury in Penn State’s 5-1 loss to Ohio State. DeSa shutout the Big Red in December’s contest, the 20th of her career, tying her with Josie Bothun (‘24) for the most in program history.

DeSa performed to her standard, leading the Nittany Lions to a 5-1 win in a mid-week matchup in the final non-conference game of the season.

The senior netminder extended her shutout streak against Cornell to four periods after blanking them in the opening frame, stopping all eight shots she faced. She passed the first test she faced with ease, turning away multiple one-timers on a Cornell power play after the officials assessed Leah Stecker for a minor cross-checking penalty.

Penn State struck first with a goal off the stick of Janecke, her 17th of the season. Katelyn Roberts battled Cornell’s Nora Curtis for the puck along the boards, ultimately forcing a turnover in Penn State’s offensive zone. Janecke was able to pick up the loose puck and score on a shot from the faceoff dot to the right of the Big Red goaltender Annelies Bergmann.

The Nittany Lions captain extended her point streak to six games with goals in each of the last four. Janecke extended her AHA goal-scoring lead and entered a tie for the sixth most in the nation with three other skaters.

Cornell was able to regroup during the first intermission and didn’t waste any time in the second period, evening things at 1-1 just shy of 90 seconds into the period. The Big Red’s Shannon Pearson picked up the puck in the neutral zone and entered her offensive zone in a 2-on-2 situation and beat DeSa under the blocker from the slot for her third goal of the season.

Just moments later, the carnelian-and-white took advantage of another Nittany Lion defensive collapse when Avi Adam entered the zone on a breakaway. Yet a diving attempt from Abby Stonehouse forced Adam to quickly recover and shoot, missing wide of the net.

After a series of multiple icing calls against the blue-and-white, Janecke circled back into her own zone and led a rush the other way and dumped the puck into the Cornell zone. Taya MacDonald was able to stop a clearing attempt from leaving the zone and found Maddy Christian coming up the boards, who received the pass, turned and ripped a shot that was deflected in front by Grace Outwater to give Penn State its second lead of the game, 2-1.

Outwater has now scored in three straight games and totaled 16 on the season, matching her career-high from last season in 15 fewer games. Her 27 points on the season set a new career-high for the sophomore winger.

With just over six minutes remaining in the second period, Cornell nearly knotted the score again, but a pass sent too wide left the Big Red looking for another opportunity.

They wouldn’t see it in the second period as the blue-and-white continued to keep its foot on the gas with Christian leading the way, but came up short after being denied by Bergmann on two scoring opportunities.

After struggling to exit their own zone in the second, the third-period Nittany Lions continued to build momentum and controlled the puck well, maintaining possession in the Cornell zone. Roberts chipped the puck up to Janecke, who dished a cross-ice pass to a wide-open Stonehouse, who tapped in her sixth goal of the season with ease.

Penn State continued its dominance in the first half of the final period, outshooting Cornell 6-1 with its lone shot-on-goal coming on the second unsuccessful man-advantage of the night.

Continuing to challenge Bergmann from the middle of the slot between the two faceoff circles, Sophie Morrow extended the Nittany Lions’ lead to three with her third goal of the season. With an assist from Kendall Butze, the Penn State defense remains one of the best in the country, breaking a tie for second in defensive scoring.

After being denied multiple times at the end of the second period, Christian netted her 14th goal of the season with no challenge on an empty-net goal.

With this win, Penn State finishes its non-conference play with a record of 7-3. Overall, Penn State improved its record to 22-4, giving the Nittany Lions the most wins in the nation.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions will return home to Pegula Ice Arena, where they will host the Delaware Blue Hens for a weekend series beginning on Friday at 6 p.m.

MORE WOMEN'S HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Guy Gadowsky talks Cerrato injury, goalie tandem
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 8 Penn State is 16-6 and winners of five straight games behind stout goaltending from Josh Fleming and multi-point nights from Gavin McKenna and Jackson Smith.

Following the Nittany Lions’ series sweep of Notre Dame, coach Guy Gadowsky spoke with the media on Tuesday about injuries, his goaltending plans and his team’s upcoming series against No. 5 Wisconsin.

Injury updates

Penn State ranks second in the Big Ten standings after sweeping Minnesota and Notre Dame. But its recent success came at a cost.

Charlie Cerrato and Braeden Ford exited with injuries against the Golden Gophers and didn’t play against Notre Dame. Gadowsky said last week that Ford will miss “a significant amount of time” and labeled Cerrato as “day-to-day.”

Gadowsky was hesitant to provide an update on Cerrato, the team’s co-assist leader, before he labeled him “doubtful” for this weekend’s series against the Badgers.

“I’m not 100% confident in giving you an update, but (Cerrato is) doubtful for this weekend,” Gadowsky said.

The Nittany Lions had so many injuries at forward entering last weekend’s series that they didn’t list a fourth-line right winger for Game 1 and omitted an extra skater from their lineup sheet in Game 2.

Mac Gadowsky, who exited Friday’s victory after taking a hard hit along the boards and missed Saturday’s contest, Shea Van Olm and Casey Aman are “day-to-day.”

Goaltending plans

Penn State has used a goaltending tandem between Fleming and Kevin Reidler in 10 of its 11 series this season. And through 22 games, both rank inside the top six in goals-against average and save percentage among Big Ten goalies — a key reason Gadowsky’s waited to name a true starter.

“I believe we're going to continue (both goaltenders) because it seems to be working very well,” Gadowsky said. What we like most is that the goaltending trio supports each other. They're a great example of what teamwork is.”

But Fleming has separated from his counterpart since the start of Big Ten play.

In 10 starts, the freshman netminder sports a 1.82 goals-against average, which far outpaces Reidler’s 2.92, and a conference-best 94.3 save percentage. He has stopped 86 of the 88 shots he’s faced in his three starts since the international break.

Despite Fleming’s impressive production, Gadowsky declined Tuesday to name him the starter, instead praising the success of the tandem.

“We have a good thing going on right now, and I don't know what's going to happen in the future, but right now, (the goaltending tandem) is one thing that's really going well. I don't know why we try to fix something that's not broken.”

Blocking the noise

The outside noise has been loud surrounding McKenna, the consensus No. 1 pick in the 2026 NHL Entry Draft. That wasn’t a surprise.

But the way he’s handled that pressure earned praise from his head coach.

“One of the things that I admire most about (McKenna) is that he really doesn't listen to the noise, and he has a confidence about him, regardless of what some people say on some website,” Gadowsky said. “I admire his internal compass. He’s really been raised well by his family, by his community, to stay level-headed and worry about what he controls.”

McKenna tallied his first multi-goal game in Penn State’s 6-3 victory over Notre Dame last Saturday. His offensive output has ballooned since his return from international play, which left Gadowsky more impressed than surprised.

“You look at the World Junior Championships, (McKenna) was one point from the lead and just turned 18,” Gadowsky said. He’s doing incredibly well, and we see him getting better every day.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling remains No. 1 in updated NWCA rankings
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Another week, another win, another No. 1 ranking.

Penn State maintained its top ranking following dominant wins over No. 4 Iowa and Northwestern.

The Nittany Lions received 14-of-16 first-place votes in the rankings for the second straight week, with Ohio State receiving the other two top votes. Penn State and the Buckeyes will meet at 7 p.m. on Feb. 13 in the Bryce Jordan Center.

title: Penn State women’s basketball looks for signs of life against upcoming Washington, Oregon
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is on an eight-game losing streak.

With no answers over the past month, the Lady Lions will look for a miracle as they hit the West Coast for a pair of games against Washington and Oregon at 9 p.m. Wednesday and 5 p.m. Saturday.

Penn State enters off a disappointing four-point loss to Rutgers, which earned its first conference win of the season on Sunday. Now, the Lady Lions will hunt for their own, starting with the No. 25-ranked Huskies.

Washington

Washington experienced on-and-off success this year, winning games against Utah and then-No. 6 Michigan. However, it lost to struggling Purdue earlier in January.

Both Penn State and the Huskies have a strong trio that contributes to most of their team’s scoring. For Washington, it’s three guards, and for Penn State, two guards and a center.

Sayvia Sellers leads the Huskies from the court through 18 games, scoring 18.4 points per game.

For the first month, it was just Sellers and Avery Howell, who averaged 12.8 points per game. But for the past month-and-a-half, senior Elle Ladine entered the mix after coming back from an injury in November.

Together, the three have combined for 42.3 points per game and over three steals per game.

The Lady Lions, however, have 6-foot-6 Gracie Merkle, who has been the most efficient player in the country. Through 11 weeks, Merkle has averaged nearly 75% shooting from the court, scoring 19.3 points per game.

To go along with Merkle’s power in the paint has been shifty Kiyomi McMiller, who’s averaged 19.4 points per game.

Rounding out Penn State’s big three is redshirt junior Moriah Murray, who has the second-most made 3-pointers in the Big Ten this season, making 55 triples.

With a star-studded trio in both lineups, Wednesday’s matchup will likely come down to which team can get better opportunities from the bench.

Oregon

While Saturday’s matchup won’t be another top-25 matchup for the Lady Lions, it will be another contest against a premier Big Ten team who’s had big wins this season.

Sitting at 14-6, Oregon had its fair share of celebrations this year with wins against then-No. 21 USC, Oregon State and Auburn. However, it’s on its own losing streak with three straight losses to Michigan State, Iowa and Wisconsin.

While Penn State searches for its first win since December 20th — losing eight straight — the Ducks have more recent victories they can still garner momentum from.

Oregon’s defense will be the biggest struggle for the Lady Lions, recording 11.8 steals per game.

Despite scoring just 6.1 and 7.4 points per game, Oregon’s Ari Long and Sofia Bell have started all a majority of games this year, mainly due to their defensive toughness. The two currently rank in seventh and 15th in the conference in steals per game, combining for 73 total this season.

The Ducks’ offense, however, comes from another pair of Oregon stars in Katie Fiso and Mia Jacobs.

Fiso has shot 49.2% from the court en route to 15.7 points per game, while Jacobs is tied for sixth in the Big Ten in made 3-pointers with 44.

If the two Ducks continue to perform at the top of their games, and Oregon’s defense puts pressure on Penn State — a team that averages a conference-high 19.6 turnovers per game — Saturday’s contest could be another “L” in the books for the Lady Lions.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Mike Rhoades talks building a program, morale of team amid losing streak
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State remained winless in Big Ten play after a 96-73 loss to Maryland this weekend, and Mike Rhoades returned to the podium for his weekly press conference on Tuesday.

Rhoades spoke on what goes into building a program, the morale of his team amid its losing streak and more as the schedule continues with a home game against Wisconsin on Thursday.

Here’s what Rhoades had to say.

Building a program

Indiana won a national championship in football on Monday night after never having much success in the sport. Prior to the Hoosiers’ recent run, comparisons could’ve been made between Penn State men’s basketball and Indiana football as both weren’t known as consistent winning programs.

Rhoades said he’s watched the Hoosiers’ turnaround in football under head coach Curt Cignetti closely, saying he tried to learn their approach of bringing potential sustainable success to a program.

“I think their organization, their commitment, the decisions they've made to be able to go to bat in the big boy batter's box has paid a dividend for them and put them in the position that they're in,” Rhoades said. “So it's a lot of decisions, a lot of conversations you got to have, and then you got to go do it, and they did it, pretty impressive.”

Rhoades said recruiting and retention of high-level players is one aspect in particular he thinks can expedite building a program. Penn State has freshman guard Kayden Mingo, who is the highest-rated recruit in program history.

“We're recruiting high-level dudes. We got to get them. We got to retain them,” Rhoades said. “The ones we have in our program that want to be here and do it the right way. We got to retain them. This is hard, and when you're losing everyone has answers or questions and all that stuff, but they're not in the building with us every day as we're trying to do this the right way and build it the right way.”

The Nittany Lions are a finalist for 5-star 2026 guard Dylan Mingo, who ranks as the No. 5 player nationally by the 247Sports composite. Rhoades was asked if he thinks Penn State is currently in a position to land the highest levels of talent out of high school.

“Not yet, but I have belief that we will, and we're moving forward,” Rhoades said.

Morale of team

Penn State has lost its last five games and eight of its last nine matchups. The losing skid has included blowout losses and close contests that saw the Nittany Lions nearly pulling off upsets.

Rhoades said the players are still working to get their first win in the Big Ten slate and have been coachable.

“To give them the respect I have for them and the way they're handling,” Rhoades said. “I mean, guys are disappointed and upset, but we don't have issues off the court or things that are getting in the way of what we're trying to do.”

The Nittany Lions haven’t won since a 90-67 victory over NC Central on Dec. 29, and they haven’t beaten a power-conference opponent this year, as all nine of their wins came against. Quad 4 teams.

Still, Penn State’s roster, which has eight freshmen, is impressing Rhoades in still putting in effort despite the season being off to a rough start.

“We have some young guys that are in big positions that a lot's on them, but win or lose, whatever the scenario is, if you keep learning from it, it's going to make you better,” Rhoades said. “It's just hard. I mean, come on, it is where we are, but I've been proud of the guys for their response, especially with the morale.”

Puff Johnson playing for Ohio State

Former Penn State forward Puff Johnson, who has already played in five seasons of collegiate basketball, transferred to Ohio State in the fall and was given a temporary retraining order, making him immediately eligible to play.

Rhoades spoke on the possibility of Johnson playing for the Nittany Lions this year, but it didn’t work out.

“Puff and I spoke about that, and we knew we were going to have a scholarship,” Rhoades said. “So if he was eligible to come back, he had a scholarship. That changes with (revenue) share and NIL because we're not in a position where we can just lose money and all that stuff … We all moved on in a positive way without a doubt. He's a Penn State grad, and he gave us everything for two years. I really appreciate (him). He's a good kid.”

Rec Hall game

The Nittany Lions are set to host Wisconsin inside Rec Hall at 7 p.m. Thursday. It’ll be a change from the usual site of the Bryce Jordan Center, bringing back an old-school look.

“We all love a little throwback in us, right?” Rhoades said. “It's an old arena. It's an old gym. People are on top of you now with the new court and the way it's configured, even more on top of you. I just think it's cool. Penn Staters love something different. I think sometimes being different and doing something cool like that is fun, fun for everybody.”

Prior to the Bryce Jordan Center opening, Penn State used to host its home games in Rec Hall from 1929-96, holding a record of 514-183. Rec Hall has a listed capacity of 6,846, and with bleachers close to the court, the atmosphere sounds louder than the typical game at the Bryce Jordan Center.

Since Rhoades took over as the Nittany Lions’ coach in 2023-24, Penn State has hosted a “Return to Rec” promotion, which features one game inside Rec Hall per season. Notably, Penn State took down No. 12 Illinois on Feb. 21, 2024, by a score of 90-89 after game-winning free throws by forward Zach Hicks.

Fans stormed the court after the Nittany Lions’ upset over the Fighting Illini.

“This is entertainment, right? And it's supposed to be about having a cool experience,” Rhoades said. “Yeah, we want to win, and we want to do everything right, but we also want to make some decisions, so we're having a lot of fun trying to do this. I think playing in Rec Hall for a lot of people, old Penn Staters, new Penn Staters, basketball fans, it's a cool place to see a college basketball game, and it's cool for our players to be a part of that.”

Rhoades said it’s a possibility to play more than one game per season at Rec Hall, but noted the logistical needs of playing more games in the historic site.

“A lot of things come into play with moving a team or a program out of one building to another, and logistics and how much it impacts,” Rhoades said. “Then you have marketing and ticket sales and season ticket sales. I think there's a lot more to it than just say, ‘Hey, let's go play.’ Some of that is above my pay grade.”

title: Penn State sits at No. 7 in the preseason Inside Lacrosse Men's DI Media Poll

title: Luke Lilledahl, Rocco Welsh jump to No. 1 in new InterMat rankings
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Penn State's dominance has reached a new level.

After victories over No. 4 Iowa and Northwestern, the Nittany Lions have six wrestlers at No. 1 in the updated InterMat rankings.

The top-ranked wrestlers include Luke Lilledahl, Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines, Rocco Welsh and Josh Barr.

At 125 pounds, Lilledahl jumped to No. 1 following his victory over No. 6 Dean Peterson. Lilledahl rose after NC State's Vincent Robinson dropped a match last weekend.

At 141 pounds, Braeden Davis fell to No. 11 after losing to then-No. 11 Nasir Bailey of Iowa.

Welsh made the jump from No. 4 to No. 1 after winning a close, 2-1, battle over former No. 1 Angelo Ferrari.

At heavyweight, Cole Mirasola rose one spot to No. 12 after his victory over then-No. 5 Ben Kueter.

The freshmen duo of 133-pounder Marcus Blaze and PJ Duke at 157 remained at their previous rankings, slotting at No. 4 and No. 3, respectively.

Van Ness, Mesenbrink, Haines and Barr all kept their top spots after all winning against the Hawkeyes.

title: Film review | Transfer WR Keith Jones Jr. has upside at Penn State
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State landed a transfer portal commitment from Grambling State wide receiver Keith Jones Jr. as the team is building its roster for 2026.

Jones has intriguing upside after leading his squad with 32 catches for 450 yards and five touchdowns this past season. He just finished up his redshirt freshman campaign, leaving him up to three more years to develop as he makes the jump to the FBS.

Here’s a look into the skills Jones could bring with him to Penn State.

Jump-ball ability

Jones has the ability to win 50-50 reps, hauling in passes over opposing defensive backs down the field.

Against Prairie View A&M, Jones had a 16-yard reception with a cornerback in tight coverage with him. He high pointed the pass and secured the catch for a touchdown.

Jones possesses a jump-ball trait, bringing down 50-50 passes.Here’s him hauling in a jump ball for a touchdown:pic.twitter.com/5yn2TdS84Y— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 19, 2026

Jones is listed at 6-foot-4, 185 pounds, which gives him a frame that has outsized competition. He’ll face tougher defenses in the Big Ten, but he’s still flashed jump-ball traits while competing in the SWAC.

Another jump-ball catch for a touchdown by Jones here: pic.twitter.com/UDzTbDPrbk— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 19, 2026

He lined up for 213 snaps out wide in 2025, according to PFF. At Penn State, that could mean he’s sent on plenty of deep routes to give him opportunities to use his size.

Yards after catch

Jones has shown the ability to rack up yardage after the catch. Throughout the 2025 season, he picked up 177 yards after catch, which is 39.3% of his total receiving yards.

He took a screen pass during a game against Kentucky State, making defenders miss and breaking a few tackles before crossing the goal line for a 36-yard touchdown.

Jones can pick up yards after the catch like this screen pass he turned into a 36-yard scorepic.twitter.com/TuwKbl9Dff— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 19, 2026

Jones has the speed to break free, so giving him passes to get him in the open field could generate big plays for the Nittany Lions.

Intermediate route runner

Jones ran numerous routes to the intermediate zone of the field with Grambling State in 2025.

He caught a pass on a 3rd-and-10 situation on an in-cutting route during his squad’s game against Alcorn State, moving the chains to keep the drive going.

Jones runs a bunch of routes in the middle of the field, such as this catch to pick up a first downpic.twitter.com/lqQN0gyWSs— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 19, 2026

On targets over the middle of the field between 10-19 yards downfield, Jones hauled in 8-of-12 passes for 116 yards and a touchdown. He also had a 12-yard touchdown reception in the back of the endzone while cutting toward the sideline.

Jones also had this touchdown in the middle of the field pic.twitter.com/Wsah268GDE— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 19, 2026

Jones could become a consistent chain mover for the Nittany Lions, picking up chunk yardage like he did with Grambling State. He had 14 catches that gained at least 10 yards this past season.

Deep-threat potential

Jones flashed home-run-threat potential on some plays with receptions of 48 yards and 28 yards downfield in 2025.

He was only targeted on five passes of 20 or more yards downfield, but one of them was a touchdown against Southern that saw him cut across the field.

Jones was only targeted on deep passes five times, but he hauled in two throws of at least 20 yards.Here’s him scoring a 28-yard touchdown pic.twitter.com/kC08OV73zY— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 19, 2026

Jones could become a deep threat with the Nittany Lions, which would add another aspect to his game.
