title: Dueling Column | Should Penn State keep or move on from Carolyn Kieger?
author: Noah Aberegg & Samuel Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
Is it time to pull the plug?

The Carolyn Kieger experiment has been a long-awaited process, as the winning culture has yet to be established. Now, in her seventh season, the pieces still do not fit.

In the midst of a dreadful season, Penn State holds a 7-12 record and is yet to secure a Big Ten win. This poses an important question: Does Kieger deserve another chance?

Noah Aberegg: A case for Kieger

While some are calling for Kieger's firing or for the entire basketball program to be dismantled, I don’t believe it’s the right time.

Sure, she’s only produced one winning record in her six years with Penn State, with another to come. But given the current roster for the Lady Lions, one more year with the Marquette alum at the helm won’t do much harm. In fact, it might be just what the blue and white need.

Throughout Kieger’s time at Penn State, she hasn’t had an established group of stars as she does now. Makenna Marisa was there for five years, but cycled through Leilani Kapinus, Ashley Owusu and Shay Ciezki.

This year, the Lady Lions have Kiyomi McMiller, Gracie Merkle, Moriah Murray, and a young handful of supporting cast members.

Besides Amiya Evans and Vitória Santana, the other nine athletes on Kieger’s roster will have the opportunity to play again next year. If and when they do, that lineup will have another year of training and chemistry under its belt.

Penn State will be joined by incoming freshman Chikae Desdunes, the No. 51 athlete in the Class of 2026. McMiller will have another year to work on patience, control and shot selection, Merkle can improve on her defense and strength and the five current freshmen — all of whom have shown potential this year — will have a full year of college experience.

If Kieger retains her current roster and still produces the same results next year then it could be time to move on. Murray, Merkle and Maggie Mendelson will graduate, and McMiller likely won’t stick around if her final year is to be a year of misery, given her star potential.

While people have said every year, “This is the Lady Lions’ year,” I believe it’ll come next season, and if it doesn’t, then it’s go time for Kieger.

Sam Simonic: The case against Kieger

It’s time for her to go.

Any supporter of the Nittany Lions’ football program understands the Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics, Pat Kraft doesn’t mess around. When it comes to an underperforming coach at the helm, Penn State is forced to respond accordingly. And, rightfully so.

The blue and white hold prestige to its name. Beyond the court, Penn State athletics has cemented itself as a perennial power in nearly every sport.

It’s not that Penn State is immune to down seasons, but rather it doesn’t have consistent losing streaks. In basketball, and specifically in women’s basketball, that standard has not been met. That is the dangerous part of keeping Kieger around.

Trial and error mark the brief adjustment period for any new coach in Happy Valley. However, a turnaround is expected in just a couple of years. In her seventh season, Kieger has made minimal improvements. If anything, it’s gotten worse.

Kieger didn’t fall under the Kraft umbrella. In fact, she was hired in 2019 under the direction of former Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics, Sandy Barbour. At the time, Kieger was viewed as an exciting hire, coming off much success at Marquette.

However, that success did not follow her to Penn State. Kieger was in charge of changing a struggling program. In many ways, a short-term rebuild was expected. But, season after season, few improvements were seen.

Across her time in State College, Kieger has only produced one winning season. That came in the 2023-24 season when the Lady Lions went 22-13 and made the WBIT. Since that season, Kieger has appeared to hit a plateau, having now tallied two of the worst seasons in her career, including this season.

Ultimately, we are now in mid January and the Lady Lions are still without a Big Ten win, even after facing Rutgers, which was winless in the Big Ten, at home. A change certainly wouldn’t guarantee rapid success, but it would give Penn State the full green light to embrace a rebuild.

Kieger was never able to do a rebuild, and it's evident. At this point, Penn State should search for a coach who can do just that.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Big Ten women’s basketball recap | Powerhouse schools remain dominant, 2 schools winless in Big Ten
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another week down, another slew of Big Ten games for women’s basketball.

While the games were more predictable this week, there were still several big moments from Week 11 of the 2025-26 season.

USC earns 1st win since December

In the wake of JuJu Watkins’ absence following an ACL tear in the second round of last year’s NCAA tournament, USC hasn’t been the same.

After starting the season 10-3, the Trojans have lost the following four games, including a pair against unranked Oregon and Minnesota.

USC flipped the script on Sunday as it earned its first win of 2026, defeating Purdue 83-57. Its last win came on Dec. 29 in an eight-point game against Nebraska.

It was another quiet game from Jazzy Davidson, who scored just 13 points on 4-for-12 shooting. Senior Kara Dunn did the heavy lifting, scoring 29 points with four triples.

The Trojans sat near the bottom of the Big Ten with just two conference wins, compared to their six wins at this time last year. Now, they’re tied for 10th in the conference with easier games against Rutgers and Northwestern on the horizon.

Indiana, Penn State remain winless in Big Ten

After Rutgers earned its first conference win over Penn State on Sunday, just two teams remain winless in conference play: Indiana and Penn State.

Indiana came into the week on a five-game losing streak, and that was extended as it fell to Washington 82-63.

Former Lady Lion Shay Ciezki continued to lead the conference in scoring as she put up another 23 points on Wednesday, shooting 7-for-11 from deep.

However, the rest of the team wasn’t able to push the Hoosiers to the win column, with just freshman Maya Makalusky scoring 16 points and five other players combining for 24 points.

Likewise, the Lady Lions saw success from Gracie Merkle and Kiyomi McMiller against Rutgers, but couldn’t come out victorious.

The two combined for 48 points, but the Scarlet Knights had five players in double figures, including Nene Ndiaye, who led the way with 20 points.

UCLA continues Big Ten dominance

After upsetting top-seeded USC in the Big Ten championship game last year, UCLA has been on a roll ever since.

That continued to be the case last week as the Bruins won two more games to move to 17-1 on the year — the best record in the Big Ten.

UCLA started the week off with an 18 point win against Minnesota, followed by a 30 point win against No. 12 Maryland.

On Wednesday’s game, UCLA star Kiki Rice led the way with 25 points, shooting an almost perfect 8-for-9. However, she was held quiet in Sunday’s big win with just eight points.

Meanwhile, the team’s supporting cast stepped up in a big way against Maryland, with Gabriela Jaquez, Charlisse Leger-Walker and Gianna Kneepkens combining for 55 points.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Weekly Recap | Penn State women’s basketball remains winless in Big Ten, showed flashes of success
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s basketball entered last week's slate with two more chances to earn its first Big Ten win. The Lady Lions traveled to Columbus, Ohio, hoping to upset a ranked Ohio State for the second straight year. The blue and white also hosted a Rutgers team that was winless in conference play.

Coach Carolyn Kieger's squad couldn’t get the job done in a blowout loss to the Buckeyes and fell just short in a close battle with the Scarlet Knights.

Penn State stands 7-12 on the season and 0-8 in the Big Ten. Even though the Lady Lions went winless, there were still both good and bad takeaways from the week.

Merkle stays efficient

Gracie Merkle has been consistent from the field all season and owns the nation's highest field-goal percentage at 74.9%. Despite the two losses, the 6-foot-6 center kept her efficiency.

The Mount Washington, Kentucky, native shot a combined 17-for-22, netting 21 points in each outing. Merkle impressed against No. 14 Ohio State, shooting 90.9% from the field, while also grabbing 11 rebounds to complete her double-double performance.

Against Rutgers, the redshirt junior wasn’t as efficient from the field, but took multiple trips to the free-throw line, going 7-for-10. This ties Merkle’s season high trips to the charity stripe, and was her third-best foul shooting performance this season.

Defense

On the defensive side of the ball, it was the tale of two stories for the Lady Lions. The blue and white gave up 108 points against the Buckeyes, marking its most points allowed this season. Penn State scored 84 points in the matchup, which would’ve been enough to win more than half its games this season.

Ohio State led from start to finish and led by as many as 26 points. The Buckeyes shot over 56% from the field and just under 50% from three-point range. However, the Lady Lions forced 17 turnovers, including 11 steals.

The blue and white improved defensively against Rutgers, falling by a score of 76-72. The Scarlet Knights’ scoring total fell under the 82.1 points per game that Penn State typically allows.

The Lady Lions held Rutgers to a 40.6% field-goal percentage and 36% from three-point range. The blue and white recorded eight steals and forced 12 turnovers.

Offensive struggles

Penn State posted strong scoring numbers and even exceeded its typical points-per-game average, but the Lady Lions also showed room for improvement.

The blue and white combined for 36 turnovers in its last two games, but 24 of those came against Ohio State. The Buckeyes capitalized on Penn State’s struggles by scoring 39 points off turnovers. Additionally, Ohio State was able to net 27 fastbreak points. The Lady Lions only scored 11 points off 17 Buckeye turnovers.

Penn State shot over 46% from the field, but went 11-for-32 from beyond the arc and 3-for-9 from the free throw line.

The Lady Lions had a better outing against the Scarlet Knights, in which they turned the ball over 12 times, which is their third-lowest mark this season. However, the blue and white only produced nine points off opponent turnovers as opposed to Rutgers’ 18.

Penn State produced a similar shooting performance to the one before, but once again struggled from deep and the foul line. The Lady Lions shot 5-for-25 from three-point range against Rutgers, and Moriah Murray, who went 8-for-17 from deep against the Buckeyes, shot 1-for-9 against the Scarlet Knights.

In that Rutgers game, at the charity stripe, the blue and white went 11-for-18, losing by just four points.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Column | Adapting to a Spanish lifestyle
author: Daniela White | The Daily Collegian
description:
Two suitcases in hand, a twenty-pound backpack weighing me down and a Lululemon fanny pack slung around my chest, I wove past the Spaniards in the Barcelona streets.

Even after a 12-hour trip, consisting of a quick layover in Dublin, Ireland, my body was spent and my mind blown once I arrived in Barcelona, Spain. But I was still able to run laps around the locals. My back ached, and all I wanted was a nap, but it didn’t stop me from being one of the faster walkers on the street.

Hands held relaxed behind their back, or a cup of coffee and a cigarette in hand, the Spaniards walked at a 60-minute mile pace, as if they had no care in the world or no destination to trek toward. It was no surprise they gave this American girl a widened side glance when I rushed (walked) past them and to my apartment.

I researched Barcelona before applying and arriving, of course, but nothing could have prepared me for the languid pace the Spaniards use throughout life, and not just when they’re blocking the five-meter-wide sidewalks.

The days are longer, and meals take place later. The nights are more lively and last until the sun rises. The people in Barcelona enjoy their lives; they take the time to savor and live out each second, minute and hour.

Cafes will open from sunrise to sunset, filled with young scholars to old shopkeepers, staying for hours at a time doing work or reading a book with a cup of coffee and a side of a smoking cigarette.

Then from 2-5 p.m., it’s like the city takes a nap, more formally known as a siesta, or what I call the best thing to ever exist. Locals close up their shops in the quiet neighborhoods, taking a moment to spend time with their family, nap, run errands or take a stroll through the park.

As a constantly busy and nervous wreck college student, the sudden change was like a soft embrace that lasted forever. My life was filled with constant rushing, leaving me with no time to breathe, but now I can truly take a pause and exhale.

Unlike at Penn State, where we pack our days with classes, quick meals, club activities and maybe a night out, I have endless hours to do all that I need. Never before in my college career have I taken the time to stroll around for an hour and sit at a cafe for another. My day has expanded, and I found myself quickly relaxing into this lifestyle that moves at a slower pace.

However, it’s been less than two weeks since I arrived, and I can’t help but occasionally rush through the slow crowds to my class, which I’m already late for, or how twice already I found a rare restaurant open at 6 p.m. to have dinner and have a snack for “dinnertime” instead.

On another note, it’s been less than two weeks, and I already find myself evolving and fitting into the Spanish lifestyle. My body grows tired at 3 p.m. and is more awake at 11 p.m.

I like exploring the city at a snail’s pace, sitting at cafes, reading and getting ahead in my assignments. I like waking early to start the day and having a pause in the middle of it to recover. I love the nightlife that bustles until morning, then repeats all over again.

While I first hated waiting until the dead of night for a cheap taco shop to open, or taking a long nap before my 2:15 p.m. class after coming home from the clubs at 5 a.m. I now find myself easily falling into this bizarre and perfect routine.

MORE ABROAD COLUMNS

title: Preview | No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey set to close series with No. 12 Cornell
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
On Dec. 30, the No. 4 Nittany Lions closed out 2025 with a 1-0 victory over No. 12 Cornell at Pegula Ice Arena behind freshman Matilde Fantin’s lone goal. It was a test of longevity and stamina — who could outlast the other — and the blue and white came out on top in the third period.

Since the calendars changed, Penn State saw diminished results. The Nittany Lions were swept by No. 2 Ohio State, fell in overtime to unranked Mercyhurst, and endured a scare to Syracuse on Saturday as well, winning 3-2.

However, the blue and white have the opportunity to put the mid-season blues to rest. Penn State and the Big Red are set to close out the second and last game they’ll face each other this season at 6 p.m. on Tuesday at Lynah Rink in Ithaca, New York.

Ranked opponents

Cornell returns home to the Lynah Rink from New Haven, Connecticut, where the Big Red suffered a 3-1 loss to No. 13 Yale on Saturday afternoon. With a 12-7-2 overall record, the last time that Cornell defeated a ranked team was on Nov. 15, when Karel Prefontaine scored the golden goal in overtime to secure a 4-3 victory.

Since then, the Big Red have struggled against the tougher competition. On Jan. 9, Cornell was on pace to take down No. 11 Clarkson, holding a 5-3 lead late in the third period. However, the Golden Knights potted a pair of power-play goals to force overtime. Ultimately, the contest ended in a draw nationally, despite the Big Red winning in a shootout.

Meanwhile, the Nittany Lions had success in their ranked affairs prior to their run-in with the Buckeyes. On Oct. 17 and Oct. 18, Penn State swept then-No. 15 Mercyhurst on home ice. Then, over a month later, the Nittany Lions split a two-game series with No. 7 Northeastern in Boston.

Scouting the Big Red

When glancing at Cornell’s roster, it’s hard to overlook goaltender Annelies Bergmann. With a .930 save-percentage and a 1.91 goals-against average, the junior from Detroit has kept the Big Red competitive in nearly every game they’ve played. Bergmann also sits tied for sixth in the nation with four shutouts on the season.

Alyssa Regalado and Piper Grober present the largest defensive threat, putting in solid performances against the Nittany Lions in their previous meeting. Regalado leads the defense in blocked shots with 27 on the season, with Grober following closely behind with 26.

However, Cornell’s biggest contributor on both ends of the ice is Avi Adam. The senior from Wolfville, Nova Scotia, leads the Big Red with 21 points and 29 blocked shots as a proper two-way forward.

Absences, current and upcoming

Penn State will be playing without Fantin for the foreseeable future, as the Como, Italy, native returned to her home country to prepare for the upcoming Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games with Team Italy.

Similarly, this week will be the last for Tessa Janecke and Nicole Hall, as well. Following the Nittany Lions’ series against Delaware in Happy Valley, Janecke and Hall are going overseas to play for Team USA and Team Sweden, respectively.

Goaltender Katie DeSa has been sidelined for the past five games with an undisclosed injury, allowing freshman Maddy Campbell to step up as the temporary starter. DeSa is tied for first in the nation with seven shutouts and is currently one away from breaking Penn State’s all-time shutout record.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Around the Big Ten | Off the mat headlines overshadow weekend slate
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
This past week, Penn State headlined the Big Ten wrestling slate with a dominant performance against the Iowa Hawkeyes. While that was Friday’s primetime bout, the rest of the conference had a noteworthy week.

Here’s what happened in the conference.

Iowa makes roster change

Before diving into the results on the mat, the top story of the week dropped out of Iowa City last Tuesday. During his weekly media availability, Iowa coach Tom Brands told reporters that then No. 4 197-pound wrestler Massoma Endene was no longer with the program.

Endene had been out with an injury and stepped away from the team temporarily following the birth of his first child last week, prior to the announcement. Freshman Harvey Ludington took Endene’s spot in the lineup against the Nittany Lions and is expected to keep the role moving forward.

Friday night lights

The second match of Big Ten Network’s Friday night doubleheader was a bout between Nebraska and Minnesota, that saw nine matches decided via decision.

Despite scoring 21 points, Nebraska was credited with a 20-12 victory over the Golden Gophers after No. 4 heavyweight AJ Ferrari was assessed an unsportsmanlike conduct deduction for his celebration after defeating Koy Hopke in sudden victory.

Other noteworthy results from the dual include No. 10 Vance Vombaur’s decision victory over Jake Hockaday at 141-pounds, No. 5 Antrell Taylor pinning No. 19 Charlie Millard at 157-pounds and No. 3 Max McEnelly needing a sudden victory period to outlast No. 9 Silas Allred at 184-pounds.

Elsewhere in the conference, Purdue took down Maryland 28-11 on the road despite missing two key contributors in Joey Blaze and Greyson Clark. The key victory came when No. 22 Ben Vanadia took out No. 15 Branson John via major decision at 197-pounds.

The evening also saw Michigan defeat Rutgers, Illinois defeat Michigan State and Wisconsin hand Northwestern their first loss of the season.

Sunday matinee slate

Three other Big Ten duals occurred on Sunday afternoon, which included Penn State sweeping Northwestern. The Nittany Lions’ 52-point margin of victory accounted for the conferences’ largest of the season.

Maryland fell to 0-4 in the conference after a 26-12 loss to Penn State’s other upcoming opponent, Indiana. Despite the team loss John bounced back in the highest-ranked match on the card, upsetting No. 14 Gabe Sollars, 4-3.

Rutgers stomped Purdue 24-9 in Piscataway, New Jersey, behind victories in four-ranked matches. With the dual starting at 197, Remy Cotton and heavyweight No. 20 Hunter Catka set the tone with back-to-back major decisions. Despite the loss, Purdue had some standout performances, including Ashton Jackson taking No. 27 Ayden Smith to sudden victory at 125 pounds and Brody Baumann shocking No. 10 Lenny Pinto at 174.

Finally, Michigan outlasted Illinois in the closest dual of the weekend, 18-14. The standout result from Ann Arbor was Illinois’ 184-pounder No. 32 Chris Moore scoring a decision over No. 8 Brock Mantanona.

MORE WRESTLING CONTENT

title: Weekly Recap | No. 4 women’s hockey completes season sweep of Syracuse
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a 1-3 start to their seven-game road trip, the Nittany Lions got things back on track with a pair of wins over the Syracuse Orange.

Looking for their first win in a week, the blue-and-white took Friday’s contest 4-1 and followed it up with a 3-2 win on Saturday. Penn State will finish the regular season 4-0 against Syracuse, outscoring the Orange 25-5 in the process. The blue and white have also now won each of their last nine games against the Orange, dating back to January 2024.

Go-getter Grace

In both games of the weekend sweep, sophomore winger Grace Outwater found herself at the top of the scoring sheet with the first goal for the Nittany Lions. Her 14th and 15th goals of the season sparked Penn State to its 20th and 21st wins of the season. Outwater has now scored first for Penn State in five games this season, the most on the team.

The Picton, Ontario, native has tallied 26 points so far this season, second on the team to Tessa Janecke

Butze stands alone

Defenseman Kendall Butze was one of five different skaters to put up multi-point games over the weekend, but her assist on Saturday set her performance apart from the rest.

Trailing 1-0, Outwater found the back of the net just over two minutes after Syracuse got on the board first. Butze and Mikah Keller were each credited with an assist. For Butze, it was her 15th of the season and the 66th of her career, a new Penn State hockey record for assists by a defenseman.

Entering this season, the senior trailed Lyndie Lobdell, 2024, and Izzy Heminger, 2023. Her 15 assists this season are the most among defensemen.

Tessa at the top

Just weeks after being named the first player in program history to represent the United States on the women’s hockey team, Janecke scored three goals over the weekend, her third serving as the game-winning goal in the 3-2 win on Saturday.

Janecke’s three goals bring her season total to 16, the most in the conference. Saturday’s contest was just the second this season in which the captain found the back of the net multiple times. She first did it in a 6-1 win over Lindenwood in October.

The Orangeville, Illinois, native has now accumulated 188 points in her career, putting her just 12 shy of the 200 career-point threshold.

Campbell continues

With Katie DeSa still out with an undisclosed injury, Jeff Kampersal has turned to freshman Maddy Campbell to go between the pipes for the Nittany Lions.

Campbell entered the weekend having allowed a career-high four goals in two of her last three appearances. However, the Courtice, Ontario, native was able to turn things around in New York, as she made 44 saves on 47 shots faced.

Over the weekend, Campbell would finish 2-0 with a .936 save percentage.

Campbell and the Nittany Lions will conclude their road trip with one game against Cornell on Tuesday. Puck drop is scheduled for 6 p.m. at Lynah Rink.

MORE HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Column | Penn State wrestling is miles ahead, dominant win over Iowa proves it
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
To call Penn State a dynasty would be an understatement.

The Nittany Lions have won 12 of the last 14 national championships, and have won four-straight national titles three different times.

In the NIL era, other teams have the opportunity to close the gap. Iowa and Oklahoma State are the two most storied programs across NCAA wrestling history. If given substantial funding, those programs are expected to take a jump and compete against the Nittany Lions. However, that has yet to happen, with Iowa most recently falling to Penn State 32-3.

The commanding win for the Nittany Lions over the Hawkeyes, one of the most historically dominant teams in the sport, showcases that Penn State is in a different lane than everyone else.

Penn State is coming off a season where it broke many records, including the points record in the NCAA championship and having all 10 wrestlers earn All-American status.

Iowa has seemingly dropped in competitiveness compared to Penn State. Whether that’s because the Nittany Lions continue to improve or the Hawkeyes’ wrestlers have dropped in talent level is yet to be determined.

The domination from Penn State on Friday raises concern for the state of the Iowa program. It has many people asking if the Hawkeyes have fallen off after one of the most lopsided duals in Iowa-Penn State history.

“I think that we have the right guys to do the job,” Iowa coach Tom Brands said post match. “There is a gap between Iowa and Penn State.”

That gap hasn’t been close since Iowa’s defeat of the Nittany Lions on Jan. 31, 2020, the last time Penn State lost a dual meet to any team.

On paper, Iowa has top wrestlers in their program, which included matches at 184 and 285 being weight classes the Hawkeyes could win.

Yet it didn’t happen, as the Hawkeyes had No. 1 Angelo Ferrari lose to No. 4 Rocco Welsh. Welsh wrestled to his style, defeating him 2-1 in an intense, yet stall-heavy tiebreaker at 184. At heavyweight, No. 13 Cole Mirasola took down No. 5 Ben Kueter in a close battle, too.

Two of Iowa’s top wrestlers failed to step up on the biggest stage of the regular season. It was something that was also notable at last year’s NCAA Championships when its transfer portal additions in highly touted Jacori Teemer failed to place, or earn any points for the Hawkeyes.

Iowa has had 34 straight years with a national finalist, which could come to an end this season. And if it doesn’t, it’ll likely come from Ferrari who’s notoriously scored few points, leading to few points earned for the overall team score.

The Hawkeyes’ major run came in the 1990s under legendary coaches Dan Gable and Jim Zalesky. Brands brought the team back to national championships with three straight titles from 2008-10.

The run may be coming to an end for Iowa as a perennial top-three team in the country, but Penn State has shown no signs of slowing down.

The Nittany Lions are a very young team with perspective. Levi Haines is the lone senior, with William Henckel in line to start next year. Henckel was a U20 World Silver Medalist, while Jayden James, a U17 World Champion could also be in the mix in that weight class when he arrives as a freshman next year.

Penn State has a surplus of title contenders to choose from, and also has FloWrestling’s No. 2 recruiting class in 2027 with No. 2 Landon Sidun and No. 6 Grey Burnett, as guys up next in the lighter weight classes.

While the train might be coming to a halt in Iowa City, the Penn State train continues to chug along, getting further away from what was once a formidable opponent.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Big Ten Recap | Men’s basketball shakeups in standings imminent
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten basketball season swung into full tilt, as the conference teams approached the midpoints of their seasons.

The hierarchical order of teams starts to emerge at this point, and with it, schools are breaking and meeting expectations. This factor reinforces the need to reflect, especially on the Big Ten media poll at the start of the year, as some of its rankings seem laughable at the midseason.

The last week of play inside the conference only strengthens that narrative.

Boilermaker brilliance, Cornhusker continuation

In the preseason poll, there stood one team as a favorite above them all — Purdue. After this past week of play, the placement is justified. The Boilermakers squeaked out two close wins on the road over Iowa and USC, both middle-of-the-pack teams with strong home records, however.

Leading Purdue, as always, is a stout big man, this time in the form of Oscar Cluff, and he’s posted efficient outings, such as a 19 point outing against USC, yet he’s played second fiddle.

The leading story out of West Lafayette is Braden Smith, who, in his fourth year with Purdue, played his best basketball so far in his career, as he stands on pace to challenge Bobby Hurley’s all-time career assists mark.

Against USC and Iowa, Smith led the Boilermakers in scoring, as the NCAA’s best passer opted to lead with his jumper, yet also posted 13 assists over the two games.

The other team atop the conference, Nebraska, didn’t get that initial buzz predicted as preseason predictions had it finishing in the bottom five of the conference. Over the past week of play, it defeated Oregon 90-55 and Northwestern 77-58, rising to 18-0. Evan Miyakawa ranks the Cornhuskers as the 12th-best team in the nation and tabs it as a hot team at the moment.

Northwestern, Penn State sink to the bottom

While those two teams skyrocketed to the top amid mixed expectations, a pair of teams sank like an anchor to the bottom of the Big Ten once conference play started.

The media picked Penn State to finish at the bottom of the conference, while it picked Northwestern just slightly below Nebraska at fourth from the bottom. Both big cat schools sit winless in the conference and have lost their last five games.

Both suffered 11 point losses to UCLA and No.11 Illinois on Jan. 14, respectively. Nebraska crushed the Wildcats, while Maryland destroyed Penn State; both squads had little to boast about this season, and last week embodied that sentiment perfectly.

The two teams face each other soon, on Jan 29, and it’ll be a battle to avoid the bottom.

Middle of the pack moments

Between those top of the conference juggernauts and those Big Ten bottom dwellers, there remain 14 teams all vying to differentiate themselves from the pack, and after the past week of play, some squads attempted that.

Those attempts span both on and off the court. A team like Ohio State, which sits seventh, added a sixth-year former Nittany Lions forward, Puff Johnson, hoping to boost its squad midseason, although it triumphed over UCLA without him this past week, who stands one spot below the Buckeyes.

Indiana and Iowa occupy the next two spots below them in the standings and faced each other last week. Iowa pulled out a 17 point victory, which tied it with Indiana at 3-4 in the conference, although the Hawkeyes appear prepared to make a leapfrog.

The next week of play inside the Big Ten has the majority of the middle-of-the-pack teams scheduled to face each other; Minnesota faces Ohio State, Rutgers heads to Iowa City to face the Hawkeyes, and the rest of the top five conference teams, behind Purdue and Nebraska. Michigan State and Illinois are set to face lower-half conference teams in Maryland and Oregon.

The matchup to watch around the Big Ten this next week is Michigan against Indiana. Michigan routinely has been tested this season and Indiana has the quality to mount an upset, despite its crushing loss to the Hawkeyes in the past week.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘Dane is a Trojan’ | Dane Dowiak exemplifies what it means to be captain at Penn State
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
When Dane Dowiak speaks, his teammates listen.

The junior forward never shies away from speaking his mind. And he’s sometimes brutally honest. But he can be, because he backs his words with an unmatched work ethic.

He’s considered the strongest player on the team. He’s unafraid to scrap for a loose puck along the boards or lay a booming hit to spark a comeback. He’s willing to play any role asked of him with no complaints.

Bottom line: Dowiak is a team-first guy. It’s why his teammates love him. It’s why they respect him. And it’s why they voted him the 12th captain in program history.

“(Dane) is very accountable to himself. He talks a big game, but he backs it up,” Penn State coach Guy Gadowsky said. “He's an extremely strong, gritty guy. He loves Penn State and embodies it. Most importantly, he plays for the team.”

Gadowsky lauded Dowiak’s willingness to do “the little things” that don’t show up in the box score. Like getting pucks out of the defensive zone, winning face-offs, getting cross-checked as he pokes at a loose puck, and, as Gadowsky elegantly stated, “getting his ankles hacked.”

Dowiak’s teammates recognize his unselfishness. They appreciate his authentic leadership style — one filled with both passion and compassion. They respect his ability to joke with them on the same day he airs them out for an embarrassing performance.

And they laud his willingness to never ask something of them he wouldn’t do himself.

“Dane is a nails guy — a guy we all look to when things are tough,” sophomore forward Braeden Ford said. “When things are tough, you look for a guy to lead the way, you look for a guy to lead the charge, and Dane is the perfect guy to do that. He'll go through somebody on the wall. He'll go score a greasy goal. He's a guy that everybody looks to for some energy and to get us going.”

Dowiak’s leadership role has grown since his first collegiate season. But he’s never needed a fancy title or a letter stitched on his jersey to motivate his teammates.

The Pittsburgh native didn’t require a boost from his coaches to outwork everyone in the weight room as a freshman. He didn’t complain when asked to play one game on the top scoring line and the next told to block shots and clear pucks on the penalty kill.

Gadowsky said he always knew Dowiak embodied traits aligned with Penn State’s captaincy. It’s why the head coach entered the season with high expectations of his junior captain. And it’s why he appeared unfazed to see his players accept Dowiak’s leadership style.

“We are seeing exactly what we saw from Dane the previous two (seasons), and I'm sure it’s exactly why he got selected by his peers,” Gadowsky said. “He does his job. He can play in every situation, and no matter what you ask of him, he never complains. He's never even hinted at wanting a different role. He'll do whatever is asked of him to the best of his ability.”

Junior forward Reese Laubach is in his third season with Penn State. He’s experienced various leadership styles, from the vocal leadership of captain Christian Berger to the quiet, measured leadership of last season’s captain, Simon Mack.

But Dowiak brings something different. Because, as Luabach explained, Dowiak leads by example.

Picture this. Penn State just lost 7-1 on its home ice to then-No. 2 Michigan — a demoralizing defeat that marked the team’s third consecutive loss. Its players were defeated and discouraged. Most importantly, they were embarrassed by their poor effort against a Big Ten rival.

The Nittany Lions sat silent at their lockers, awaiting a possible message from Gadowsky. But their coach never showed. He knew his captain’s words would hold more weight. He knew Dowiak would speak because his competitiveness wouldn’t stand another effort like the one seen that Friday night inside Pegula Ice Arena.

And, as Laubach said, when Dowiak spoke, everyone listened.

“(Dane’s) words go a long way with how he plays and how he holds himself,” freshman defenseman Nolan Collins said. “He plays hard for us. He blocks shots for us. He throws his body around. So it's easy to follow a guy like that.”

Dowiak’s words did hold weight. The junior forward assisted Laubach’s game-winning goal as Penn State defeated Michigan 4-2 the next night.

It was an example of Dowiak’s leadership style, one that rubbed off on his teammates to earn an upset win. And while that style resonated that night, his leadership extends beyond hustle plays and blocked shots.

Sophomore goaltender Kevin Reidler called Dowiak an “awesome leader” because of his positivity on and off the ice. Sophomore defenseman Nick Fascia said it’s “easy” to play for someone like Dowiak, who himself does everything he asks of others.

Halfway through Dowiak’s first season as captain, the Nittany Lions are rolling. They’re 16-6 and ranked No. 8 in the latest USCHO poll.

There are many reasons for Penn State’s hot start. The additions of top NHL draft prospects Gavin McKenna and 2025 first-round pick Jackson Smith have certainly helped. As has standout play from its goaltending tandem of Reidler and Josh Fleming.

But, as Dowiak’s teammates would tell you, his leadership has topped everything.

“Dane is a Trojan. He's our captain,” freshman forward Shea Van Olm said. “We look up to him, we want him to lead, and he knows, being in the position he's in, he's got to lead by example.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Column | The anthropology of Penn State
author: Julia Kushner | The Daily Collegian
description:
If you’re anything like me, growing up, your parents regaled you with stories from their college days, usually concerning their collegiate escapades, but with some cultural flair as well.

For example, my dad, a graduate of the University of Michigan (sigh), barring all of his Greek life adventures (he was a pledge master in the ‘80s — do with that what you will), most often told me about the “M” in the Diag quad.

If you stepped on this infamous letter, it was said you wouldn’t pass your next exam unless you ran about a half mile to a nearby clock tower in ten seconds or less.

Though seemingly just a silly tradition, this 70-plus-year-old lore has stood the test of time, but if you mentioned the bronze “M” to anyone who hasn’t gone to UMich or heard stories from someone who did, it would make no sense to them.

Just as we here at PSU use words and phrases like “THON,” “State Patty’s,” and “townies” that would mean virtually nothing to the average Joe Schmoe around the block, every campus has its own unique culture.

We’re connected here by much more than simple accidental proximity. We’re connected by tradition, by culture, by vocabulary, and even by brands.

We all know that Crown Russe will put the fear of G-d into anyone who’s ever tasted it before, but outside of PA, I don’t know anyone who’s even heard of it, let alone drank it. And every college has its own brand of disgusting and disgustingly cheap vodka used at every frat party.

We even have our own cultural rites of passage. Yes, everyone across America celebrates their 21st birthday as it symbolizes something special. But at Penn State, it would be a crime if you didn’t celebrate it at The Phyrst with the green, plastic top hat and a shot of a more explicit nature.

Food is a similarly strong indicator of a unique cultural space. We all know that D.P. Dough is the greatest drunk food of all time, but would probably be revolting to consume in sobriety. Similarly, El Jefe’s is best consumed after a night out. And The Tavern is a great spot for when your daddy’s in town, footing the bill.

And although I’m a bit of a luddite with a rather lackluster grasp on pop culture these days, even I know we have our very own campus celebrities. Before she graduated, Katie Feeney was a constant presence in the PSU football world, and her successor, Megan Million, is relatively well known in the Dunkin’ and social media world.

I often think about, as a senior, what I’ll remember after I graduate, and especially, what I’ll remember well enough to tell my own children about.

I think about our singing “Sweet Caroline” at every football game; about the Willard preacher in his classic red sweatshirt; about the daunting feeling of stepping into Thomas 100 or Forum 102 for the first time. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg.

None of these things are official, and none of them are school-sanctioned, but this is what we remember most about our experiences here.

Each and every university is its own micro-culture, its own small study of anthropology.

What will you remember?

MORE COLUMNS

title: ‘We could all use a bit more love’ | Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Service honors his legacy
author: Alex Fischer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Students gathered in the HUB-Robeson Center Monday afternoon to celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy with an annual Day of Service. Hosted by the Martin Luther King Jr. Commemoration Student Committee, the theme for this year’s MLK Day celebrations is “Undaunted Hope.”

The MLK Day of Service is part of a nationwide movement started in 1994 to turn a federal holiday — a day “off” — into a day of community service — a day “on.”

The event began with breakfast, followed by a keynote speech from Smeal College of Business Associate Dean Jamie Campbell and a video about the life and legacy of King.

Attendees then dispersed into volunteer groups to work with non-profit organizations from Centre County, including Centre Safe, the Jana Marie Foundation, the Youth Service Bureau and the Institute for Promoting Health, Education, Art and Technology (iPHET).

Maya Mathes, a member of the MLK Commemoration Student Committee’s planning committee, was thrilled to see about 600 people in Alumni Hall at the start of the day.

“I just hope that people get a lot of fulfillment out of this,” Mathes, a third-year studying food science, said. “(Waking) up early in the morning, on a snowy day with 22 degree weather, no school … I’m just happy that a lot of people just want to give back to our community.”

Mathes said her mom raised her to always give back to the community.

“It’s just always been a core part of who I am as a person,” Mathes said. “And I feel like just being able to give back to Centre County, where I’ve been a resident for three years now, I feel like it’s a really nice way for me to just show my appreciation to everybody around me.”

Patrick Williams, the outreach director for the MLK Commemoration Committee, said his favorite part of the day was going from room to room, checking in with each volunteer group and seeing everyone talking to each other.

“Everybody is just spreading love because that’s what MLK wanted,” Williams, a fourth-year studying telecommunications and media industries, said. “You get people from diverse backgrounds just spreading awareness, spreading love, everybody coming together.”

Ezekiel Hernandez spent the afternoon helping the Youth Services Bureau package diapers with members of his fraternity, Sigma Lambda Beta.

“There’s a lot of stuff that’s been happening all across the United States and across the world,” Hernandez, a third-year studying computational data science, said. “I’m Latino, (and) there’s been a lot of different things with ICE, with Venezuela, just so many different things that are happening right now … but there’s still a lot of people that are in need of help, and we just need to keep pushing forward.”

Valeria Herrera attended the event with her roommate.

“I actually transferred from a community college this semester, so this is all very new,” Herrera, a third-year studying global and international studies, said. “I wanted to get more involved on campus and just help out as much as I can.”

Herrera worked on making “Jared Boxes” for the Jared Box Project, which are plastic, shoe-sized boxes filled with gifts, games and toys which are given to children in hospitals all over the country.

“I think it’s so much fun to just envision a little kid receiving a box, and then just lighting up (with) excitement,” Herrera said. “I just want to make positive impacts in (these) little kids’ lives, because they’re just in hospitals all day, every day, and I feel like their days could definitely be really gloomy … I want to make them happy and make their childhood as normal as possible.”

Kadyn Young was at the Day of Service with members of her sorority, Alpha Kappa Alpha, making first-aid kids for iPHET.

“With everything going on in the world, we could all use a bit more love, we could all use a bit more unity,” Young, a second-year studying finance, said. “So, I feel like that’s a great way to honor him, (by) helping others and giving back to our community … (MLK Day) is not just a day off, it’s a day of doing something to honor his legacy.”

Paris Stafford, co-director of the MLK Commemoration Committee, said it’s important to not forget MLK’s legacy.

“No one wants to repeat history,” Stafford, a third-year studying economics, said. “So really just, keeping all our generations, future generations informed of what MLK did.”

King is also the reason Stafford went into economics, as King had written a book about the connection between systemic poverty and systemic racism.

“He wanted everyone to be equitable and everyone to be equal,” Stafford said. “I really thought that was just phenomenal. And using that type of mindset, it really got me into economics and wanting to kind of close that generational wage gap.”

As volunteers came back together in Alumni Hall at the end of the event, they were asked to sign a large “MLK 2026” poster on their way in. The prompt was: “What hope do you want to create?”

“MLK has definitely been a big part of my life,” Stafford said. “And so, really, just seeing this opportunity to do service in my community is just phenomenal.”

title: ‘It was quite enlightening’ | CSA holds 13th Annual Miss West Indies Pageant
author: Rubi Orellana & Kyla Jones | The Daily Collegian
description:
Correction: A previous version of this article incorrectly stated that Miss Jamaica took first place at the pageant. The story has been updated to reflect Miss Panama as the winner. The Daily Collegian apologizes for this error.

Miss Panama took first place at Penn State’s 13th Annual Miss West Indies Pageant: Pearl of the Caribbean on Saturday evening in Alumni Hall, with Miss Jamaica placing first runner up, Miss Dominican Republic earning second place and Miss Haiti placing third.

The event, held from 6-10:30 p.m., featured four contestants — Miss Panama, Miss Haiti, Miss Dominican Republic and Miss Jamaica — who showcased their nations through cultural wear, performances and personal presentations.

Camren Boyogueno, president of the Caribbean Student Association (CSA), said she has experienced the pageant at every level and seen its evolution.

“Seeing how far the pageant has come mirrors my own growth within CSA and highlights how it continues to evolve into a signature cultural event at Penn State,” Boyogueno, a fourth-year studying psychology, said.

The pageant included talent, advocacy and carnival portions which were all culturally based, meant to highlight the importance of cultural representation on campus.

“You can’t find opportunities to learn about Caribbean culture unless you’re actively seeking them,” Boyogueno said.

This year’s planning faced funding challenges for certain organizations under Paul Robeson Cultural Center, resulting in the team having to fundraise independently.

“It is a way to broadcast cultural information and personal stories, allowing students to feel at home even when they’re far away,” Boyogueno said. “It highlights diversity in a space where it’s not always visible and encourages students to step into areas they haven’t explored before.”

Reflecting on her journey from participant to President, Boyogueno sees the pageant’s growth as both personal and communal.

“Holding the 13th year pageant means I was able to uphold CSA’s legacy, continuing the tradition and hopefully making it a bigger event in cultural organizations and not only smaller communities,” Boyogueno said.

Jenna Vega, a dancer on the Caribbean dance team Island Fever, said it was her first time attending the pageant and she had a “really good time.”

“I love seeing everyone in Caribbean culture come together and the performances and my Caribbean dance team,” Vega, a third-year studying rehabilitation and human services, said.

Preparing for the performance required dedication and teamwork, according to Vega.

“We started preparing right before break and put in a lot of effort,” Vega said. “It was a little rough, but I’m really proud of how we performed today. It all came together really good.”

Vega said everyone at the event was happy to be there and attendees could “feel the energy in the room,” making the event a “good time.”

Norma Sannon said she appreciated the depth of the contestants’ presentations and the cultural issues they addressed.

“I love the way they talked about specific issues their respective countries are going through,” Sannon, a third-year studying global and international studies, said. “It was quite enlightening.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: ‘I felt comfortable’ | Penn State guard Kayden Mingo makes return from injury in Maryland loss
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Guard Kayden Mingo was on the court warming up ahead of Penn State’s game against Maryland on Sunday. He was listed as “questionable” before the game due to his nose injury.

Mingo then made his return to action by slotting back into the starting lineup and dropping 19 points, five assists, three rebounds and a steal despite a 96-73 loss to the Terrapins. He wore a face mask during the game and explained what it was like playing in his first game back.

“I felt comfortable,” Mingo said postgame. “It was an adjustment at first and practice and stuff, and now I feel good with it.”

Mingo spoke to reporters during a press conference on Jan. 5, and there wasn’t an indication he was dealing with any injuries at that moment. However, during a practice later that day, Mingo suffered a broken nose, which forced him to miss the Michigan game on Jan. 6, and he didn’t even appear on the sideline for the matchup.

The freshman remained listed as “out” for the Purdue game on Jan. 10, but Mike Rhoades provided more clarity on the situation postgame, saying Mingo’s surgery “went well.”

Mingo stayed under the “out” section of the availability report for the UCLA game last week, but he made a public appearance and sat on the sideline for the contest.

Sunday marked the first time Mingo warmed up ahead of a matchup since suffering the injury, and he didn’t believe he’d be sidelined for a long time.

“I didn't think (my absence) would be too long,” Mingo said. “I know I'm around a lot of great people who can help me and get me back fast, so I didn't stress on it too much. I just wished my teammates good luck as they went into the next couple games.”

Mingo kicked off the game with a corner three, as Penn State grabbed an early lead. Through the first five minutes, Mingo had seven points on 100% shooting, keeping the Nittany Lions within range of Maryland’s 16-13 advantage.

The Terrapins began to run away with the game in the first half, leading 56-26 at halftime, but Mingo helped Penn State stay in the game. Coming out of the second half, the Nittany Lions cut the lead down to 10 points behind multiple plays by Mingo.

“I thought his timing was off a little bit at times, but he battled, especially in the second half when we made that run,” Rhoades said postgame. “I thought he really got downhill, was pushing the ball, got us into stuff and all that. So our trainer did a great job with him, helping him get back. Doctors did a great job to get him back. You just got to get now, in the flow of it, and the feel of it, all that stuff. He was out for a while, but he's a hard rock and dude, he's a tough kid.”

Mingo averages 15.2 points, 3.9 rebounds, 4.5 assists and 2.4 steals per game throughout 15 appearances this season. He shot 58.3% from the field and 40% from 3-point range against the Terrapins, improving his season shooting marks to 49.2% from the field and 25% from 3-point range.

It was more than just a return for Mingo as he seemed his usual self at times throughout the game against Maryland. He credited Penn State’s training staff for its efforts.

“Our trainer, Justin (Pomar), had a good plan in place,” Mingo said. “We took it day by day, and every day was a step closer to getting back in the process. Give all thanks to Justin and everybody who helped me.”

title: This week in State College
author: Ava Aguiar | The Daily Collegian
description:
Now that students are settled back into classes and their home away from home, events in State College are beginning to pick up.

Here’s some events for students to enjoy this week.

Monday, January 19

Yoga & Meditation

If you’re in need of a break after syllabus week, there will be free Yoga & Meditation in Room 232 of the HUB-Robeson Center from 12:30-1:30 p.m.

Sessions will be taught by certified instructors and all are welcome. Participants are encouraged to bring their own yoga materials as supplies are limited.

MLK Free Soup Dinner

On the dinner menu is potato leek soup, slaw and oatmeal cookies. Those interested in attending should register at the link.

Tuesday, January 20

Dr. King Memorial March

Celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King’s legacy at the 2026 Memorial March: Undaunted Hope.

The march is set to begin at 3:45 p.m. at Downtown MLK Plaza on the 100 Block of S Fraser Street. After the march there will be a panel discussion in the Freeman Auditorium followed by a social reception in the Paul Robeson Center.

Fill out this form if you plan to attend 2026 Dr. Martin Luther King - Undaunted Hope: Memorial March – Fill out form

Salsa Lessons

Come with or without a partner, as they take care of pairing, and no experience is necessary. The first 90 minutes will be for lessons, while the rest is left for socializing.

Wednesday, January 21

You will learn skills to deal with and manage the way you respond to stress in this calming environment. No registration is required.

Thursday, January 22

Return to Rec Hall

Tickets start at $26 for the 7 p.m. game where the Nittany Lions will take on the Wisconsin Badgers.

Create Your Career Vision Board

The Queer Business Leaders are hosting a Vision Board night dedicated to planning out your dream career. Join them in Room 108 of the Business Building.

Friday, January 23

“Interstellar” at the State Theatre

Student tickets are $10.58 and non-student tickets are $12.68.

Women’s Ice Hockey

Join the student section in cheering them on at 6 p.m. No ticket purchase is required.
