title: Column | Authentically inauthentic: Music’s evolution away from sincerity
author: Emma Strickling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Much like anything, music has evolved and continues to evolve over time. While things like genre popularity have influenced its direction — the most influential factor is arguably technology.

Increased technological capabilities has allowed artists a greater ability to expand the way they create music. While technology is a helpful tool, I think it’s led to less authenticity in music. For example, autotune, which made its way onto the music scene in 1997, has made music less unique and personal

Cher’s “Believe,” one of the more notable songs featuring autotune, used it as a pitch corrector. Its usage meant less time was spent in the studio rerecording vocals, saving the bigwigs of the label money. Today technology can do a myriad of things, such as shape one’s voice manually . Furthermore, its broadened capabilities now make this a staple within the music industry today, with a large majority of artists using autotune on their records.

While some argue technology broadens the scope of musical ability, I believe it takes away the opportunity for an authentic sound — making each singer’s voice a replication of others. All the distinct little quirks within a singer's voice are no longer present, leaving the vocals sounding soulless.

So what if the note is a little flat? I want to hear the little imperfections. I want to hear the humanity of natural singing and instrumentation, not something that sounds like it’s coming from a computer.

One of my favorite artists is Bob Dylan, and occasionally, when I mention that to people, they normally comment on his singing voice. I know he’s not the best singer ever to exist on this Earth.

However, the thing that sets Dylan apart from modern-day singers and one of the reasons I admire him is that he’s not pretending to be some great singer. Even as an 84-year-old man, he’s still performing, now with a gravelly and weathered voice. Some might argue it’s worse than before, but he isn’t covering it up.

Not only does excess technology rob music of an authentic sound, the lyrics suffer as well. If it seems like songs today are simpler and more repetitive, it’s because they are. A study from the Scientific American magazine found over the past 50 years songs have adopted longer choruses which is part of the reason everything sounds the same.

In a lot of modern music it seems like the chorus takes up half the song, and in some cases it absolutely does.

Even songs today credit multiple people writing on them. Popular names like Benson Boone and Sabrina Carpenter have credited at least three people per song on their most recently released album. One would think that by having a variety of perspectives, there would be a greater possibility for more unique lyrics and less repetition. But alas that isn’t the case.

Authenticity of voice is especially important for songwriting because it creates a connection between performer and listener. It’s more compelling when you hear a song that comes from a place of true expression and feeling, whereas repetitive writing potentially leaves the listener uninspired and bored. Well, at least it does for me.

I think something that gets overlooked today is that songwriting is just as much a method of storytelling as any artistic medium. Take the song “Suite: Judy Blue Eyes” written by Stephen Stills and performed by Crosby, Stills & Nash. It’s divided up into four sections, true to its name as suite, with each section distinct from the others. Yes, there’s a repeating theme in the first part with the chorus, but it’s not like it occurs during the entire seven minutes of the song.

Through his songwriting, Stills reflects on a relationship that’s on the verge of ending. Not only is there strong lyrical writing, but the inclusion of harmonies provided by bandmates David Crosby and Graham Nash really help to create a sound that’s distinct and authentic to their group.

To make it clear, I’m not trying to say that music needs to be complex in order to be considered great. Simple songs can be great, too, if they’re done well. What I really mean is that creating music that’s heavily repetitive and dependent upon technology takes away the potential of greatness.

Perhaps these artists of today should focus more on their own abilities and not what will be commercially acceptable. If technologies like autotune are a must to today’s artists, then I think they might be in the wrong business.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Penn State women’s basketball lacks 4th quarter toughness in loss to Rutgers
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Against Illinois on Jan. 11, toughness was the key talking point for coach Carolyn Kieger as Penn State fell to 7-11 on the year.

Things were no different on Sunday as the Lady Lions fell to Rutgers, marking their eighth-straight loss and continuation of a winless conference record.

“It comes down to toughness again,” Kieger said following the Rutgers game. “We did a great job taking care of the ball tonight, but it still goes back to being tough and finishing the possession.”

For a majority of the first three quarters, that toughness was visible as the blue and white were up by three points entering the final period.

Despite not being the team’s leading scorer, 6-foot-6 Gracie Merkle was a key contributor to that toughness against the Scarlet Knights, constantly being double-teamed down in the paint.

“Well, I’m kind of used to (being double-teamed),” Merkle said. “At this point, I’m getting double-teamed, triple-teamed all game, every game. We go to practice, we work on it, and at the end of the day, I just got to go up stronger.”

Merkle put up 21 points on Sunday as she went 7-for-11 from the field. However, her strength was most evident with her 10 free throw attempts. While she only made seven of them, her strength was on display as she got to the line five times.

On the same side of the ball, freshman Nyla McFadden also exhibited the Lady Lion tenacity in her third career start.

While McFadden scored nine points on 4-for-4 shooting, her main takeaway from the game wasn’t her starting spot or perfect shooting, but rather the team’s poor fourth-quarter defense that led to Sunday’s loss.

“Really, we just need to be tougher on the defensive end,” McFadden said. “We just need to when it comes to in-the-game situations if we want to win a big game.”

Entering the final quarter up three points, the Lady Lions fell to the hands of a 9-2 run from Rutgers, who quickly retook the lead.

Despite the Scarlet Knights having just three offensive boards in the first three quarters, they tallied eight in the final period, which proved to be the game-changer.

“That’s just something that can’t happen,” McFadden said.

While Kiyomi McMiller led the team in points, her presence was limited in the early parts of the fourth quarter after picking up her fourth foul with over nine minutes to play.

McMiller ultimately returned later in the quarter to finish the day with 27 points. However, hers and Merkle’s performances couldn’t overcome Rutgers’ fourth-quarter advantage.

“So until we develop this toughness and this grit to play defense, the results are not gonna change,” Kieger said on Jan. 11 after the Illinois game.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's basketball star Kiyomi McMiller shines in loss to former team
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A few weeks after Rutgers star freshman Kiyomi McMiller made the news after being benched due to internal matters, she entered the transfer portal and ultimately committed to Penn State in April.

On Sunday, she had a chance to face her former team for the first game, putting on a dominant performance on both sides of the ball despite the Lady Lions falling to 0-8 in conference play.

McMiller kept the blue and white alive late in the fourth quarter, tallying nine of the team’s 17 points. However, hers and Gracie Merkle’s efforts alone weren’t enough for the win.

The Silver Springs, Maryland, native was silent for the first four minutes of action, but quickly came alive and stayed alive for the rest of the game. McMiller kick-started her game off with her first of many rebounds in the game and took it down the court, weaving back-and-forth through traffic as she stopped for a quick jumpshot.

As Rutgers began working the ball back down the court, ultimately missing the basket, the former Scarlet Knight earned her second rebound of the day, and after some back-and-forth ball movement, scored again with a layup.

McMiller’s success didn’t just come from her own shots, however. Down by seven points, McMiller found 6-foot-6 Merkle in the paint and dished the ball to her between tight double coverage.

After a few baskets from each team, McMiller followed up a four-point play from Viktoria Ranisavljevic with a triple of her own. That toughness continued midway through the second quarter as McMiller fought in the paint for a layup and earned a free throw, putting herself at double-digit scoring on the day.

Despite being a huge offensive and defensive asset to the Lady Lions, McMiller had a big impact on the court even when she didn’t have the ball in her hands or guard the ball.

Less than one minute into the second half, Merkle and Nyla McFadden made a pair of baskets, giving Penn State its first lead of the game. As McFadden’s shot hit the net, McMiller started clapping her hands and screaming in celebration as she stared over at Coquese Washington, her former coach.

Two drives following McMiller’s celebration, the Lady Lions made arguably one of their biggest plays of the game. Freshman Tèa Clèante picked off the inbound from Rutgers’ Lauryn Swann and passed the ball to Moriah Murray, who crossed over a pair of Rutgers players and found McMiller wide open for a layup.

Penn State ultimately lost its lead late in the fourth quarter as the Scarlet Knights got hot, but McMiller was the key difference-maker who kept things close.

With just over a minute and a half left in regulation, McMiller drained her second triple of the day to end Rutgers’ 8-1 run.

Over the next two drives, McMiller made a pair of layups to ultimately cut the lead down to three points, but her efforts weren’t enough for the Lady Lions.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Mike Rhoades reflects on coaching, defensive flubs after huge loss to Maryland
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
COLLEGE PARK, Md. – Penn State basketball went to face the Terrapins with the expectation that the Nittany Lions would fight and potentially earn their first Big Ten win against one of the other three teams that were winless in the conference. Yet, the only fight shown stood too little, too late.

Maryland endured a tumultuous season to this point, similar to Penn State, and this clash seemed like the season's pinnacle of that trend, as both staggered into the contest at less than full strength.

Mike Rhoades’ squad entered with two questionable players, its leading scorers Kayden Mingo and Freddie Dilione V, while it listed big man Tibor Mirtić as out. Both questionable players suited up, with mixed results: Mingo played his usual over 30 minutes, while Dilione’s ankle injury limited him to only 15.

Those injury woes didn’t appear early for one squad, as a Maryland unit with three players sidelined cruised to its highest scoring first half in program history, en route to an eventual 96-73 rout.

“Maryland came out and just absolutely smacked us in the first 20 minutes,” Rhoades said. “With the group we have, the young team we have, we’ve had some tough spells this year of just letting guys get off and get going, and Diggy (Coit) did that.”

Maryland guard Diggy Coit enacted the onslaught by the Terrapins, to Penn State’s ire, as he flirted with a new program single-game scoring record, ultimately finishing a point shy. The Columbus, New Jersey, native notched 43 points on the day, obviously a career high, behind nine three-pointers, which consistently came off slick handles.

“I thought (Diggy Coit) was going to score 100 points today,” Rhoades said. “Our guys are fighting, you saw the second half, I thought the first eight to ten minutes of the second half, our guys battled.”

That second-half run that Rhoades references is the only bright spot on a day on which the Nittany Lions fully surrendered to Coit and Maryland. The Nittany Lions came out on a 25-5 run over the first ten minutes of the second half, which pulled them within ten.

“This stinks, this sucks, I hate it – we all hate it,” Rhoades said. “Nobody is giving us a freebie, this is life in the Big Ten, this is how it is nowadays in this crazy landscape of college athletics when you're trying to build a program … I’ve done it at other places, some places it may take longer than ever.”

That sentiment remains bitter in the mouths of Penn State basketball fans: a program that wants to win, every moment it gets to boost morale immediately gets countered by a blowout loss.

Rhoades and Penn State played many different lineups throughout the game, including a new small-ball lineup after Ivan Jurić picked up foul trouble in the second half. It signals where this team is at: still molding, figuring itself out, and creating its new identity. But Rhoades reflected on that lineup change and how his coaching came into play.

“In our league, it’s really hard to do that,” Rhoades said. “I just didn’t think we were getting enough from the other guys. I thought Josh (Reed) was playing really hard … they weren’t playing inside-out as much, we could do that.”

A Maryland team, which struggled with its own adversity and doubts this season, showed why its team, led by Buzz Williams, is destined for greater things and the blueprint for doing so, with a passion and culture that Penn State hoops would expect to envy, as Maryland triumphed over all adversity with its versatility.

For Rhoades and Co., it’s clear there is a ceiling they’ve yet to break through, and despite moments of success, every harsh defeat and unprepared outing threatens the very foundation of the program it tries to establish in Happy Valley.

“If there’s any hits to take, I’ll take the hits; if there's any pointing fingers, point them at me,” Rhoades said. “Don't point them at the guys, they're working their butts off – they wanna win.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘I’ll take the hits’ | Mike Rhoades assesses state of program after Penn State’s loss to Maryland
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Mike Rhoades had a defeated look on his face as he sat down in the Xfinity Center media room after Penn State’s 96-73 loss to Maryland on Sunday.

The result dropped the Nittany Lions to 9-9 on the year, bringing into question if Rhoades can build a basketball program at Penn State. He gave a blunt answer when asked about the current state of the team, saying “this stinks” and “we all hate it.”

“If there's any hits to take, I'll take the hits,” Rhoades said. “If there's any pointing fingers, point them at me. Don't point them at the guys. They're working their butts off, and they're there. They want to win. They want to get after it. So it is what it is. You got to continue to move forward … So there's never going to be a day that, if I'm in charge of the program, that we're not going to try to get these guys better and push each other, telling each other the truth, and have each other's back.”

The Nittany Lions have seen close losses in conference play throughout this season, such as a 74-72 defeat to No. 2 Michigan or a 76-72 loss to No. 9 Michigan State. But the bottom line is Penn State is winless in Big Ten play, and there’s been games where the team didn’t show much, like Sunday’s game or the 113-72 loss to Indiana.

Penn State has 13 games left in the season to pick up its first win in conference play. Despite being 0-7 in Big Ten play, there’s a belief within the program in Rhoades and the Nittany Lions’ chances to rattle off some victories.

“Things happen,” guard Kayden Mingo said. “It’s basketball. There’s two sides to it. You might win some, you’re gonna lose some. And the same way we’re going on a losing streak, I feel like we could turn it around and go on a winning streak, so I got confidence in my teammates and my coaches.”

Rhoades is in Year 3 of his head coaching tenure at Penn State. While the Nittany Lions finished 16-17 in Rhoades’ first season and 16-15 last year, there were flashes of what Rhoades could build.

Notably, Penn State knocked off No. 8 Purdue and No. 12 Wisconsin during the 2024-25 season. Rhoades came to the Nittany Lions after guiding VCU to multiple NCAA Tournament appearances.

“I've done it in other places,” Rhoades said. “Some places may take a little bit longer than others, but get the right kids on board, hold them accountable to a high level, and especially when it's times like this, love them. Coach them hard. Love them harder.”

Penn State has a Big Ten Freshman of the Year contender in Kayden Mingo, among other young players who have flashed talent at times. Furthermore, the Nittany Lions are a finalist for 5-star 2026 guard Dylan Mingo, who plans to announce his college decision Thursday and would help in Rhoades’ efforts in building a program in Happy Valley.

Regardless, the Nittany Lions are still 41-41 overall and 15-32 in Big Ten play under Rhoades. Close losses have plagued Penn State, but blowout losses like Sunday won’t help its outlook with Rhoades at the helm.

“We've had pockets of good basketball. We've been close in some games,” Rhoades said. “You saw how we played those first eight minutes. We're just not mature enough and tough enough and mentally tough enough, and it starts with me. I got to keep helping these guys to find a way to get over the hump. But there's no excuses. We're not playing good enough basketball to win in the Big Ten, especially on the road.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling dominates Northwestern to finish weekend road trip
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State entered Sunday against Northwestern coming off a massive 32-3 win on the road against No. 2 Iowa. The Nittany Lions ended their weekend on the same side of the win column and extended their historic consecutive win streak in matches.

Penn State took home the victory by a score of 51-0.

174 Pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs No. 32 Eddie Enright (NU)

The match started at 174 with Levi Haines after he dominated Gabe Arnold against Iowa. The senior continued that momentum in this match against Eddie Enright.

Haines recorded the only points in the opening period to grab the 3-0 lead. Haines added two more takedowns in the second period and started to tire out Enright.

Haines continued to maintain control on the mat, extending his lead to 16-4, only allowing Enright to gain points by escaping. Haines got the tech fall-victory, 19-4.

Penn State leads 5-0.

184 Pounds: No. 4 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs JD Perez (NU)

Rocco Welsh started on the attack with a takedown in the opening 30 seconds of the match. Welsh continued to build off his momentum after defeating No. 1 Angelo Ferrari against Iowa, as the Ohio State transfer ended the first period on top, 12-5.

JD Perez secured the Wildcats first takedown of the match, but Welsh went right to work after, garnering two more takedowns in the second period.

Welsh got the tech fall 22-7 and extended Penn State’s lead 10-0.

197 Pounds: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs Alex Smith (NU)

Since coming back from injury Josh Barr has been on a tear, going undefeated so far this season.

Barr was in control for the entire match and pinned Alex Smith with 1:10 left in the first period.

Penn State leads 16-0.

285 Pounds: No. 13 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs Gabe Christenson (NU)

Cole Mirasola opened the match with a takedown in the opening 10 seconds and continued to get several takedowns in the first period.

The redshirt freshman looked quicker than Gabe Christenson and used that to his advantage.

Mirasola got the tech fall with 19 seconds left in the first period 19-4 and extended the lead to 21-0.

125 Pounds: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs No. 26 Dedrick Navarro (NU)

Luke Lilledahl and Dedrick Navarro wrestled pretty evenly in the first period with Lilledahl ahead 3-1, but in the second period Lilledahl started to pull away.

Lilledahl garnered two more takedowns in the middle period to extend his lead to 9-3. Lilledahl was the quicker wrestler and continued to maintain control of the match as it went on.

The St. Charles, Missouri, native secured the takedown late with a 20-6 victory.

Penn State leads 26-0.

133 Pounds: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs No. 24 Sean Spidle (NU)

Marcus Blaze was the only wrestler to secure a takedown, but neither wrestler was able to do much. Sean Spidle displayed solid defense against Blaze and kept it close, 3-1.

Blaze earned the only points of the second period, yet Spidle had the biggest chance to earn a takedown. Spidle had Blaze’s leg, but was never able to get the freshman to the ground.

Blaze started to take control in the third period with three takedowns to get the major decision, 15-4.

Penn State leads 30-0.

141 Pounds: No. 7 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs No. 32 Billy Dekraker (NU)

The match started pretty evenly until there was 20 seconds left in the opening period. Braeden Davis got a takedown and four near falls.

Billy Dekraker couldn’t find a way to get any points on the board, despite having a few opportunities.

Davis got the major decision, 9-0. Penn State leads 34-0.

149: Pounds: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs August Hibler (NU)

Shayne Van Ness seemed comfortable the entire match against August Hibler. The junior secured two takedowns and seemed to be on top the entire first period.

Van Ness garnered two more takedowns and four near fall points in the middle frame. Van Ness secured the riding time right as the third period began.

Penn State leads 39-0

157 Pounds: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs Gunner Myers (NU)

PJ Duke started the match with a takedown and never took his foot off the pedal. After review, Duke got the takedown erased as he never separated from Gunner Myers.

The freshman then secured the pin with 18 seconds left in the first period.

165 Pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs Nobody

Northwestern forfeited this match.

Penn State wins 51-0.

title: Former Penn State TE Tyler Warren selected to Pro Bowl
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former Penn Stater is headed to his first Pro Bowl in his first NFL season.

Indianapolis Colts tight end Tyler Warren was selected to the 2026 Pro Bowl.

Warren finished his rookie year with 817 yards and four touchdowns after being selected 14th overall in the 2025 NFL Draft.

The former Nittany Lion replaces Las Vegas Raiders’ tight end Brock Bowers on the AFC Pro Bowl roster after Bowers was shut down for the season due to a lingering knee injury.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball fails to record first Big Ten win, falls to Rutgers in nail-biter
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s basketball returned to Rec Hall on Sunday to take on Rutgers for its White Out and THON game. The matchup guaranteed someone their first Big Ten win.

The Lady Lions failed to earn their first Big Ten win, falling 76-72.

“We’ll continue to fight and figure out a way to get this team confident and finish out a fourth quarter,” coach Carolyn Kieger said.

Penn State’s Gracie Merkle took on Rutgers’ Imani Lester for the opening tip that found Tèa Clèante to give the Lady Lions first possession.

The Scarlet Knights got off to a quick start, shooting 4-for-6 from field-goal range to take an early 10-5 lead. However, Merkle got Penn State two points from the foul line, and Kiyomi McMiller nailed back-to-back buckets from inside the paint to give the Lady Lions their first lead of the game against her former team.

Rutgers didn’t back down, as the Scarlet Knights went on an 8-0 run to take an 18-11 lead with just under four minutes to play in the opening frame.

Both teams kept trading baskets through the final minutes, but Rutgers had the upper hand to end the frame with a 22-17 lead.

About a minute in the second quarter, Moriah Murray got the scoring started with a foul-line jumper. It was quickly matched with a layup from Lester on the other end.

Rutgers exploded for a 7-0 run to take a 10-point lead with just under seven minutes left in the quarter, but Viktoria Ranisavlijevic picked the Lady Lions up with a four-point play.

Penn State wouldn’t let up as a three-pointer from McMiller and a layup from Vitória Santana cut the Scarlet Knights’ lead to 31-28.

Down by five, McMiller went at three Rutgers players inside the paint and completed the and-1 to make it a two-point game.

Both teams went cold for two minutes, but Santana stripped the ball from Faith Blackstone and was fouled after the play. The senior guard went to the line for two with a chance to tie the game, but missed the first.

The foul-shooting woes continued for the Lady Lions as Ranisavlijevic went 1-for-2 from the line to put the blue and white at 6-for-10 on the day and give the Scarlet Knights a 35-33 lead.

“We shot better from the floor, but not the free-throw line and not the three,” Kieger said. “I thought that was the big difference today.”

Rutgers had a shot at the buzzer to extend its lead, but Kennedy Brandt’s three-point attempt circled the rim and fell out.

Penn State opened up the second half, scoring four-straight points to take its first lead since the opening quarter and cause a Rutgers timeout.

The timeout didn’t slow the Lady Lions down as two defensive plays from Clèante led to four points on the offensive end.

Tied at 45 with five minutes to go in the frame, McMiller found McFadden on a cut to the basket to give the freshman her sixth points of the quarter. Penn State didn’t hold the lead for long as Brandt nailed a three on the other end.

Merkle went 1-for-2 from the foul line on the other end to make it a tie contest once again.

Penn State held a 52-50 lead with just over a minute to play in the quarter, Merkle fouled Lester to give the Scarlet Knights a chance to even the score. Lester missed both, and a rebound by McMiller found its way to Murray for a three-pointer on the other end.

Swann made a jumper in the final seconds for Rutgers, but the Lady Lions held a 55-52 lead heading into the final frame.

The Scarlet Knights started with the ball, and a quick foul by Maggie Mendelson sent Blackstone to the line, where she made both.

After a layup from Merkle, Rutgers scored four-straight points to gain a one-point lead, forcing a Penn State timeout.

The Scarlet Knights continued a 7-0 scoring run to take a 61-57 lead, but were finally slowed down by consecutive two-pointers from McMiller and Merkle.

“We had only given up three offensive rebounds going into the fourth and they ended up with 11,” Kieger said. “So it comes back down to toughness. We did a great job of taking care of the ball, but it goes back to being tough and finishing the possession.”

Both teams traded baskets over the next three minutes. With Rutgers holding onto a 66-64 lead, its leading scorer, Nene Ndiaye, recorded an and-one to make it a five-point game.

After a free throw from Merkle and back-to-back layups from Lester, Rutgers held a 73-65 lead with just over two minutes left to play.

With about 34 seconds left, the Scarlet Knights led 75-70 and had possession under their own basket. Following a shot-clock violation, the Lady Lions had 25 seconds to score two baskets.

McMiller drove to the basket for two points and only five seconds ticked off the clock. Coming out of a timeout, Shaelyn Steele fouled Ivey before Rutgers could inbound the ball. Ivey missed the first and made the second, making the score 76-72 with 20.7 seconds left.

Murray and Clèante both got three-point looks for the Lady Lions, but it wasn’t enough as time ticked away.

Injury Report

Amiya Evans was listed as out for Penn State.

Up Next

The Lady Lions will start their West Coast trip with a contest against Washington at 9 p.m. Wednesday.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball drops to 9-9, 0-7 in Big Ten following blowout loss to Maryland
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
COLLEGE PARK, Md. — After losing four-in-a-row, Penn State ventured south to Maryland to take on the Terrapins on Sunday.

When it rains, though, it pours. The Nittany Lions remain winless in conference play after suffering an embarrassing 96-73 loss to Maryland.

To kick things off at the XFINITY Center, Ivan Jurić won the opening tipoff, which led to a Kayden Mingo three-pointer. Despite sporting a mask around his eyes and nose, Mingo’s vision didn’t look restricted at all in the early running.

David “Diggy” Coit, coming off a 30 point performance against USC, was up to 11 points within the first four minutes of the game after knocking down two three-pointers that pushed Maryland ahead to a 16-13 lead.

“When good players get going early in the game, they have career nights,” Mike Rhoades said about Coit. “We let him get going early. Good players, they get going early, that’s what happens.”

Another look from downtown, this time from Freddie Dilione V, tightened the gap for Penn State as it cut the deficit to 21-18 with 13 minutes left in the first half.

The long-ball had been the story of the game, still in the early stages, as Maryland’s Elijah Saunders knocked one down to make it an eight-point game. It was his second of the day, while Coit was 3-3 from three-point range.

The Terrapins seized a 33-21 lead on a Darius Adams drive that forced the blue and white to use a timeout in an effort to regroup after facing its first substantial deficit.

It was all Maryland with just five minutes to play in the first half when the Terrapins extended their lead to 18 points after yet another three-pointer, this time from Isaiah Watts.

Penn State had no answer to the volume shooting, as it was draining just 25% of its three-pointers while the Terrapins were knocking down 67%.

With the game slowly slipping away from them, a visibly frustrated Mike Rhoades and the Nittany Lions took to the locker room at halftime, facing a hefty 56-26 disadvantage – The most points Maryland has ever scored in the first half of a Big Ten game.

Coit put up 30 points against the Trojans his last time out, but reached that mark in the first half alone after going 6-8 from three-point range.

Penn State opened up the scoring in the second half, though, with a Dominick Stewart three-pointer that was really just for pride at that point, as the Terrapins immediately responded.

At the first media timeout of the second half, around the 16-minute mark, Maryland was out-rebounding Penn State 27-13, with Mingo leading the blue and white with three boards.

A Josh Reed steal and score cut the lead to 60-46, but there wasn’t a ton of belief in the XFINITY Center that his basket would turn it around for the blue and white.

“We knew that we were going to go on a run, and that’s what we did,” Reed said. “We tried to maintain it, but stuff happens; they made shots. But, coming out the second half with a lot of energy, we know that’s how we have to play from here on out.”

Another Stewart triple gave him 13 points on the day and made it a 12 point game, but there was a lot more work to do with just over 11 minutes left to play.

After being down 30 points at the half, the Nittany Lions worked it back down to just a 10 point game, only for the Terrapins to silence them and grab a 19 point lead thanks to scoring efforts from Saunders and Solomon Washington.

The two teams traded scores the next few possessions, with Eli Rice hitting a three-pointer of his own and Coit notching his 35th point of the game as Maryland went up 79-58.

“Hey, you suck” chants rang out from inside the XFINITY Center after the Terrapins pushed their lead to 25 points with just about four minutes remaining, thanks to another Coit three-pointer, which gave him 43 on the day – a new career-high.

“We’ve had some tough spells this year of just letting some guys get off and get going, and David did that,” Rhoades said. “I thought he was going to score 100 points today.”

Some more scoring came here and there, but Maryland mostly played keep-away as time drained down and captured a 96-73 victory.

Injury Report

Penn State’s standout freshman Kayden Mingo was listed as “questionable” while recovering from a broken nose. However, Mingo was back in the starting lineup, but with a mask around his eyes and nose.

Freddie Dilione V was also listed as “questionable” with an ankle injury, but played, though less than usual.

Tibor Mirtič was again sidelined with a knee injury. Mirtič will “be out for a little bit” as his knee is “just rehabbing.”

Up Next

The Nittany Lions look to snap their five-game losing streak when they host Wisconsin on Thursday for the annual “Return to Rec” game inside Penn State’s historic Rec Hall.

Scheduled tipoff is set for 7 p.m.

title: Penn State College Republicans host third annual Pennsylvania Collegiate Leadership Conference
author: Sara O'Connell | The Daily Collegian
description:
On Friday and Saturday, the Penn State College Republicans hosted its third annual Pennsylvania Collegiate Leadership Conference in the HUB-Robeson Center.

Throughout the conference, the Penn State College Republicans offered a variety of speakers, including elected officials, Turning Point USA members, students and other political activists, part of efforts to introduce conservative principles throughout the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

Hunter Steach, the Penn State College Republicans’ vice president, said the goals of the conference were civic engagement and creating a safe place for those with conservative and liberal ideologies alike to attend.

Steach said he wanted to allow attendees to meet with speakers, such as Glenn Thompson and Stacy Garrity, to gain insight into conservative perspectives.

Mia Humphreys, the Penn State College Republicans’ director of special events, said the event offered community building for conservatives to portray their ideas, goals and values.

In Glenn Thompson’s speech, he said principles and values define each person. He offered insight into his values as a Congressman by offering advice to potential future political leaders.

“Always try to listen twice as much as you speak — that's a true leader,” Thompson said.

Brooke Phillips, a former member of the Penn State College Republicans, said that by listening and working together, real understanding and progress can happen.

“Conservative principles support open discussion and civil discourse,” Phillips said. “We shouldn’t avoid these difficult conversations.”

Throughout the conference, the Penn State College Republicans and their speakers presented conservative perspectives on various political topics. Ideas on how to combat issues — such as defending the republic by exploring ways to counter immigration flaws and a debate over U.S. policy regarding Venezuela to gain attendees' perspectives — were also presented.

“Each side should be given the opportunity to express their views calmly, without attacking, while seeking common ground and shared goals,” Phillips said.”

Phillips, a Penn State alumna, said she values learning from other people and believes disagreement doesn’t have to prevent cooperation.

“I’ve had a lot of people in my time here, from [a range] of political ideologies that feel afraid to share their beliefs,” Steach, a fourth-year studying political science, said. “This conference enables people who have a dream in politics or not politics, and something in this realm, [to] chase them.”

Humphreys said the topics were intended to rally people together and enhance perspectives by standing up for beliefs and allowing attendees to speak their truth.

“We’re trying to continue free speech and free narrative on college campuses today,” Humphreys, a second-year studying political science, said.

Penn State ranked 228 in a College Pulse Free Speech ranking in 2024 and again in 2025. The ranking detailed students’ comfort expressing their ideas, as well as their tolerance for liberal and conservative speakers.

Despite the ranking, Penn State is considered to have a balanced ratio among conservative and liberal students.

“The climate here is great,” Humphreys said. “We have a great relationship with the College Dems. We work together. We do our 9/11 event together. Overall, Penn State does a better job of allowing all of us to have a voice compared to other college stories we may have heard of.”

Steach said he always felt safe and respected at Penn State regarding his political beliefs and affiliation.

The growth of the College Republicans has gone from roughly three chapters to twenty-plus chapters connecting over the past three years, according to Steach.

“A lot of college students sometimes aren’t politically engaged at all,” Humphreys said. “They don’t go to the polls and vote, and that’s ultimately what’s most important.”

She said the conference was meant to spread the word regarding conservative thought and get attendees involved to become more politically active.

Steach said he wanted people to feel more confident and comfortable sharing their beliefs after attending the conference.

“We are a diverse community here at Penn State,” Phillips said. “Exposure to differing perspectives allows students to form their own opinions and develop skills to engage respectfully.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: McKenna, Smith combine for six points in No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey’s victory
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Gavin McKenna and Jackson Smith entered the season with higher expectations than most — a fitting narrative surrounding two of the NHL’s top prospects.

For the first half of the season, their low scoring production had undermined an otherwise impressive start to their collegiate careers. But McKenna and Smith have found their stride, and their combined six points in Penn State’s 6-3 victory over Notre Dame on Saturday signaled a fitting arrival.

After JJ Wiebusch opened the scoring 17 seconds into the contest, Smith received a pass near the blue line and ripped a slap shot past Nicholas Kempf to double his team’s lead.

A SMITTY BOMB!! 💣#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/HblaTfUhX1— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 18, 2026

“I saw it was open for the (DiMarsico), and once you see the pass coming, your head is buried, and you're just trying to hit the net,” Smith said. “(I just) threw it there, and it happened to go in.”

The tally marked Smith’s sixth goal and 12th point of the season. But the freshman defenseman wasn’t done.

After Notre Dame scored twice in 15 seconds to tie the contest, Smith sped up the right side before crossing a pass to McKenna, who sniped a snap shot into the top corner to give Penn State a 3-2 advantage.

Great Pass, Better Finish!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/jeK7qcf3dm— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 18, 2026

In a spot he might’ve considered an extra pass in the past, McKenna set his sights on scoring. And his aggression paid off.

“This season, I've kind of been passing up on some shots,” McKenna said. “In this game, they wanted me to shoot the puck, and it worked a couple of times.”

With the Fighting Irish threatening in the third period, the 18-year-old forward found a loose puck and snapped it home to give the Nittany Lions a two-goal cushion. As the goal horn blared, he skated on one knee to the blue and pumped his arm multiple times in a rare display of emotion.

I think the kid is enjoying college hockey!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/YGPpJp0vhM— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 18, 2026

McKenna had earned his first multi-goal game as a Nittany Lion. But his increased aggression was the true story.

The freshman forward sports impressive vision. He can see passes that others can’t. He can envision plays before they develop. And while McKenna’s unselfishness creates scoring chances for others, he sometimes becomes too passive — a play style he altered in Saturday’s contest.

“(McKenna) wanted to shoot the puck right from the get-go. And I appreciate that,” Gadowsky said. “I appreciate that he's such a team guy. He wants to get everybody involved, and he would much rather set up a teammate for a goal and get one himself, but it was nice to see him get a little hungry to shoot the puck.”

The freshman duo, which earned the first and second stars of the game, contributed to Penn State’s final goal — an empty-net tally scored by captain Dane Dowiak. It marked a fitting end to a game dominated by two stars who had endured and overcome difficult adjustments to Division I hockey.

And for Smith, who tallied a career-best three points and finished as a plus-two, it signaled a newfound comfort level in Big Ten play.

“(Smith) looks comfortable, doesn’t he?” Gadowsky said with a smile. “He is just an absolute thoroughbred the way he skates, the way he handles the puck, the way he sees, the way he shoots. Every single weekend, he gets a little more comfortable. I think he's just playing awesome hockey.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State posts two first-place finishes at West Point Open
author: Jimmy Blair | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following their 26th team victory at the West Point Open, the Nittany Lions looked to continue the momentum in the individual finals on Saturday night.

The blue and white featured two first-place finishes on the night, alongside seven podium placements.

Floor

On the floor, Kellen Ryan posted the first event win on the night for the blue and white, topping the table with a 13.400. Michael Artlip came up just behind his teammate, as a score of 13.150 slotted him into second place.

Bars

Army’s Noah Duran took the top spot in the parallel bars with a score of 13.300. Artlip continued his strong night with his second podium finish, placing second with a 13.000. Landon Simpson took his lone podium finish in third with a 12.800.

Penn State couldn’t find the same success on the high bar, with William and Mary’s Luke Tully taking first with a 13.150. Artlip posted a 12.650, which was good for fifth place. Kacper Garnczarek was just behind in seventh position with an 11.950.

Pommel horse

Maddox Pabellon for Army took the top spot in the pommel horse with a 14.200. Simpson placed sixth for the blue and white with a 13.150, with Garnczarek right behind in seventh with a 13.000.

Rings

Just like the night before, the Nittany Lions dominated the still rings. Luke Esparo claimed the second first-place finish of the night for the blue and white. The junior posted a huge 13.900, putting him above Karsikas and Matthew Underhill, who both tied for second with a 13.000 for both of them.

Vault

Ryan continued his impressive night with a second-place result on the Vault, with a score of 13.800, giving him his second podium on the night. Shaun Smith matched Ryan’s score, giving him a podium finish as well.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions hit the road to Sarasota, Florida, to compete in the Sam Mikulak Invitational on Saturday, January 24th, against Big Ten foe Illinois, as well as other local clubs.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

Wide receiver Anthony Ivey has committed to San Jose State, he announced Sunday via X.

COMMITTED 💙💛 #AllSpartans @SanJoseStateFB @BRayStutzmann @CoachStutzmann pic.twitter.com/a1Z6gOhmqX— Anthony Ivey (@AnthonyIvey16) January 18, 2026

title: ‘It takes a lot of guts and bravery’ | ASA holds 13th annual Mr., Miss Africa Pageant
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Heritage Hall came alive with music and dance Saturday evening as the African Students Association (ASA) held its 13th annual Mr. and Miss Africa pageant in the HUB-Robeson Center.

The pageant, themed “Crowned in Heritage,” saw five contestants “embody the beauty, strength and elegance” of their respective countries. Each contestant integrated elements of their culture within their entrance into Heritage Hall and during events later into the night that were observed by a panel of four judges.

The contestants also presented an issue within their country they felt a personal connection to, as well as causes currently working to solve them.

Mercy Adetoyese, ASA’s president, said she has helped set up the pageant since her freshman year and thought of the event as a way to display African culture in University Park.

“This pageant is a way for people to showcase their culture, their identity, to the rest of Penn State and, honestly, it takes a lot of guts and bravery to even be up here, so going from being a shy and timid person to being able to get up on that stage is something I also truly admire,” Adetoyese, a fourth-year studying biobehavioral health, said.

She said the pageant served as a way to show Penn State students, especially those within minority groups, that there is a supportive community for them on campus.

The pageant kicked off at 5:55 p.m. as contestants were met with applause from attendees as they entered Heritage Hall.

Rasha Elwakil, who competed as Miss Egypt to spread awareness about disability-related stigmas, said she saw the pageant as a way to step out of her comfort zone while showcasing Egyptian culture.

She said she hoped attendees left the pageant having learned about the importance of everyone’s causes, as well as the diversity of Africa.

“All of our countries, we've learned, either have some similarities that are really, really cool; they also all have a lot of differences that make all of our cultures unique,” Elwakil, a fourth-year studying geography, said. “I want them to learn more about all of us as contestants and who we are. I think we really showcase our personalities throughout this entire experience and so that's going to be really cool to showcase throughout the night and have people learn more about who we are, as well as our causes.”

Contestant Khamaal Akinwande, who competed as Mr. Nigeria and advocated for increased prostate cancer resources, said he hoped attendees would see ASA as more than just another student organization on campus.

“I hope they leave here with an interest in not just my culture, but all of the contestants' culture,” Akinwande, a first-year studying cybersecurity, said. “I hope they understand that ASA is a place where we don't just come to talk about classes or the workload or how our week is going. We come to truly engage with others, learn about our cultures and how we can cultivate those cultures to build a stronger bond between each other.”

The pageant concluded at 10 p.m. following the crowning of Ader Deng, a first-year studying cybersecurity who advocated for increased educational resources as the pageant’s first Mr. South Sudan, and Zara Amos, a first-year studying political science who advocated for ending period poverty as Miss Ghana, as Mr. and Miss Africa.

They were crowned by Wisdom Moses, ASA’s public relations chair and 2025 Mr. Africa winner.

Ian Mwaura, who travelled to University Park from Williamsport to attend the pageant, said he believed Deng’s and Amos’s victories were well deserved based on what he saw during events, such as the talent show, and the causes they presented.

“Mr. South Sudan, he did his thing, his talent definitely stood out, his principles and what he stands for also stuck out and the same thing with Miss Ghana,” Mwaura, a third-year studying heating, ventilation and air conditioning engineering technology at the Pennsylvania College of Technology, said. “Everybody talks about the problems that go on in the world but to actually make an organization at such a young age, to tackle them and get your hands dirty and do something about it, that's very commendable.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey completes series sweep over Notre Dame
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
After taking a 4-1 victory over Notre Dame in a physical, special-teams battle Friday night, No. 8 Penn State returned to Pegula Ice Arena on Saturday for a conference rematch.

Despite the Nittany Lions skating without a 12th forward or an extra skater due to a series of injuries, they held on to capture the series sweep with a 6-3 win.

The blue and white have consistently struggled to score first and do so early, but that factor was nowhere to be found on Saturday night.

To the sound of the Roar Zone’s opening chants, alternate captain Jarod Crespo found forward JJ Wiebusch as he was entering the offensive zone. At the same time, a Notre Dame defender lost an edge, leaving one of Penn State’s top producers all alone with goaltender Nicholas Kempf.

Wiebusch flicked a backhand pass over Kempf that ricocheted off both posts and in, giving the Nittany Lions an early lead.

The offensive dominance didn’t let up, and the home team added another just over six minutes later. Freshman defenseman Jackson Smith unleashed his signature slap shot from Notre Dame’s blue line to double Penn State’s early lead.

Following up Friday night’s 15 penalty night, the physicality was evident early on.

The Nittany Lions were first to the box after the officials called freshman Lev Katzin for a holding penalty, but they held off Notre Dame's top-ten-ranked power-play unit.

Just over a minute after the first penalty expired, the blue and white went right back on the penalty kill, this time after defenseman Carter Schade went to the box for hooking.

The Fighting Irish only had 17 seconds on the power play before defenseman Henry Nelson was sent to the box for interference, with the next minute and a half being 4-on-4 hockey.

As the first frame was coming to a close, Notre Dame stunned the crowd in Hockey Valley into silence when its relatively quiet offense scored two back-to-back goals just seconds apart to tie the game.

The first goal was scored by forward Brennan Ali with just 1:36 left to go in the period, and junior Cole Knuble’s goal off the rebound came just 15 seconds later, to even the score heading into the first intermission.

Penn State regained some of its initial momentum in the middle frame, and freshman Gavin McKenna was there to capitalize on it. Smith picked up his second point of the night after he found McKenna off the rush, and the forward potted his fifth of the season.

Hockey Valley’s energy matched the physicality level, and after Smith and Knuble got into it and were both given minor penalties, Pegula Ice Arena roared louder.

Another Fighting Irish penalty shortly after turned the 4-on-4 into a Nittany Lion power play. Instead of giving the blue and white an advantage, however, Notre Dame’s Sutter Muzzatti notched a shorthanded goal and tied the game for the second time.

Three back-to-back penalties through the next five minutes of play maintained the theme of the weekend of special teams battles.

After nine total penalties, the game finally saw its first power play goal. DiMarsico — who registered a hat trick on Friday night, including two goals on the power play — cleaned up a loose puck around Kempf’s crease, and retook Penn State’s lead heading into the final period.

The third period held much of the same, with a rotation of Nittany Lions and Fighting Irish skaters heading to the box, but both teams struggled to capitalize on their opportunities.

After McKenna’s initial goal, the momentum shift from the forward was evident. The top 2026 NHL draft prospect’s speed and skill provided multiple high-danger chances throughout the game, and his second of the night seemed almost inevitable.

It finally came with about nine minutes to go in the game, after the Yukon, Whitehorse native fired home a loose puck in front of Kempf’s net.

McKenna’s second of the night was followed up by an empty net goal from captain Dane Dowiak to seal the 6-3 win and series sweep for the Nittany Lions.

Up Next

Penn State begins a tough Big Ten stretch, first traveling to No. 2 Wisconsin for a 7 p.m. puck drop on Jan. 23.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field opens indoor home meets with Nittany Lion Challenge
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A month after several Nittany Lions put up top-tier performances at the Penn Opener, Bucknell Opener and Sharon Colyear-Danville Season Opener, they returned home and showcased their talents on Saturday.

Penn State welcomed 15 teams to the Horace Ashenfelter III Indoor Track for the Nittany Lion Challenge, kicking off its four home meets of the indoor season.

Sophomore Sasha Garnett kicked off the day with the women’s shot put, where she threw 14.59 meters for third place. Fellow sophomore Skye Petrie-Cameron threw just shy of Garnett, with a fourth-place throw of 14.49 meters.

Despite being a multi-event athlete, senior Maddie Pitts took the victory in the women’s long jump, jumping 5.91 meters for a new indoor personal best.

Like the shot put, junior Lizzie Schreiber finished right behind Pitts with a 5.72-meter jump for second. Junior Joe White finished second in the men’s long jump with a distance of 6.99 meters.

The Nittany Lions took the top-two places again in the men’s pole vault as Tristan McGarrah jumped a season-best 5.05 meters for first, followed by Mason Bucks’ season-best 4.75 meters for second.

Penn State earned yet another first-place finish in the women’s pole vault. Senior Amelia McBain jumped 3.75 meters for a season best.

The men’s shot put got the ball rolling for record-breaking performances for the Nittany Lions, as Ryan Henry and Dylan Lambrecht tied for first place with throws of 19.43 meters, the fifth-best in school history.

MIT transfer Sam Engebretson finished fifth with a personal-best throw of 17.62 meters.

Senior Alex Pancoast earned the fifth first-place finish of the morning for Penn State in the women’s weight throw following an 18.55-meter throw. Sophomore Gabby Cope came in third place with a personal-best 18.24-meter throw.

When the action on the track started, the Nittany Lions were just as dominant as the field. The women’s mile saw Katie Dallas, Claire Zubey, Charlotte Costich and Claire Daniels sweep the top-four places with personal bests under 4:50.

On the other hand, the men’s mile saw Penn State’s first loss in several events.

Brian DiCola and Logan Strawser finished just shy of first place, finishing in second and third with personal bests of 4:06.08 and 4:06.51, respectively.

Pitts continued her dominance in the women’s 60-meter hurdles, where she earned a fifth-place personal-best to book her ticket to the finals in 8.53 seconds. She came back and finished fourth in the finals, setting another personal best with a time of 8.50.

Despite not making the finals in the 60m hurdles, sophomore Addyson White earned her spot in the women’s 60m with a 7.69 for 10th place. Alexandria North also earned a spot in the finals in 7.71 seconds for 13th place.

White ultimately finished fifth in the finals with a 7.60, while North finished last with a personal-best 7.68.

A trio of Nittany Lions earned spots to the finals in the men’s 60m as sophomore Ajani Dwyer ran 6.55 seconds for first place — a facility record for the Horace Ashenfelter III Indoor Track — Scotty Coffi ran 6.88 seconds for second, and Lucas Band ran 6.97 seconds for ninth.

Dwyer stumbled out of the blocks during the finals, but still came through with a 6.70 for the win. Coffi finished third with a 6.78, while Band ran a personal-best 6.93 for sixth.

Freshman Boh Ritchie burst onto the scene in the women’s 600-meter, running the second-fastest time in school history to win in 1:28.21. Freshman Macey Shriner finished shortly behind in 1:32.82 for third place.

The men’s 600m saw top performances from Penn State as well, as Nebraska transfer Niko Schultz finished second with a personal-best 1:16.35, followed by Kaleb Nastari’s personal best of 1:16.89 for third.

After finishing second in the long jump, Schreiber came back and won the triple jump with a season-best 12.96-meter jump.

The men’s high jump saw the Nittany Lions continue their win streak as freshman Trip Campbell finished first with a personal-best 2.15-meter jump. Robert Allen finished in second with a season-best 2.06, followed by Tim Watson in fourth with another season-best 1.96.

The women’s high jump didn’t follow suit, however, as sophomore Hannah Riolo finished fourth with a jump of 1.73 meters.

Penn State returned to form for the men’s weight throw, as Collin Burkhart and Sam Engebretson took the top-two places with throws of 19.61 meters and 19.21 meters, respectively.

The Nittany Lions took the top-four spots of the women’s 1000-meter, led by Hayley Kitching’s NCAA record performance. Kitching finished in 2:38.45, setting a personal record, school record and NCAA record in her first race of the year.

Sarah Pickering, Ada Rand and Lea Hatcher finished in second through fourth, coming in back-to-back at 2:47.12.

The men’s 1000m saw just as much star power as the women’s, as the top-four Penn State finishers each ran in the NCAA top-10 fastest finishes.

Allon Clay led the way for first place with 2:18.09 for the Penn State record, followed by Handal Roban in second with 2:18.72 for the third-fastest in Penn State history, Yukichi Ishii’s 2:18.76 for the fourth-fastest and Nick Sloff’s 2:19.06 for the fifth-fastest.

DiCola ran his second race of the day in the men’s 800-meter, where he finished fourth with a 1:54.40. Band also ran again in the men’s 200-meter, finishing in third with 21.92.

The Nittany Lions ended the day with the 4x400-meter relay, where the women’s team earned the win. White, Mimi Duffy and Kylie Jacoutot got Penn State in second with 2:49.41 before North won the race with her 54.14-second lap.

On the other hand, the men’s squad wrapped up with a third-place finish with Joshua Stolarski, Matt DeMatteo, Luke Seymour and Jake Palermo with a time of 3:15.11.

Up next

The blue and white will travel to Philadelphia for the Penn 10 Team Elite on Jan. 24.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: State College welcomes Punxsutawney Phil during event at The Press: Cider & Craft Beverage Taphouse
author: Lily Dorf | The Daily Collegian
description:
After the excitement of the holiday season fades and students return to school to finish out the academic year, many feel as though there is nothing exciting to anticipate. However, some Pennsylvania locals — and the surrounding states — may disagree.

Groundhog Day, celebrated annually on Feb. 2 in Punxsutawney, Pa. is a cultural tradition in which a groundhog — named Punxsutawney Phil — is brought out from his burrow to predict whether winter will last for another six weeks or an early spring will arrive.

While fans typically have to travel to Punxsutawney for the event, State College residents were able to have a special chance to see the famous furry friend.

Penn State students and State College locals gathered at The Press: Cider & Craft Beverage Taphouse to meet Punxsutawney Phil and his handlers. Some attendees dressed for the occasion, wearing top hats and suits to match the groundhog’s handlers.

The event started at 2 p.m., and by 2:30 p.m., the line to see Phil and his crew was wrapped around the block.

The Press is owned by four lifelong friends, who happen to all be from Punxsutawney, Pa. One of the owners, Andrew Divelbiss, said he wanted to bring Phil to Happy Valley so he could experience life outside of Punxsutawney.

“State College is such a good town to introduce people to Phil,” Divelbiss said. “That’s a big thing that everybody in Punxsutawney tries to do is spread the incredible thing of Punxsutawney Phil.”

With the help of his family, who are a part of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club, Divelbiss said he was able to bring his family and business together through the event.

Excitement buzzed through the line as students and locals waited to see Phil and hopefully and take pictures with him.

During the event, handlers and club members handed out Punxsutawney Groundhog Club tokens and top hats.

Many attendees learned about the event online, but Sophia Balaratna said she heard through word of mouth and knew she wanted to attend.

As a Pennsylvania native, Balaratna said she grew up hearing about Punxsutawney Phil and wanted to meet him.

“I was really excited, I’m a big fan of Phil,” Balaratna, a fourth-year studying mechanical engineering said.

She left him with some encouraging words for his big day coming up, and to hopefully help get the prediction she wants to have for the seasonal weather.

“I love you Phil, but please no more winter,” Balaratna said.

Sagufta Muktadir, also a Pennsylvania native, said she knew she needed to attend the moment she read about the event.

Muktadir, a fourth-year studying biomedical engineering, said she and her family are fond of Phil, but have never traveled to Punxsutawney for Groundhog Day.

“I love him,” Muktadir said. “I love his predictions and everything — I was super hyped to come and see him in person.”

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball defeats No. 9 Lewis to move to 4-0
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
After starting the season 3-0, Penn State got a look at its first ranked team of the season, hosting No. 9 Lewis in Rec Hall.

On Saturday night, the Nittany Lions picked up their first ranked win of the season, beating the Flyers 3-1 to hand them their first loss on the season.

The first two points of the opening set the two split at 1-1 after a Penn State opening serve error that Lewis matched when it committed a mistake of the same nature.

It was all Lewis in the early running, though, as it jumped to a 7-3 advantage in the set after a few more Nittany Lion errors.

Penn State used a timeout when it went down 11-6. Only one of Lewis’s points came from a kill, as all the rest came from errant blue and white serves or attacks.

Owen Rose and Jaxon Herr gave the Nittany Lions their first lead of the night after a block assist gave them a 17-16 edge. Penn State rode that wave to the end to capture the first set 25-21 after back-to-back Sean Harvey kills.

Now one step closer to a top-10 win, Penn State got on the board first in the second set and jumped up to a 4-1 lead after back-to-back Gaige Gabriel kills and an ace from Herr.

Lewis used a timeout after the blue and white took an 11-8 advantage after a Matthew Luoma kill.

The Nittany Lions felt themselves closing in on a 2-0 lead on the night after capturing a seven-point lead in the latter stages of the second set, thanks to consecutive Flyers errors.

A Luoma kill off the assist from Herr allowed Penn State to capture the second set 25-18 to move one set closer to a sweep over a top-10 team.

Once again, Penn State started the action due to a Lewis error. It was the Flyers’ 12th attack error of the night.

For the first time in a while, though, the Nittany Lions found themselves down and facing a 5-2 deficit thanks to Oguzhan Oguz picking up his sixth and seventh kills of the night – the most of any Flyer at that point.

Another Gaige kill was just another point Penn State traded with Lewis until an 8-8 standstill turned into a two-point lead for the Flyers, thanks to a Gauthier Brozak kill that he followed up with an ace.

Lewis extended its lead to 15-13 before a Tristan Hassell kill made it a one-point game that Penn State capitalized on and turned into a little scoring run, as it captured a 16-15 lead thanks to a Brozak error and a Gaige ace.

Inching closer to a win, the blue and white snuck up to 20-18 after another Harvey kill – his 10th of the night.

The Flyers weren’t going away that easily, though, and Penn State took a timeout after a 3-0 Lewis scoring run put the Nittany Lions down 21-20.

After some more back-and-forth, Lewis did just enough to win the third set 25-23 and keep the night going after a Daniel Haber kill.

Following the rest of the night, the fourth set started off tight until the Flyers jumped out to a 5-3 lead in the early running after kills from Brozak and Haber.

Consecutive Hassell kills gave him six on the night, but Lewis was still comfortably ahead, holding a 12-7 advantage prior to the Nittany Lions calling a timeout.

It was all Hassell as Penn State was closing in on the lead after the six-foot-six freshman picked up his eighth kill to cut the deficit to 16-13.

The Nittany Lions battled back and went on a 3-0 run, with Hassell picking up two more kills to gain a 23-21 edge.

Momentum shifted back the other way for a moment, but Penn State held on and captured the fourth set 25-22 to secure the 3-1 win.

Up Next

Penn State hits the road for the first time this season for a two-game series against McKendree next weekend. Friday’s match is set for 7 p.m., while Saturday’s is scheduled for 2 p.m.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Janecke’s two-goal effort secures No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey series sweep over Syracuse
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State got itself back on track following its first loss in the AHA to Mercyhurst with a 4-1 victory over conference-opponent Syracuse in Game 1. The Nittany Lions returned to Tennity Ice Pavilion in Syracuse, New York, on Saturday afternoon for Game 2 of the series, looking for their first sweep since late November.

Unlike the previous meetings with the Orange, Penn State was given a run for its money, gritting out a 3-2 victory behind a pair of goals by captain Tessa Janecke. The Nittany Lions improved to 21-4 on the season, and secured the season-sweep over Syracuse.

Goaltender Maddy Campbell was given her fifth-straight start for the blue and white, in Katie DeSa’s absence due to an undisclosed injury. The Courtice, Ontario, native made 13 saves on 14 shots in Friday’s victory before closing out the series with 31 saves on 33 shots on Saturday, improving to 5-2 on the season.

The teams jumped out of the gates with blazing speed, with the Nittany Lions getting play started when Abby Stonehouse and McKenna Walsh were stopped at the crease on a 2-on-1. The Orange’s Jackson Kinsler responded with a breakaway that was stopped by Campbell.

But Kinsler’s next attempt broke the ice. Just over three minutes into the game, the Madison, Wisconsin, native picked up her own rebound and beat Campbell under her glove.

However, the AHA-leading Nittany Lions didn’t stay down for long. Grace Outwater floated a backhand shot past freshman goaltender Ava Drabyk to tie the game, with 14:10 left in the period.

The blue and white’s powerplay got to work midway through the first period, when Emma Gnade tripped Janecke in the offensive zone. Janecke responded 23 seconds into the advantage, striding down the left side boards before cutting to the middle and firing a wrist shot past Drabyk to take a 2-1 lead.

Just over five minutes into the second period, the Orange were awarded their first power-play opportunity as Grace Tullock headed to sin bin for tripping. Maya D’Arcy ensured that the special teams remained perfect, as she tallied her first of the season 30-seconds later to tie the game at 2-2.

With 11:25 remaining in the middle frame, Celia Wiegand’s interference infraction gave the Nittany Lions their second power play of the game. However, Drabyk made a series of saves in tight to keep the game knotted.

The penalty box was again populated as Mya Vaslet took a boarding penalty in the offensive zone. Syracuse peppered Campbell with shots, but the Nittany Lions cleared the penalty after sending the puck down the length of the ice.

Following a back-and-forth affair in Penn State’s zone, the Nittany Lions cleared the puck to Janecke, who entered the zone with speed. She made a nifty move to the slot before rifling a shot under Drabyk’s globe for her 16th goal of the season, now leading the blue and white.

Despite applying offensive pressure early in the third period, the officials called Penn State’s Maddy Christian to the penalty box for interference. The blue and white easily cleared the penalty, but struggled to generate offense throughout the early goings of the frame.

That was until Heidi Knoll took a tripping penalty right off a face-off outside of Penn State’s zone. Although the Nittany Lions weren’t able to find the net, they shaved valuable time off the clock.

The blue and white continued to dominate the possession, winding down the clock with an intense forecheck. Syracuse was unable to pull Drabyk until the 48-second mark, leading to the Orange having limited time to tie the game.

The blue and white cleared the puck with one second remaining, and Campbell made a final save to secure the 3-2 victory.

Injury Report

Senior goaltender Katie DeSa has remained out with an undisclosed injury since Jan. 2, when she was shaken up midway through the third period against No. 2 Ohio State.

Up Next

Penn State will stay in the state of New York, travelling to Ithaca to face No. 10 Cornell for the second time this season. The Nittany Lions previously beat the Big Red, 1-0, on Dec. 30.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Allon Clay breaks 1000m record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another event, another record broken by Penn State.

Graduate runner Allon Clay ran a 2:18.09 in the men's 1000-meter to break the Nittany Lion school record at the Nittany Lion Challenge.

BIG FOUR IN THE 1K🦁Allon, Handal, Yuki, and Nick each post times in the NCAA all-time top 10 in the 1K!🥇| 2:18.09 | Clay🥈| 2:18.72 | Roban🥉| 2:18.76 | Ishii4 | 2:19.06 | Sloff #WeAre #PSUTF pic.twitter.com/GircBQMXbS— Penn State Track & Field/Cross Country (@PennStateTFXC) January 17, 2026

Clay's time broke the 2:18.26 record set by Brannon Kidder in 2016.

Clay missed out on the 2025 Indoor NCAA Championship after his 800-meter finish at the Big Ten Championship, but redeemed himself in the outdoor championship, booking his ticket to the national meet.

title: Penn State track and field's Hayley Kitching breaks 1000m record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Hayley Kitching is in the Penn State record books again.

The Australian mid-distance runner ran a 2:38.45 in the women's 1000-meter at the Nittany Lion Challenge, breaking the school and NCAA record.

HISTORY IN HAPPY VALLEY‼️Hayley Kitching breaks the 1K collegiate record with a 2:38.45!#WeAre #PSUTF pic.twitter.com/TuXlZCNOzO— Penn State Track & Field/Cross Country (@PennStateTFXC) January 17, 2026

Kitching's time broke a program record previously held by Danae Rivers in 2019, who later won an NCAA championship that year.

The senior runner now has three records in Happy Valley, including the women's 1000m, indoor women's 800-meter and outdoor women's 800m.
