title: Savory and sweet | A review of Honeygrow
author: Veronica Figg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A new spot for stir-frys, salads and honey-based desserts recently opened it’s doors in State College. The Philadelphia-based restaurant chain Honeygrow is now located at 160 E Beaver Ave from 10:30 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

This week, I decided to go and try some of the new spot’s options, and to find a dish that might “wok” your world.

Stir-Fry

I chose to order Honeygrow’s seasonal Miso Garlic stir-fry noodles. The dish includes egg white noodles, roasted chicken, miso corn, caramelized onions, shaved parmesan, chives and Umami miso sauce. I chose to remove the shaved parmesan.

The dish was very good and had a great Umami profile. The noodles were cooked perfectly — not too soft or soggy from the sauce.

The chicken was juicy and was not dry at all. The Umami profile came into play when the sauce mixed with the individual flavors of the chicken, corn and onions, making them a powerful combination.

The caramelized onions were tangy and crunchy, giving a needed sharpness to the sweet corn. The noodles, corn and onions together created a rich, tangy and sweet balance that — when mixed with the chicken — created the Umami flavor the dish strives for, tasting savory and comforting.

The chives were sprinkled on top and I mixed them in to add to the flavor profile. Unfortunately, the taste of the chives was overpowered by the garlic in the sauce.

I would have liked to have tasted the chives more clearly so they could have added some more tang to the dish.

Rating: 8/10

Dessert

I ordered a create-your-own Honeybar for dessert, and chose clover honey, apples, grapes, blueberries, strawberries and granola as my toppings.

This dessert was delicious. I ate the whole thing and would really recommend it.

Clover honey is sweet and was the highlight of the dessert. It made the multiple flavors of the fruits really pop.

The granola was crunchy and a great juxtaposition for the sweetness of the strawberries and tanginess of the blueberries, making for a great flavor combination.

The grapes were a great addition to the dessert that added a unique flavor which complimented the other fruits.

The apples were crunchy and sweet, and — when paired with the grapes — went great with the honey. All of the fruits tasted fresh and no part of the dessert was dry.

Rating: 10/10

Veronica’s Food Sensitivity Corner

As a student who was recently diagnosed with a dairy sensitivity, I am always on the lookout for foods that fit my new dietary needs and am aware there are other students who may have similar needs as well.

Honeygrow does offer vegan dishes like the Red Coconut Curry Stir-Fry, or Gluten-free items on their menu including the Loaded Greek Salad and OG Cobb Salad.

At Honeygrow, all dishes on the menu can be modified to remove ingredients, and you can also create your own stir-fry, salad or honeybar and customize it.

As with any food establishment, please inform a service worker if you have any food allergies.

Overall, I would recommend Honeygrow to anyone who misses a home-cooked meal of the noodle variety, and for any student that needs a sweet treat after a long day of classes.

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: 5 Songs to Get You Through the Winter Blues
author: Brennan Kramp I The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s a random Wednesday during the frigid January winter in Happy Valley. You step out of your class building and get hit with a gust of wind to the face followed by a trek through the flurry of snow to the library under an endlessly grey sky.

The sun becomes a celebrity — making rare and treasured appearances. In times like these, it’s best to put on some headphones, crank up some music and escape the seasonal depression for a few brief minutes.

Here are some tunes to play to get you through the day and put a little more pep in your step as you hunker through the winter.

“Like A Rolling Stone” by Bob Dylan

Arguably Dylan’s biggest hit of his career, “Like A Rolling Stone” is a bitter sweet story about a once-rich woman who loses everything and finds herself — as Dylan would put it — rolling through life like a stone.

Sure, a bummer topic for a song, but the production, ensemble and groovy tempo of it make you want to shake into a dance no matter where you’re walking. A fitting song for a gloomy mood as the juxtaposition of the lyrics and the production of the track make for a comedically ironic vibe that is sure to boost your spirits.

“Drive” by Incubus

Incubus’ “Drive” is a much slower tune, but the true uplifting power comes from the lyrics. A fabulous song about regaining control of your life and finding the empowerment behind that act.

Lead singer Brandon Boyd lays a blanket of warmth over your soul as he belts out the lyrics to the chorus, “whatever tomorrow brings, I’ll be there, with open arms and open eyes.” Best played on the bus or car ride home after a long day, “Drive” will give you a comforting sense of security in yourself to keep pushing through the dreary days of winter.

“Let’s Go Crazy” by Prince

Switching tracks and putting you in a free and easy mood is the iconic opener to Prince’s “Purple Rain” album, “Let’s Go Crazy.” This killer track opens with a monologue from the eccentric lead singer, talking about “the afterworld, a world of never-ending happiness.” In this world, “you can always see the sun, day or night.”

The true message of this song is simply, if the world is bringing you down, just let loose and find a way to have a good time — ignore everything else and just be alive. The snow and the wind won’t stand a chance to bring you down with this tune bumping between your ears.

“Sweater Weather” by The Neighbourhood

An early 2010’s hit where the music alone immediately throws you back to the wonderful winter days of elementary school, while keeping you in the present to take a moment to appreciate how many winters have passed and how you’ve survived all of them.

A truly creative and embracing song on all levels that carries the vibe of a gloomy winter night to help you embrace — yes — the sweater weather. Layered on top of that is a lyrical composition that will also take your mind away from whatever it is that has you down that day, as you hear a tale of two lovers cherishing each other during a similarly rough patch.

“I Gotta Feeling” by The Black Eyed Peas

Rounding out this list is a pure nostalgia hit for anyone working through their years at State College. “I Gotta Feeling” is sure to remind you of the upcoming good vibes of spring and summer that lay ahead.

This 2000’s radio banger exudes positivity, enthusiasm and eager excitment, with the trio preaching, “tonight’s gonna be a good night,” and just like with Incubus’ “Drive,” you truly feel that sense of confidence in the thought tonight will in fact be a good night, no matter the blizzards of assignments you have to go through.

Lyrics aside, the production on this track just puts you in a party mood — wanting to bust out dancing and grooving along to the fun and energetic tune. A choice pick for the mid-day grind that will hit you like a double shot of espresso between the ears.

MORE BLOGS

title: Penn State women’s gymnastics heads to Champaign to take on Illinois
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hits the road this Friday for an away meet, kicking off its Big Ten schedule, taking on Illinois. The Nittany Lions were in Rec Hall this past Sunday and tested the waters by testing various rotation lineups against Yale, which proved successful and resulted in a win.

The Nittany Lions rank well entering week 2, obtaining the No. 17 spot, while the Fighting Illini hold the No. 35 spot. Illinois finished second in the Border Battle Quad Meet, coming in close to first-place, Iowa.

Penn State looks confident in its ability to secure some big points right off the bat, with a slew of well-rounded talent to play around with. Penn State brought in an arsenal of new talent this season, and it can begin to move around.

Fresh faces like Kayla Bender, who excels on the balance beam, round out some of the struggles that the blue and white saw on the event last season. Freshman Lizzy Ryan could be a great addition as an all-around competitor, adding to the capabilities of Kalea McElligot and Elizabeth Leary, who were strong all-around athletes in the 2025 season.

The floor is looking like the event that will define this Fighting Illini and Nittany Lion meet, with 2025 season scores on the floor being high on both sides. Illinois enters the Big Ten season with high 9.800 scores for multiple athletes, with some reaching that 9.900 mark. Penn State is right up there with the Fighting Illini, with most of its roster scoring a high 9.800.

Vault appears to be a weak spot for Illinois, struggling to put up 2025 season high scores above 9.7500, and the rotation wasn't as successful as it had hoped during the Border Battle Quad Meet. The Nittany Lions put a heavy focus on vault, and they managed to get a good set of numbers after their rotation on Sunday.

Penn State’s meet with Yale showed Dani Latronica as a possibility for multiple events, starting off strong across vault, bar and beam. Ellie Monahan and Allison Kaempfer are both great options for the Nittany Lions to cover all their bases on Friday, with Monahan scoring well on beam and floor and Kaempfer holding it down on vault and bars.

As for the Fighting Illini, Chloe Cho showed out in their quad meet, scoring over 9.800 across the board. Bars also seem to be a focus for Illinois, with multiple 9.800 and higher scores after week one.

Mareli Muller is also a strong all-around athlete for the Fighting Illini, but she was missing from competition last week. If she joins the team again on Friday, she could be a really powerful aspect of the lineup. Being a great all-around gymnast, she can really excel and be a reason for the Nittany Lions to worry.

Illinois, similar to Penn State, has great depth and new talent entering the 2026 season, especially Callie Kauffman, a freshman who was a four-time level 10 regional qualifier and proved her abilities during week one.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Ways to celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King’s legacy in State College
author: Rubi Orellana | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is celebrating Martin Luther King Jr. with a series of events honoring his legacy of service, social justice and community.

From service projects to panels, students and community members are invited to celebrate King’s legacy and take meaningful action together.

Monday, January 19

MLK Day of Service

Students are invited to join the MLK Jr. Day of Service from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m. in the HUB-Robeson Center. The event honors King’s legacy by bringing students together for a day of community service and impact.

Volunteers will take part in indoor service projects with local organizations where free food, T-shirts and giveaways will be provided.

All students and student organizations are welcome to attend.

Tuesday, January 20

Dr. King Memorial March

Students are invited to gather at 3:30 p.m. at the MLK Jr. Plaza in downtown State College.

The march will begin at 3:45 p.m. following brief, inspirational remarks from State College Mayor Ezra Nanes and a Penn State student.

Participants will walk to the HUB, where the event will continue with a panel discussion at 4:45 p.m. in Freeman Auditorium. Students and community members are all encouraged to attend.

Register at this link if you plan to attend.

MLK Jr. Panel Discussion

After the march and a short break, students and community members are invited to stay for a panel discussion at 4:45 p.m. in Freeman Auditorium in the HUB.

Moderated by Penn State students Deja Workman and Noa Diggs, the panel will feature Randall Maurice Jelks, Wade Fulton Dean and Tracey Mariner who will explore how King’s legacy connects to today’s social and political challenges.

The evening will wrap up with a social reception at the Paul Robeson Cultural Center.

Wednesday, January 21

Poetry and Performance: A Tribute to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

From 6-8 p.m, the Lion’s Lair Lounge will have music and readings with students, community and staff members. There will also be featured performances.

Make sure to RSVP before this event.

Friday, January 23

A Musical Tribute to MLK

Students can enjoy a special musical performance from 7:30- 9 p.m in Freeman Auditorium as part of Penn State’s week-long celebration of Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy.

The event will feature Noire, Spelman College’s contemporary popular music ensemble, known for reimagining popular music and highlighting historically underrepresented voices.

Additional performances by the United Christian Campus Ministry Choir and Penn State’s Essence of Joy will round out the evening, creating a powerful and uplifting musical tribute to King.

Saturday, January 31

A Movie Screening of the “ King in the Wilderness”

Join fellow community members in State College for a special screening of “King in the Wilderness” in Freeman Auditorium at the HUB-Robeson Center.

The film explores King’s final years, his struggles and the lasting influence of his leadership.

The screening provides new insights into King’s philosophy, courage and legacy, giving viewers a deeper understanding of the man behind the movement.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State hits the road, visits Syracuse
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
The collegiate women’s hockey world was stunned on Saturday afternoon, when No. 4 Penn State allowed a late tally followed by an overtime goal against Mercyhurst in its first conference loss of the season.

Continuing on their seven-game road trip, the Nittany Lions embark to Tennity Ice Pavilion in Syracuse, New York, to take on the Orange at 6 p.m Friday, and 3 p.m Saturday. The blue and white enter against Syracuse with a 19-4 overall record and 13-1 in the AHA. Meanwhile, the Orange are 12-11-3 overall and 8-6-2 in the conference.

Head-to-Head

The last time these two teams squared off, the puck was nearly always on a Nittany Lions’ stick.

The blue and white rode the offensive wave en route to an authoritative series sweep over the Orange, kicking off with a 7-0 victory in Game 1 before its history-making 11-2 punchline in Game 2. Penn State’s 11 goals tied the program record for most goals in a single game.

Syracuse currently rides a four-game winning streak after stringing together consecutive sweeps over Delaware and Robert Morris. Meanwhile, the Nittany Lions endured an upset in their previous outing against Mercyhurst.

Scouting the Orange

Syracuse is a difficult team to read. While they’ve faced defeat to ranked and unranked teams alike, the Orange responded with close games and even found success in the shootout against a top-5 opponent.

On Nov. 25, Syracuse went the distance with then-No. 5 Cornell. The game was deadlocked at 2-2 and ended up decided in a shootout. Heidi Knoll and Nea Tervonen converted on their attempts, while goaltender Ava Drabyk was solid in net for a 2-0 shootout victory, despite the game officially registering as a draw nationally.

This contest wasn’t the first time the Orange pulled off an extended-time victory, however. Four days before beating Cornell, Knoll dealt the same blow to Mercyhurst in a shootout, as well.

Outside of the shootout, Emma Gnade paces Syracuse’s offense with eight goals and seven assists. Peyton Armstrong follows closely, with 13 points this season and Jackson Kinsler rounds out the top three with 12 points.

Senior Sami Gendron leads the defensive effort with 51 blocked shots, as well as contributing a goal and five assists while maintaining a zero plus-minus rating. Sophomore Jessica Cheung ranks second with 42 blocked shots, adding seven assists.

Drabyk’s set to make her 24th start of the season between the pipes. The freshman netminder shows a 10-10-3 personal record, while boasting a .931 save percentage and 2.07 goals-against average.

Potential roster changes

Currently, Penn State has two players listed as members of their respective Olympic teams for the 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games: Tessa Janecke for the United States and Nicole Hall for Sweden.

With the Games approaching, Janecke and Hall, two of Penn State’s top performers, could be missing out on the Nittany Lions’ closing act with the Orange this season.

Starting goaltender Katie DeSa didn’t appear in either game against the Lakers last weekend, possibly due to an undisclosed injury, with no clear timeline on return. Freshman Maddy Campbell stepped into the starting role and has posted a .932 save percentage coupled with a 1.40 goals-against average so far through eight games.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 2 Penn State travels to West Point open for first tournament of the season
author: Annie Gleba | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 2 Penn State travels to West Point, New York, to compete in the 2026 West Point Open. The two-day event begins this Friday. The Nittany Lions opened this season with a win over Army, 311.300-297.600, at Rec Hall.

This event features competitors from levels 3 to 10 events and includes athletes from Penn State, Simpson, Navy, Springfield College, Army and William & Mary. The first day consists of NCAA-level team competition, while the second day will host individual event finals for the top qualifiers from Friday’s competition.

Last season at the West Point Open, Penn State finished second behind Ohio State, which will not return to the competition this year, with a team score of 237.800.

Simpson College

Simpson College is a Division III program that competes in the Eastern College Athletic Conference (ECAC). Simpson established its program and began to compete in the 2022-23 season. This means the Storm has never attended the West Point Open competition. They are the only NCAA school in Iowa to sponsor men’s gymnastics and one of the few DIII programs nationwide.

Last season, they placed 6th in the ECAC Championship with a score of 299.600, and their all-around season average being 292.100.

Navy

Navy won its conference championship frequently in the last decade. The Midshipmen are a powerhouse within their conference and defeated Springfield College this season. Last year in the West Point Open, they placed third with a score of 309.500.

Despite losing the conference last year, Navy posted a 5-0 record. The name to watch from the Navy is Danilo Viciana. He was elected team captain this season and participated in the NCAA Championship Event Final.

Springfield College

Springfield College finished last place during last year's competition, just narrowly behind William & Mary with 300.050 points. During the first meet of this season, the Pride placed about 1.5 points under Navy, 307.650-306.100. The Pride’s roster contains gymnasts who previously qualified for individual finals in recent seasons, aiming to improve on their previous standing scores.

They will lean on players like Owen Carney, who qualified for individual finals in three different events in last year’s West Point Open. The senior won the high bar event and placed second on the floor.

Army

Last year, Army won its conference, dethroning Navy's previous six-year streak and its first ECAC championship since 2015. Last season, Army placed 4th in the West Point Open, just slightly behind Navy with a score of 308.300.

After their conference win, the Black Knights went on to the NCAA Championships Qualifier, where they placed 10th.

William & Mary

The Griffins placed 5th in the West Point Open last year with a score of 300.450. They had four individuals advance to event finals, with all competitors placing inside the top eight. One of William & Mary’s top competitors is Evan Wilkins.

His floor score against Springfield ranks as the nation's 10th-best mark in 2025, as well as earning all-ECAC on the floor after tying for third.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: No. 1 Penn State wrestling hits the road to face No. 4 Iowa
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
This Friday, Penn State faces their marquee opponent of the season so far, traveling to Carver Hawkeye Arena to face off against the Iowa Hawkeyes.

The venue is the last place the Nittany Lions lost a dual, nearly six years ago. Iowa will look to shock the world by handing the Nittany Lions another loss. However, recent controversies and some underperforming upperclassmen leave Penn State as a heavy favorite in this top-five matchup.

125: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 6 Dean Peterson (UI)

This serves as a revenge match for Luke Lilledahl after Dean Peterson upset him, 4-1, at Rutgers last season.

Peterson is 7-1 in his senior year, but has no marquee victories under his belt to this point. This will be Lilledahl’s highest-ranked matchup of the season so far.

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 8 Drake Ayala (UI)

Drake Ayala is a two-time NCAA runner-up, but has taken a step back early this season with his record floating around the .500 line heading into a match with Blaze. For Blaze, this marks an opportunity to claim a victory over one of the most prestigious names in college wrestling, even during his down year.

Despite the record, Ayala is no cake walk. In the past two years, Ayala didn’t drop more than five matches in a season. Blaze will have to use pure skill to outmatch the experience of Ayala.

141: No. 7 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 11 Nasir Bailey (UI)

Braeden Davis faces another big name talent having a relatively down year for the Hawkeyes, wrestling against former All-American and Pac-12 champion Nasir Bailey. Bailey’s 9-3 record isn’t bad, but he is nearing his loss total for previous years earlier in the season than usual.

For Davis, this is his biggest match since moving up to 141. Davis jumped into the top 10 immediately after returning to the lineup and will try to earn that ranking on Friday.

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 17 Ryder Block (UI)

Ryder Block is in the midst of a breakout year after going 2-4 last season. Block is 6-2 in the early goings of his sophomore season but is 1-2 in ranked matches.

Shayne Van Ness has been running through competition this season, and Block doesn’t show the makings of an opponent that could upset the No. 1 at the weight class.

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. No. 12 Jordan Williams (UI)

Jordan Williams is another highly touted transfer on Iowa’s roster after coming in from Little Rock. He’s 7-2 on the season for his new team, but is 0-2 against ranked opponents. This is the biggest matchup of the season so far for PJ Duke, going against the defending PAC-12 champion. Duke has been outscoring Williams on the year and is the favorite in this matchup.

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs No. 3 Micheal Caliendo (UI)

This is a familiar matchup for both sides, as Michael Caliendo has faced Mitchell Mesenbrink six times over the last few years, with Mesenbrink winning each matchup. Each matchup has gotten closer, but it’s clear Mesenbrink has Caliendo’s number. This is expected to be a low-scoring affair as both wrestlers are patient and familiar with each other’s styles.

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs No. 3 Patrick Kennedy (UI)

Patrick Kennedy is in the midst of his most successful season in his senior year, starting out 9-1 and jumping into the top three. He is 3-1 against top-15 opponents, but Levi Haines is on a different level.

Haines is 3-0 against Kennedy in his career, with each win being decisive. Nothing has shifted to suggest this match will end much differently than those ones.

184: No. 4 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs No. 1 Angelo Ferrari (UI)

Angelo Ferrari was a highly touted prospect during his redshirt season last year. During one of his matches in the Bryce Jordan Center, Ferrari held former Nittany Lion Carter Starocci to one point. This season, his defense has defined his success, as he hasn’t been taken down in a match this season. This is one of two matches where the Nittany Lion won’t be the favorite.

Rocco Welsh has been consistent since joining the Nittany Lions, but hasn’t been showing off the way Ferrari has this season. This will be a low-scoring match that may be decided by a single takedown or escape points.

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. Gabe Arnold/ Harvey Ludington (UI)

With the dismissal of No. 4 Massoma Endene, there is uncertainty around who Josh Barr will face on Friday night. Gabe Arnold is a familiar name to Penn State fans and he has wrestled up to the weight class multiple times.

Harvey Ludington is on the verge of burning his redshirt, so the decision must be made to start him for the season, or yield to Arnold.

Barr has been dominant since returning to action in December, either wrestler will be challenged to compete with No. 1.

285: No. 13 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs No. 5 Ben Kueter (UI)

This is the second matchup in which the Hawkeye is favored. Kueter, a former Iowa football player, has continued to grow as Hawkeye heavyweight. He is 3-1 in limited action and viewed as a tier above Mirasola in terms of national championship contention.

This means Mirasola has an opportunity to move up a lot in the rankings with a victory over Kueter. However, Kueter has a clear size advantage over Mirasola, a consistent struggle for the undersized Nittany Lion.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Film review | Ohio State transfer James Peoples brings athleticism to Penn State RB room
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Ohio State running back James Peoples committed to Penn State during the transfer-portal window, giving the team a player with upside.

Peoples was in a depth role for the Buckeyes in 2025, tallying 61 carries for 344 yards and three touchdowns. The sophomore was a 247Sports composite 4-star and the No. 115 player nationally in the 2024 class, and he flashed some of that potential this past season.

Here are the traits Peoples could bring with him to Happy Valley.

Athleticism

Peoples has the athleticism to make potential tacklers in the open field miss. He’s flashed that talent on the limited touches he saw through his two seasons with the Buckeyes.

Possibly his most noteworthy play in 2025 came against UCLA, where he took a handoff to the right side of the field, hurdling over a defender to score a touchdown on a 19-yard rush.

Peoples has athleticism in the open field, such as this hurdle to score a touchdown against UCLA pic.twitter.com/UGG526xscs— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Peoples showcased some shiftiness, being able to change direction quickly and juke out defenders.

He can make potential tacklers miss like this rush versus the Bruins pic.twitter.com/kXEGaae4bP— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

With this skillset, Penn State could try to get Peoples out in the open field on plays next season. Him consistently making opposing players miss would allow him to break off chunk yardage plays for the Nittany Lions.

Vision

Behind an offensive line that opened up running lanes at Ohio State, Peoples used his vision to find and attack those opportunities to pick up yards.

With a quick burst of speed, he can quickly run through open rushing lanes.

Peoples has the vision to see and attack open rushing lanes, which gives him opportunities to pick up large gains like this pic.twitter.com/Ro7JvBz6S9— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Peoples’ proved his vision on these plays, trusting his eyes and not hesitating on these rushes.

Peoples consistently takes advantage of rushing lanes generated by the blocking in front of him pic.twitter.com/0iLkreYrP9— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

If Penn State’s offensive line can generate a similar push on opposing defensive fronts, Peoples seems like he’ll be able to make the same impact plays on the ground for the Nittany Lions.

Yards after contact

While Peoples has speed in the open field, he can also break out of contact between the tackles.

He had one of those types of plays against Penn State in 2025, picking up a first down after being contacted near the line of scrimmage.

Peoples can pick up yards after contact, such as this rush against Penn State pic.twitter.com/mmw0VDoUhM— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

The 5-foot-10, 206-pound running back has the strength to break through would-be tacklers, powering himself downfield for tough yardage.

Here’s another look at Peoples gaining yards after contact pic.twitter.com/pkBqG3lmAw— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

It’ll give him the versatility to be used on either inside or outside zone rushes for Penn State.

Pass-catcher potential

Peoples didn’t see much action in the passing game during his two seasons at Ohio State, but he still caught 10 passes for 50 yards in 2025.

As such, Peoples flashed the potential to be involved in a passing attack with receptions via screen passes or check downs for the Buckeyes.

He could be used in the passing game as well with screen passes or checkdowns pic.twitter.com/79rYvzgCiE— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Getting the ball to Peoples with a throw also gets him in the open field, where he can use his agility to rack up yards.

Another catch by Peoples here: pic.twitter.com/cthinfL6J2— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Peoples could be on the field in obvious passing downs for Penn State, adding another wrinkle to his game.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Off the Record | Ins and outs of 2026
author: The Daily Collegian
description:
Editor’s Note: Off the record is a weekly column written by a third-year Collegian staffer writing under an alias. It aims to promote a space for honest conversations about love, sex and relationships. Those interested in sharing their experiences or submitting a topic are invited to do so through our anonymous form.

Dearest reader,

Welcome back to another semester in Happy Valley — where the drama is high, the standards are low and somehow everyone’s still trying to “just see where things go.”

Allow me to introduce myself. I am Miss Behave and this semester I have the pleasure of exploring everything and anything about love, relationships and sex with you. And the best part? You get to send in your own stories and advice, anonymously, of course.

Think of me as your campus Cupid, if Cupid had a sharper tongue and better Wi‑Fi. So grab your beverage of choice and settle in, because it’s time to talk about what’s in and what’s out as we enter our 2026 era. The popular “ins” and “outs” trend is the new way to set intentions, and naturally I have thoughts.

I know we’re all busy bees this first week back, so let’s skip the foreplay and jump right into it.

INS

Self-Respect (Membership Mandatory)

Self-respect is mandatory. Desperation is the emotional equivalent of wearing socks with sandals, stop it. Also, if someone can’t meet you at your level, don’t lower standards and don't you dare settle for less than you deserve. Respect yourself and know your worth.

Emotional IQ

Ladies, if you can order a Starbucks with multiple modifications, you can say what’s actually going on in your head. Gentlemen, if you can rant about your favorite sports team for half an hour, you can spend a few minutes admitting you have feelings. Speak up and be honest.

Dating with Intention

We’re dating like adults … calendars, expectations and actual standards included. If you want something casual, say it. If you want something real, act like it. Show up, text back like a functioning human and stop acting like effort is optional.

Modern dating isn’t always cute; it can be exhausting. So stop with the games, stop with the mixed signals and for the love of all that is holy, stop chasing people who won’t even meet you halfway.

A Review Board

Your friends are the jury. If your friends aren’t hyping up your standards, they’re enabling your delusions. We should be able to lean on our close friends for advice and some guidance. Navigating a love life isn’t an easy task, and without a friendly jury, it’s basically a trial by fire.

When it comes to crushes, dating and relationships, none of us have it all figured out. It’s easy to get lost in your own feelings. Take a breath. Sometimes your friends can see the red flags or the hidden gems that you can’t.

OUTS

Chasing the unavailable

Newsflash. If they’re unavailable, they’re unavailable. Stop wasting your emotional energy on a figment of your imagination. Chasing someone who isn’t showing up for you isn’t romantic. It’s pathetic.

Your time, attention and feelings are worth more than being a background character in someone else’s story. Walk away, save your energy and invest it where it’s actually wanted.

Mixed signals

Mixed signals are manipulative. One minute, they’re all warmth and charm, the next, they vanish like Houdini. If someone can’t communicate, they’re not complicated, they’re careless.

Stop twisting yourself into knots trying to interpret vibes, texts or emojis like a cryptic code. Give your attention and effort to people who actually show up consistently, not ones who leave you guessing.

Ghosting

It’s not Halloween. Grow up.

Red flags

Listen, we will not be colorblind in 2026. If it’s giving toxic energy, leave. Ignoring warning signs isn’t brave; it's dumb. Likewise, red flags aren’t suggestions; they’re stop signs. Respect them and trust your gut.

I apologize if I sound a little harsh. Scratch that, I’m not sorry. I’m here to be real with you. If anything I said makes you flinch, chances are it’s about you. And if it is, maybe it’s time for a little self-reflection as we enter the new year.

I truly hope everyone had a great first week back. Take some of these thoughts to heart. Let them inspire you, or simply remind you that you matter. Your time, effort and heart deserve to be treated with care.

I hope your first week back is as exciting as the stories waiting to be written.

Yours truly,

Miss Behave

MORE COLUMNS

title: UPUA president’s fall attendance raises concerns over bylaws, accountability
author: Mia Debelevich | News Editor
description:
The University Park Undergraduate Association (UPUA) enforces mandatory attendance rules for general assembly members, but its governing documents do not establish attendance requirements for executive board members.

In order to pass any legislation, the UPUA needs general assembly members to meet its quorum of one-half plus one. For example, a 58-member general assembly would need 30 in attendance to pass legislation.

However, attendance requirements are not applicable to members of UPUA’s executive board, which comprises the president, vice president, chief of staff and deputy chief of staff, as they are not considered members of the general assembly.

According to Article VI in the UPUA’s bylaws, “attendance of the General Assembly, Work Session, Committee of the Whole, and Committee Meetings is mandatory for all members of the Assembly.” Any unexcused absences by general assembly members results in deficiency points.

Once representatives reach three deficiency points, their membership is reviewed, according to UPUA Vice President Noah Youcheff. He said if representatives attend tabling events, write extra legislation or engage in UPUA extracurricular work, they can bring their deficiency points down.

Hunter Steach, chief justice, said the expectation for executive attendance is an “unsung rule,” typically passed down from preceding presidents. He said some of the problems the UPUA had this past semester can be “attributed to members of the executive branch not being there.”

Steach said he “hardly remembers” any absences from the past three UPUA presidents. However, the same can not be said for Rasha Elwakil.

“I don't think it’s the best reflection at all times, because we had a lot of attendance problems just across the board,” Steach said. “I've been in UPUA for four years and been going to GA — pretty much every GA — for the last four years, and from my perspective, I don't think we've ever struggled with attendance across the board as much as last semester.”

Steach said he would be open to reviewing rules regarding attendance or introducing a formal mechanism that clearly outlines the expectations of executive members.

Elwakil arrived to the following meetings after the halfway point: Oct. 8, Oct. 29, Nov. 5 and Dec. 3.

“I chose to be selfish and go to a (panhellenic) event because that was our last one of the year,” Elwakil said at the Dec. 3 meeting. “But, I think it’s very hypocritical of me to not apologize when I’ve been asking you guys to show up and be in attendance every week, and so I just did want to give that apology real quick and say I’m truly sorry for that.”

The Dec. 3 meeting was delayed due to an inability to meet quorum. Representatives were asked by Kat Hogan and Youcheff to contact other representatives and ask if they could attend the meeting.

Elwakil did not give her report at this meeting, stating she didn’t want to take up more time of those in attendance.

“I'm not perfect, and I won't say I was a perfect president,” Elwakil said in an interview. “But I do say that I am trying my best and I think I am showing up for the organization.”

Elwakil said only one UPUA member came to her with concerns about her absences following the Dec. 3 meeting. The conversation made her realize it was unnecessary to come late, she said.

“I should have shown up, and I did reflect on that, and moving forward this semester, I'm making sure that I show up to everything, hopefully,” Elwakil said.

Youcheff said attendance is a “big thing” for UPUA, as it’s important to meet quorum, hence the attendance requirements for representatives. He said the steering committee — which includes the president, vice president, chief of staff, chief justice and the five legislative committee chairs — has possible plans to intensify attendance requirements this semester.

“I’ve always been very amenable to the argument for implementing attendance points, and I think that conversation is going to be pretty big this year when we go into these governing document reviews and talk about that,” Youcheff said.

Youcheff said people have varying opinions on the importance of attendance to the executive and judicial branches.

“It kind of depends on what you view general assembly as,” Youcheff said. “If you see it as this meeting where the whole student government gets together once a week and kind of gets their business done, a lot of people think everyone should be there for that. Other people think that the executive, judicial roles in general assembly aren’t as crucial.”

The vice president has to chair the assembly per 6.2.3 clause 2 of Article VI of the UPUA Constitution — so he described his attendance as necessary.

The clause states: “The Vice President shall preside over the meetings of the Assembly, retain floor privileges, and vote solely in the cases that will influence the outcome of a tied vote, except on votes to override a veto of the President.”

Despite this, attendance is not tracked nor explicitly constitutionally required for the vice president of the organization. He said he’s held accountable by representatives.

In the fall semester, Youcheff came to the beginning of the Oct. 29 meeting, but left due to a scheduled exam. It was the only meeting that occurred without his presence.

Youcheff, Steach and Elwakil all said they had no concerns about the attendance patterns of other executive members.

Hogan, speaker of the assembly, said attendance has been the topic of a “multitude” of conversations within the UPUA’s steering committee.

“Having leadership not be very active in attendance sets an example for the rest of the assembly,” Hogan said. “It can be a bit difficult to try and encourage representatives to show up when they’re seeing that.”

Hogan said she’s spoken with at-large representatives who’ve expressed discontent with the disparity in attendance policies. She said many feel “disheartened” by the absence of their leaders.

“I do think that there should be more attendance standards that the executive, and even judicial members, should be held accountable for,” Hogan said. “That will be up for significant discussion when we get into our constitution and bylaw amendments later (this) semester.”

Maria Lopez, justice and equity chair, said she’s also noticed a change in the enthusiasm of the general assembly.

“Though representatives look up usually to members of steering for guidance when it comes to initiatives or attendance or what projects to work on, I believe that this semester specifically some people have been a little unmotivated to continue on the work,” Lopez said. “We’ve had our ups and downs this semester, but I’m grateful (representatives) have found that motivation to still come back.”

MORE INVESTIGATIONS

title: ‘That's going to cost you’ | Penn State basketball loses rebounding, 2nd-chance point battles vs. UCLA
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
After Mike Rhoades started his opening statement by thanking the fans who showed up like he usually does, he said what he felt was the reason behind UCLA’s 71-60 win over Penn State on Wednesday night.

Rhoades said it “came down” to second-chance points with the Bruins outscoring the Nittany Lions 19 to 4 in that category. It was the main result of UCLA winning the rebound battle 32 to 21 as the Bruins secured a double-digit road win.

“I thought we've been rebounding the ball pretty well. We didn't do that today,” Rhoades said. “We give up too many second-chance points, and that's going to cost you. So I think some of it was fatigue, some of it was young guys out there, but you got to find a way to scrap out some defensive rebounds and give yourself a chance. We didn't do that.”

Before UCLA pulled away for the victory, Penn State had the Bruins in striking distance throughout the second half. With around 10:00 left in the game, UCLA missed three-straight 3-pointers, but it grabbed the offensive board every time before guard Trent Perry knocked down a jumper to give his squad a 52-49 lead.

A similar sequence happened a few minutes later as guard Donovan Dent missed a layup, but UCLA got the offensive rebound and got two more second-chance points via a pair of free throws by Perry. Those points gave the Bruins a 60-52 advantage as that was the closest the Nittany Lions were to the lead for the remaining 6:04 of the game.

Wing Eli Rice didn’t know the exact statistics when he spoke with the media postgame, but he even knew that UCLA won the rebounding and second-chance point battles.

“It definitely hurt us,” Rice said. “Their second-chance points, I'm not sure what they are, but I'm sure it probably was way more than ours. So I mean, it definitely hurt us, and that's always a vocal point going into every game to box out and then with our offensive rebounds. But that's definitely what hurt us today, was the reason we lost again.”

The Bruins finished the night with 11 offensive rebounds compared to Penn State’s six. Furthermore, all four of the Nittany Lions’ second-chance points came within the last four minutes of the game, when the Bruins consistently had a double-digit lead.

UCLA 6-foot-9 forward Tyler Bilodeau and 6-foot-10 center Steven Jamerson II totaled nine and eight rebounds, respectively. Both of them are taller than every Penn State player who saw minutes in Wednesday’s game, except for freshman 7-footer Ivan Jurić.

“Some of it is size. Some of it is a young guy not pushing them out early enough,” Rhoades said. “We give up a bunch of offensive rebounds on the backside today because we didn't do our work early. We got to work on it. We got to continue to work on it. We do work on it every day.”

Rebounding is an issue for Penn State that even popped up in the nonconference schedule. Against Campbell on Dec. 2, the Nittany Lions were outrebounded 39 to 30.

Throughout the start of the Big Ten slate, Penn State has been outrebounded in four of six games — the Michigan and Purdue games are the two contests the Nittany Lions won the battle on the glass. On the year, Penn State is averaging a margin of -2.1 rebounds per game.

Penn State not getting a rebound against UCLA began to stack up, highlighting the difference in skill between the two teams.

“They took advantage of it,” Rhoades said. “Good players take advantage of small errors. And you just got to harp on it all the time. So when you're dealing with young guys, you hold them accountable, you teach them, you show them. You keep doing it over again until they become good habits. You want it to be tomorrow morning, but the reality of it is 18 to 22-year-olds, nothing happens overnight. You just gotta keep working on it. Keep building habits. That's part of the culture you gotta build.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball drops fourth-straight game in loss to UCLA, still winless in Big Ten
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
UCLA’s first-ever trip to State College was an eventful one.

In the midst of a three-game losing streak – all ranked opponents – Penn State has been desperate for a win.

The Nittany Lions fought hard in their recent stretch of games and kept it interesting, but just weren’t able to close it out, including a near-upset over then-ranked No. 2 Michigan.

Once again, the blue and white just didn’t have enough to keep up, and remain winless in conference play after falling to UCLA 71-60.

“It was a tough game. I think it came down to second-chance points,” Mike Rhoades said. “We gave up. We battled; we were in striking distance a few times. As the game went on, we settled… We gave up too many second-chance points, and that’s gonna cost you.”

To kick off just the third all-time meeting between the two programs, Penn State won the opening tipoff only to turn it over, giving the Bruins an optimal scoring opportunity.

However, a missed UCLA three-pointer turned into a defensive rebound, leading to an Ivan Jurić posterizing slam that put the Nittany Lions on the board first.

At the first media timeout, Penn State found itself with a 6-2 edge backed by Jurić’s four points and three forced Bruins turnovers.

Six points for Trent Perry in the early going gave the Bruins an 11-8 lead, but it didn’t last long as Eli Rice drained two shots back-to-back, including a three-pointer, which tied the affair at 13-13.

The two cross-country foes traded points back-and-forth for a while and kept it tied up until momentum seemed to shift slightly to the blue and white’s end of the court as a few Bruins turnovers and fouls allowed Penn State to take a 21-17 lead.

The low scoring continued for the last few minutes of the first half until UCLA started to put points on the board quickly, with just under two minutes left.

Just before the Bruins started up the scoring again, Freddie Dilione V went down with an ankle injury that Rhoades later said was a sprained ankle. Dilione V missed the remainder of the game, and that absence was felt all around.

“Freddie went down; that obviously hurt us, but I think it was a group thing,” Rice said. “We weren’t doing good as a group.”

Tyler Bilodeau and Eric Freeny each drained a three-pointer to put the Bruins in control at 29-21, but Melih Tunca, draining both of his free throws just before time expired, cut the blue and white lead to six points at the half.

Perry was the all-around points leader at the half with eight, shooting one-for-five from the field, but drilling six free throws on as many attempts.

Not only was the score close, but so was the rest of the game. Penn State was shooting 39% from the field while UCLA was shooting 35%.

The Nittany Lions knocked down just one three-pointer in the first half and sent the Bruins to the charity stripe ten times, where they didn’t miss once.

Tunca hit one from downtown to start the second half for his first points of the night aside from free throws.

Penn State was closing in, cutting the deficit to 31-30 until a UCLA three-pointer stopped the effort. The Nittany Lions matched it with a Rice three, but it wasn’t enough to gain an edge.

On fire to start the second half, Perry sank another three-pointer to once again grab a four-point lead and give himself 14 points on the night, still the most from either end to that point.

UCLA grabbed an eight-point lead, its largest of the night, after a Bilodeau and-one. It didn’t take long for Penn State to close in, though, as points came in rapid succession.

Dominick Stewart’s physicality and long-range shooting gave the Nittany Lions their first lead since the late stages of the first half, but an immediate Bilodeau three-pointer put the Bruins back up with a slight 50-49 lead.

The Nittany Lions found themselves in the midst of an 11-1 UCLA run, however, and went down 58-50 not long after they captured that hard-fought lead.

Perry and Bilodeau had 24 and 21 points each, with five minutes left to play as the Bruins jumped up to a 63-52 lead.

“Sometimes you get lost in the game,” Rhoades said. “(UCLA) made their threes, and we didn’t. That was a huge difference.”

Eric Dailey Jr. was the only other UCLA starter with any points.

Penn State struck back, but being down 13 points with three minutes to play is not a recipe for success.

The deficit proved insurmountable, and the Nittany Lions suffered their fourth-straight loss, falling 71-60.

“It’s super frustrating,” Rice said. “I mean, close doesn’t get you the win; it doesn’t mean anything. It’s still a zero in the column. It’s definitely frustrating, but we want to win, we don’t want to be close.”

Now at 9-8 on the year, Penn State finds itself just one game ahead of Northwestern and two games ahead of Maryland in the Big Ten Standings.

Injury Report

Penn State’s standout freshman Kayden Mingo was out again with a broken nose sustained in practice before the Michigan game. He underwent successful surgery but will be “out for a while.”

Tibor Mirtič also missed action with a knee injury. Mirtič will “be out for a little bit” as his knee is “just rehabbing.”

Up Next

The Nittany Lions look to snap their now four-game losing streak when they hit the road and head south to Maryland to take on the Terrapins on Sunday.

Scheduled tipoff is set for noon.

title: SEE IT: Aiden Fink becomes fastest Nittany Lion to hit 100 career points

Fink was bombarded by his teammates after entering the locker room, dousing him with water.

🔥 FINKER’S ON FIRE 🔥 1️⃣0️⃣0️⃣ PointsThe fastest Nittany Lion to ever do it 😤🦁#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/prIS9CHdM5— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 14, 2026

title: Penn State adds former Iowa State DL Ikenna Ezeogu
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Will the Ames to State College pipeline stop anytime soon?

Penn State has added former Iowa State defensive lineman Ikenna Ezeogu, according to the school's directory.

Ezeogu is coming off of a 2025 for the Cyclones where he tallied a career-best 25 total tackles, starting in all 12 games.

After redshirting in 2022 for his freshman season, he became a key piece on defense over the next three seasons, tallying 60 total tackles, four pass break ups, three sacks and a fumble recovery.

The 6-foot-5, 285-pound defensive lineman from Blue Springs, Missouri, will have one year of eligibility remaining.

title: Penn State notebook | Cael Sanderson reveals status of Aaron Nagao, talks Iowa in weekly availability
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Following a win against Rutgers to open up conference play, Penn State will hit the road this weekend for a pair of duals, facing Iowa on Friday and Northwestern on Sunday.

Ahead of wrestling a pair of conference foes, Cael Sanderson met with the media to discuss where the program sits heading into the new year as well as his business venture.

Here’s what he had to say.

Aaron Nagao

After suffering an injury in the Black Knight Invitational in November, Aaron Nagao returned to the mat in December in the Southern Scuffle, only for him to medically forfeit after winning his first match.

Sanderson provided a status update on Nagao, and it’s one that won’t have him suit up at 141 pounds for the remainder of the year. Sanderson said “he’s definitely done for the season.”

“Has had some setbacks, obviously, with that shoulder, and that's a tough one to come back from, but he's kind of got to restart that process,” Sanderson said.

Nagao returned to the mat this year after having not wrestled for close to two years. He’ll finish the season with a 5-2 record, with both of his losses coming on medical forfeits.

He will likely need surgery, as Sanderson mentioned postgame after the win over Rutgers. In place of Nagao, Braeden Davis will likely be the starter at 141 the rest of the way.

“The reality of what Aaron was coming back from, just an uphill battle,” Sanderson said. “Shoulders are really challenging in our sport. It's complicated, obviously, joint positions you get put in wrestling, but if anyone could do it, it was Aaron. So, we want to give him the best support and opportunity we could give him.”

Iowa

Just like Penn State, Iowa has historically been in the top tier of collegiate wrestling programs.

Come Friday night, in a battle between the No. 1 Nittany Lions and the No. 4 Hawkeyes, Sanderson knows his team will have to bring it, but still keep the main thing the main thing.

“Same mentality,” Sanderson said. “Of course, Iowa is a great opponent. Great wrestlers, great coaches, great tradition and history. We got to be ready to roll.”

Carver Hawkeye Area notoriously is known for being a raucous environment and drawing great crowds. There’s no doubt the Hawkeye faithful will bring the juice on Friday night.

Sanderson said Penn State will be ready for it, as the squad has wrestled in a handful of similar atmospheres, paired with having them in their own backyard.

“I think we're blessed. I mean, most of the places we go, we get a great crowd,” Sanderson said. “We wrestle in front of a great crowd here at Penn State, whether it's in Rec Hall or the (Bryce) Jordan Center. So we're used to getting to compete in front of enthusiastic fans. That makes what we do more fun and worthwhile.”

Iowa has a handful of talented wrestlers, notably No. 1 Angelo Ferrari at 184 pounds, No. 3 Michael Caliendo at 165 and No. 5 Ben Kueter at 285. At 197 pounds, Penn State could see Gabe Arnold or Harvey Ludington, as previous starter Massoma Endene is no longer with the team.

Regardless of who is wrestling or how good the opponent may be, Penn State has heavy hitters of their own.

“Our guys are just gonna do what they do,” Sanderson said. “It doesn't make a lot of sense to make any adjustments. Obviously, you're aware of your opponents, but at the same time, the long-term plan is let's get better at what we do, and keep improving and go compete to the best of our ability with some fire and enthusiasm.”

Masanosuke Ono

It was big news for Penn State when it landed Japanese world champion Masanosuke Ono to its roster during the offseason.

During his preseason media availability, Sanderson said the plan for Ono would be for him to redshirt. Now, there’s questions as to if he’ll actually compete this year due to his health.

Ono sustained a kidney illness, according to a report from Wrestling Spirits. The news came out in light of him supposed to wrestle in Japan’s Emperor’s Cup in December, but he ended up withdrawing.

“I’m not sure,” Sanderson said. “Obviously, we’ve been discussing that. But, I don’t know if we’ll see him this year or not. He’s got to get back and get healthy.”

Cael’s Cookie

Off the mat and into the kitchen, Sanderson was asked about his new business venture that has to do with cookies to wrap up the media session.

Sanderson, a self-proclaimed enjoyer of cookies, tried to start his own line close to 20 years ago but didn’t find much triumph.

Now, he recently got back into the field as an enjoyable side quest and is finding more success, releasing “Cael’s Cookie.”

“I have a very small part in it, but it was something that’s kind of fun and I really like them,” Sanderson said. “Basically just got a group of killers to kind of take it and run with it and that's what they're doing.”

title: Former Penn State RB Ki-Jana Carter named to 2026 NFF College Football Hall of Fame class
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former Penn State running back will be honored for his career.

Ki-Jana Carter was named to the 2026 NFF College Football Hall of Fame class on Wednesday.

One of the most dominant backs to wear the @PennStateFball uniform, Ki-Jana Carter (@mastakey32) has been named to the 2026 NFF College Football Hall of Fame class. pic.twitter.com/oXjPzPxNUu— National Football Foundation (@NFFNetwork) January 14, 2026

Carter was the runner-up for the Heisman Trophy and a first-team All-American in 1994, when he rushed for 1,539 yards and 23 touchdowns, which are both the highest totals by a junior in program history. He had an 83-yard score on the Nittany Lions' first offensive play in the Rose Bowl against Oregon that year, kicking off a 38-20 win over the Ducks.

He's No. 12 on Penn State's all-time career rushing list with 2,829 career rushing yards from 1992-94. Carter's rushing yards in 1994 is the third-highest single-season total in Nittany Lion history.

Carter went on to become the No. 1 overall pick in the 1995 NFL draft to the Cincinnati Bengals.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Too much, too early | Penn State women’s basketball slow start sinks Lady Lions in battle with Ohio State
author: Sam Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
Who doesn’t like scoring?

It was a high-scoring affair and a historic night for Ohio State as Penn State battled with the No. 14 Buckeyes in the Jerome Schottenstein Center.

Despite the stats, Penn State’s 0-6 Big Ten record and 7-10 overall losing record did not faze the scarlet and white, who put forth a Big Ten season-high of 108 points scored in a single game.

Last year, the meeting between Penn State and Ohio State served as a ‘trap game’ for the Buckeyes. This season, it marked nothing more than a regular Big Ten clash.

However, the Lady Lions finally played at their opponent's level, not backing down despite early struggles. Less surprisingly, more of the same struggles plagued Penn State in a 108-84 loss.

Hunched over as she observed from the bench, coach Carolyn Kieger could only watch as a disparagingly large Buckeye lead mounted early on. In the blink of an eye, Ohio State found itself holding a double-digit lead.

As the game approached, Penn State had remained searching for its spark. On Wednesday night, the rookie, Nyla McFadden, earned the start as Tea Cleante moved to the bench. However, as the season has already proved, the lineups haven’t mattered.

The turnovers, slow starts, and long runs have.

The Lady Lions allowed a massive run out of the gate as Ohio State took advantage of another slow start. Penn State endured a drought that lasted over halfway through the first quarter with no points.

It was the guard-big duo of Jaloni Cambridge and Elsa Lemmila that dominated as Penn State surrendered the mass of its points inside. Following a major deficit, the Lady Lions began to wake up and combated the run with disciplined basketball.

Moriah Murray, who hadn’t scored in double-digits since her outing against VCU, was the main culprit. While Kiyomi McMiller established an offensive rhythm, it was others who added the flare Kieger had sought.

Instead of digging a bigger hole, Penn State settled in as the adjustments began to take place. Penn State took a trip down memory lane to revisit its win last season. Despite the mostly new roster, there were two constants who had seen what it took.

Along with Murray, Gracie Merkle became the focal point of the offense. Beyond the arc, Murray had fired back with several triples, while Merkle took advantage of the height advantage inside. The pairing successfully brought Penn State back within striking range after scoring 13 and 12 points at the break.

As the old saying goes, ‘Defense wins championships.’ If Penn State were to pull off another upset over Ohio State, it would need an elite defensive effort to complement the offense. Both Cambridge and Lemmila proved to be an issue on that end as they had combined for 34 points at the break.

Being down by less than ten points at the half has become an unfamiliar sight for the Lady Lions. Ultimately, the blueprint had been laid out before their eyes. Penn State had to get stops.

After switching out of a full-court press, Penn State favored a 3-2 zone, aimed to force the ball out of Cambridge and Lemmila’s hands. Yet, what followed wasn’t the result Penn State had hoped for.

Ohio State followed Kieger’s lead in utilizing a zone to contain the Merkle inside. The Buckeyes got their way as Merkle’s quiet third frame gave way to a near 20-point lead. But Penn State was scratching and clawing.

The Lady Lions were able to generate points off turnovers, turning defense into offense. Just as McMiller neared 20 points, Penn State found itself down by ten points. Ohio State began to expose Penn State’s defense as the three-point shooting inserted the dagger.

Chance Gray hit seven threes on the night, many of which came in the second half. In addition, Ohio State made 17 triples; the red-hot offense had stalled all the momentum the Lady Lions were building up, and closed the door for good.

Cambridge, Gray, and Lemmila led the team, all scoring above 20 points each, and combining for 77 points. There was no overcoming that margin for Penn State.

Injury Report

Penn State’s Amiya Evans did not suit up in her second-straight contest.

Up Next

Penn State will host Rutgers on Sunday, Jan. 18, for the school’s White Out game, sponsored by THON. The Scarlet Knights, with a 0-6 Big Ten record, will present Penn State’s best opportunity to earn its first conference victory. Tipoff is scheduled at 1:00 p.m. in Rec Hall.

title: Former Penn State women's soccer star Sam Coffey signs with Manchester City
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former Penn Stater is going abroad.

Sam Coffey, a former midfielder for the Nittany Lions, signed with Manchester City Women on Wednesday.

We are delighted to announce the signing of United States international Sam Coffey until the summer of 2029, subject to international clearance. 🙌✍️ pic.twitter.com/Duv3W3cxUf— Manchester City Women (@ManCityWomen) January 14, 2026

Coffey played for the Nittany Lions from 2019 to 2021 after two years at Boston College. During her college career, she became the 50th player in NCAA Division I soccer history to score 40 goals and record 40 assists.

After graduation, Coffey was drafted in the first round of the 2021 NWSL Draft to the Portland Thorns, where she spent three years and won a championship in her first year.

Coffey now has a deal with Manchester City until the summer of 2029. Manchester City finished runner-up in the league championship last season.

title: Report: Penn State adds JMU kick-off specialist Cristiano Rosa
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Get ready to learn touchbacks.

Penn State has landed a transfer commitment from former JMU kick-off specialist Cristiano Rosa, per Nate Bauer of On3. Rosa is listed in the directory.

Rosa transferred to play for the Dukes in 2023 following two seasons at Central Connecticut, where he went 1-for-3 on field goal attempts.

In 2024, he found his way onto the field as a kick-off specialist, notching 52 touchbacks and appearing in every game for the Dukes the past two years.

Rosa will likely be the favorite to start in the kick-off specialist role, as Gabe Nwosu, who held the role down in 2025, has exhausted eligibility and declared for the NFL draft.

Former Penn State assistant running backs coach Charles Walker is headed to Central Michigan: https://t.co/zZsP7GYmuM— Avery Hill (@official_aveee) January 14, 2026

title: Get to know new Penn State edge coach Christian Smith
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s first coaching staff under Matt Campbell is officially filled, and there’s a new position that’s been filled by one of Campbell’s former players.

Christian Smith will be the Nittany Lions’ edge rushers coach this season, while Ikaika Malloe holds the defensive line coach title. Previously, Penn State had just one head defensive line coach, but the two positions are now separate.

Here’s what to know about Smith, who’s moving east from one Big Ten school to another.

Coaching career

Smith has spent the last three seasons with Northwestern as its defensive line coach, being selected to the 2025 American Football Coaches Association “35 Under 35” list, which identifies premier young coaches in the football industry.

Before joining the Wildcats, Smith spent six years at South Dakota State, spending the first two as the defensive tackles coach before becoming the full-time defensive line coach.

He saw ample success with the Jackrabbits, winning the FCS National Championship in Smith’s last year with the program while making the playoffs each season he was there.

Smith’s defensive line at South Dakota State allowed just 88.1 rushing yards per game in 2022, which ranked first in the FCS, while tying for fourth in sacks with 39. In his four years as the defensive line coach, the Jackrabbits allowed 106.4 rushing yards per game.

In the years prior to Smith’s time at South Dakota State, he worked under Campbell at both Toledo and Iowa State. The Oklahoma native spent 2014-15 as a graduate assistant with the Rockets before doing the same with the Cyclones in 2016.

Smith’s first coaching job, however, was in 2013 as a strength and conditioning intern at Ohio State.

Playing career

Not only did Smith coach under Campbell previously, he also played for him. Smith was a defensive end at Toledo from 2010-13, overlapping with Campbell from 2011-13.

Smith totaled 80 tackles, 11.5 tackles for loss, five sacks and four forced fumbles during his playing career as a defensive end, earning team captain honors as a senior.

He never experienced a losing season at Toledo, helping lead the Rockets to three bowl games during his time as a player.

Players coached

At South Dakota State, Smith helped defensive tackle Caleb Sanders earn FCS First Team All-America honors in 2022 with 6.5 sacks and 9.5 tackles for loss. Sanders currently plays in the Canadian Football League for the Saskatchewan Roughriders but had a brief stint with the Philadelphia Eagles.

Smith also coached Reece Winkelman with the Jackrabbits, who was named to the All-MVFC first team in 2022. Winkelman led the team in tackles for loss and sacks, but is no longer playing football.

Aidan Hubbard was the star under Smith at Northwestern, as the defensive end finished his career fifth on the Wildcats’ all-time sacks list and All-Big Ten honors twice.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State set for showdown against St. Thomas Aquinas, Lewis
author: George Keene | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s volleyball is off to a dominant start, defeating Mount Olive in its home opener 3-1.

In the match, Sean Harvey led the Nittany Lions, collecting 13 kills on 29 total attempts, and Miller Trubey, who racked up 10 kills on 25 total attempts, was just behind him as the secondary option. Jaxon Herr and Michael Schwob combined for a total of 44 assists en route to a blue and white victory.

Penn State followed up that strong performance with a 3-0 shutout win against Manhattan on Saturday. Harvey led the Nittany Lions with 14 kills on 18 attempts, hitting a resounding 0.667.

Penn State has the opportunity to build on its hot start with matches against St. Thomas Aquinas at 7 p.m. Thursday and Lewis at 7 p.m. Saturday.

St. Thomas Aquinas

The Spartans are off to a rough start, losing their first two matchups with Pepperdine and USC and getting swept in the process.

However, St. Thomas Aquinas suffered the same fate at the start of last year’s season before finishing 16-9 behind a seven-match and five-match win streak.

Through their first two games, outside hitter Kyran Versteegen leads the Spartans, accounting for 16 kills this season, more than doubling the total of his next closest teammate.

The junior will need to have his best performance of the season in order to give the Spartans a shot at stealing a victory in Happy Valley, especially if Harvey continues to swing effectively for Penn State.

This matchup marks the first all-time between Penn State and St. Thomas Aquinas.

Lewis

Unlike the Spartans, Lewis heads into this matchup with momentum after winning each of its first two matches against Menlo College and No. 9 Stanford, both with sweeps.

Oguzhan Oguz leads the Flyers in kills with 26 and leads their frontline. However, Lewis has a balanced attack, with three players already collecting 20 or more kills this season. Winning the battle at the net will be key in their matchup with the Nittany Lions, as Harvey, Trubey and Matthew Luoma have an attempt to keep Penn State rolling.

Lewis arrives off a strong season, earning a 22-9 record, including a sweep victory over the blue and white in the teams’ only meeting of the season.

This season, Penn State has the advantage of home court, which is crucial for securing a victory, as Lewis finished 7-6 away from home last year, compared to its 14-3 home record.

Both teams are off to strong starts, and this will be an early test for both squads as the season begins to ramp up.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State DT Alonzo Ford Jr. declares for NFL draft
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
The big man is off to the big leagues.

Penn State starting defensive tackle Alonzo Ford Jr. has declared for the 2026 NFL Draft, he announced on Tuesday via Instagram.

Ford spent three seasons with the Nittany Lions, transferring in from Old Dominion.

Being sidelined for all of 2023 and missing the tail end of 2024 with injuries, Ford’s only fully healthy season was his most recent.

In that campaign, he earned a starting role and tallied 18 tackles, one interception and half of a tackle for loss. He totaled 104 tackles, 11.5 tackles for loss and four sacks in his collegiate career.

title: State College Borough Council discuss Renee Good, consider local policies on immigration operations
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Mayor Ezra Nanes addressed the fatal shooting of Renee Nicole Good by an Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE) agent in Minneapolis on Jan. 7 during a State College Borough Council meeting Monday.

Nanes said Good’s death sent “ripple effects” throughout the community and called for a reaffirmation of the borough’s policies regarding immigration operations occurring in State College.

“There have been requests for information pertaining to residents’ rights when it comes to immigration enforcement, and other things as far as what federal law enforcement officers are able to do, where they are able to go, what is required of them under the laws of the United States, the laws of the Commonwealth and the ordinances of the borough,” Nanes said. “I think it's important that we make this information publicly available because there is a great feeling of fear and anger and concern over these events and we want to keep our community safe and people here want to be safe.”

Council President Evan Myers said he was appalled by some of the measures he had seen people take to ensure that their citizenship could be proven should they be stopped by ICE.

“I know people of color, born in the United States, who carried their passports with them on their persons, people in our community, to prove their own citizenship, born in the hospital a few miles away from here,” Myers said.

Myers said it was important for the council to show its support for the State College community as well as to develop measures to ensure their rights are protected.

“A year ago, even before Trump took office, this council started to discuss things we could do to protect our residents,” Myers said. “We must begin to explore ways that our local government, right here in State College, can put in motion safeguards beyond the things that we're already doing, that the mayor alluded to, for those that live here. I'm not sure what they all are, but there are things we need to address and address them quickly over the next coming weeks.”

Council member Nalini Krishnankutty said much of the fear and anxiety from State College residents stemmed from concerns that local law enforcement organizations may not be equipped to ensure peoples’ safety while handling the different operating procedures of external organizations.

“There were people who were not feeling safe anymore in the sense that it doesn't matter what our local policing is committed to, we might have other law enforcement agencies that might not be practicing the same things,” Krishnankutty said. “If they do something that doesn't seem right, we are not sure there's going to be an independent investigation. It's just very different from, or appears to be different from, what we are committed to and we don't seem to have the resources to assure us that we are safe if other law enforcement comes into our community.”

“In council, we've already decried the killings of people like Melissa Hortman and Charlie Kirk, but this feels different on a different level, because our own government did it,” Council Member Matt Herndon added.“...I've seen people say it's not unusual for politicians to take factual liberties and while this may be true for many, it does not have to be and we should not accept it. Facts matter, the truth matters, we must demand the truth.”

Council member Gopal Balachandran said it was “chilling” to see the reaction of ICE agents immediately after Good’s death and how it was another example of law enforcement agencies failing to prevent acts of violence upon those they are meant to protect.

He said both Democrats and Republicans are responsible for empowering ICE in their own ways and believed it was up to bipartisan action to curb the actions of the federal government, both at home and abroad.

“The problems with our immigration laws stretch long and far; our problems with our foreign policy stretch far and wide, and they are bipartisan issues, meaning that Democrats and Republicans bear responsibility for it,” Balachandran said. “While I am horrified by what has happened and I do believe that we need to do whatever we can to fight what appears to be very serious threats to our democracy, the rule of law, and the respect for human rights and dignity, we should not kid ourselves that this somehow began with the Trump administration in 2024 when it's been an ongoing feature of American political life and American foreign policy for a very, very long time.”
