title: Penn State field hockey announces Hannah Prince as next head coach
author: Sam Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
There’s a new coach in town and she won’t need to travel far.

A trip down I-95 brought St. Josephs’ Hannah Prince to State College. Penn State Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics Pat Kraft announced the signing on Tuesday afternoon.

Hannah Prince named Penn State Field Hockey's new head coach!https://t.co/TdAr4EmTg8 pic.twitter.com/f1uw9nlW1p— Penn State Field Hockey (@PennStateFH) January 13, 2026

“We are grateful and excited to welcome Hannah Prince to Happy Valley as the leader of our field hockey program,” Kraft said in a press release. “Hannah has already achieved national success and has emerged as one of the bright young coaching stars in collegiate field hockey.”

The move followed a nearly month-long search that began after Penn State parted ways with Lisa Bervinchak Love. The Nittany Lions marked three subpar seasons with Bervinchak Love at the helm, as the team combined for a 24-27 losing record.

Prince will seek resurgence as she marked a high level of success at St. Joseph's. The former UMass star brings a wave of youthful energy to Happy Valley.

In her time at St. Joe’s, Prince led the Hawks to four-straight NCAA Tournament appearances and a National Championship berth.

The now 33-year-old began her coaching career at New Hampshire, where she led the Wildcats to two American East Championship games. Prince led the Hawks to four-consecutive Atlantic 10 Tournament titles and won two regular-season championships after taking over in 2022.

“Penn State is committed to excellence at the highest level in everything we do, and Hannah shares the vision of bringing championship field hockey back to Penn State,” Kraft said.

Penn State is the owner of two national titles in field hockey, having won in back-to-back seasons in 1980 and 1981. The school holds six Big Ten titles in the sport, most recently coming in 2016 when the Nittany Lions defeated Maryland.

Prince will mark the seventh head coach in the school’s field hockey history. Penn State will look to bounce back in 2026 with its new coach.

MORE FIELD HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | Penn State men's hockey earned Big Ten sweep despite injury concerns
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s hockey used a rejuvenated lineup to dominate Minnesota in a sweep last weekend. While it played its best games of the season, it didn’t escape unscathed. A few key injuries sustained in the Big Ten series will be key moving forward for the Nittany Lions.

Defense

Throughout the first half of the season, Penn State’s defense struggled to find an identity, which was an issue Guy Gadowsky preached on in nearly every press conference until winter break.

Upon return, and the return of Cade Christenson, Penn State’s defense has begun showing some consistency and an identity that can lead the Nittany Lions forward.

Every series showed a shuffling of lines prior to these past two weeks. Now, the pairings of Jackson Smith-Jarod Crespo and Mac Gadowsky-Christenson have performed well enough to remain together long term.

The defense allowed both Kevin Reidler and Josh Fleming to benefit, giving up just two goals behind a scrappy bunch that broke up passes, exited the defensive zone cleanly and contributed to the scoreboard as well.

Penalties

One of the blue and white’s defining traits in the 2025 half of the season was its tendency to engage in heated matchups that stuck them in the penalty box for extended periods of games. Heading into the break, Penn State was the most penalized team in the country.

Against Minnesota, Penn State took victories without lighting up the penalty board. The Nittany Lions had just three penalties in the first game, in which they shut out the Golden Gophers, and kept the number low in Game 2.

This was seemingly the product of cleaner defensive play that was able to control the pace without crossing the line.

Outside of just penalty kill, this showed deeper progress for the Nittany Lions’ mindset. They weren’t just avoiding penalties, they were keeping their heads level, even in a second game where Minnesota pushed their boundaries.

The only moment all weekend where Penn Star overstated their emotions was after Braedon Ford was injured on a hit into the boards.

Injuries

While Penn State regained Aiden Fink and Christenson over break, the hockey gods wouldn’t let them off the hook. The team suffered a few injuries during the series with Minnesota.

The big one came in the first period Saturday when Charlie Cerrato left the game, not returning to action last weekend. Gadowsky stated that Cerrato was day-to-day heading towards Penn State’s series against Notre Dame.

Casey Aman and Shea Van Olm are also role-players who are day-to-day heading into this weekend. Aman served as the extra skater against Minnesota on Saturday, while Van Olm fills a bottom-six role.

Van Olm and Cerrato will be even more important heading into this weekend with the news that Braedon Ford will be out of action long term with a lower-body injury. Ford took a shot to his ankle while being hit into the boards and spent a prolonged time on the ice before being helped off. Prior to the injury, he scored his first goal of the year off a feed from Gavin McKenna.

These injuries will test Penn State’s forward depth that has been an issue for them throughout the season. However, during the last games, the depth started showing up for Penn State. Luke Misa and Lev Katzin each showed up on the score sheet against Minnesota. Contributions like those will need to be the answer to how Penn State weathers the injury bug.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State notebook | Coach Carolyn Kieger talks changes, future outlook
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
For the first time since coach Carolyn Kieger’s first season with Penn State in 2019 — excluding the shortened COVID year — the Lady Lions are halfway through January with a losing record.

Sitting at 7-10, Penn State has been struggling to find answers during its six-game losing streak. With another top-25 Big Ten opponent on the schedule this week, answers need to be found soon.

During the weekly media session, Kieger spoke about those changes, as well as the future outlook of the team.

Scouting the Buckeyes

Despite upsetting Ohio State in last year’s matchup, chances are very low for a repeat on Wednesday, with ESPN Analytics giving Penn State just a 3.7% chance of winning.

The Buckeyes are home to several of the best players in the Big Ten, including Jaloni Cambridge. Cambridge is averaging 21.2 points per game through 17 games and has a pair of 30-plus point performances.

“We got to build a wall around Jaloni,” Kieger said. “She’s probably the number one player in the country right now in transition offense. She’s super talented at running, so we need to change up defenses a bit to give pressure.”

In addition to the offensive challenges presented by Ohio State, the Buckeyes also have one of the top defenses in the country, forcing 13.4 steals per game.

“Obviously, we need to take care of the ball,” Kieger said. “So we got to weather the press. We know they're going to get up and in full court on every play.”

Defensive changes

After giving up 94 points to Illinois and 105 points to Michigan, Sunday’s postgame press conference was centered around defense.

The Lady Lions allowed the Fighting Illini to shoot nearly 60% from the field and 50% from 3-point range as they fell by 16 points.

“I think a lot of it comes down to one-on-one defense,” Kieger said. “We call it guarding your yard, three feet in both directions.”

Freshman Nyla McFadden stood out as a strong defensive presence against Illinois, guarding every position on the floor. However, the rest of the team’s efforts didn’t satisfy Kieger’s expectations.

“The willingness to step up and guard your area, guard your yard, (is missing),” Kieger said. “I can’t necessarily say it’s one thing, but if I had to bottle it up all into one word, it would be toughness.”

Retention

Amidst a six-game losing streak with five more top-25 matchups on the horizon, Penn State has fallen out of March Madness contention and are teetering on the verge of missing the Big Ten tournament.

The Lady Lions have a young squad with only two seniors and all of its starters set to return next year.

However, in the ever-changing world of college sports, retention has become a hot-topic issue, and Kieger is well aware of that with the offseason quickly approaching.

“That’s obviously on the forefront of everyone's minds right now in college athletics,” Kieger said. “Players are motivated by different things, so relationships and player retention are big things.”

After losing 11 players to the transfer portal in the last two years, Kieger has to focus on bringing back Moriah Murray, Kiyomi McMiller and Gracie Merkle next season.

“Building continuity and keeping players and making transformational changes and building energy (are important),” Kieger said. “I think you see the teams that are having the most success right now have been together for a couple years to build that synergy amongst their star players.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Two men arrested for trespassing Beaver Stadium
author: Taylor McGillvray | The Daily Collegian
description:
Two State College men were arrested Saturday night for trespassing into Beaver Stadium.

19-year old Jacob M. Pittman of Latrobe and 21-year-old Travis D. Wilk of Lititz were charged with a third degree felony offense for criminal trespassing.

A Penn State police officer sitting in a parked police vehicle noticed one of the men descending stairs in the stadium. At the time, Beaver Stadium was not open to the public.

They were allegedly walking around campus after a concert when they slipped through a bent fence. CCTV footage showed the men in the stands and field and taking photos, according to the affidavit of probable cause.

The two men exited the same way they had entered. They then headed to the Medlar Field box office and walked northbound, before the officer stopped them.

Both Pittman and Wilk are awaiting a preliminary hearing scheduled for Jan. 21.

MORE CRIME & COURTS COVERAGE

title: State College residents express concerns over Addison Court redevelopment
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Several State College residents spoke before the borough council during a meeting Monday to express concerns over the redevelopment of Arnold Addison Court, known informally as Addison Court.

The building, which opened in 1994 to provide affordable housing to elderly and handicapped State College Borough residents within the downtown area, has already seen preliminary plans for its redevelopment into a mixed-use structure viewed by the State College Design Review Board during a meeting last Tuesday.

Kathryn Santoro, a tenant of Addison Court, said she was having trouble finding housing outside of the complex due to unaffordability, as well as most not being handicapped-accessible.

“I came to Addison Court because it's 55 and over and I wanted to be close to the community,” Santoro said. “You're going to put a condo in Addison Court. It's gonna contain four or five bedrooms. How come you guys, borough and the planning commission, say, ‘Wait a minute: is it all about money?’”

Santoro said she was concerned the new development would only prioritize Penn State students and believed its construction would push out older residents living in that area.

Richard McCarty, another tenant of Addison Court, said it’s a newer building, and those residing within it have disabilities that would be impacted by the redevelopment.

“A lot of (residents) possess particular disabilities, etc., from which they don't even go outside their doors and stuff,” McCarty said. “There are over 60 individuals out of the 80 plus units in Addison Court, which is not an old building. There are old buildings in State College that probably should be torn down. Addison Court, I do not believe, is one of those.”

Council President Evan Myers said it was the borough’s responsibility to its residents to find ways to ensure that the tenants of Addison Court are able to find housing.

“The community is crying for help,” Myers said. “Even though we have no ownership in Addison Court, and we never did, we did help facilitate its construction and use it and behooves us to do all we can to help to provide some similar living situation, and we should do what we can to make that happen.”

Council member Kevin Kassab said he felt it was the borough’s responsibility to ensure the tenants of Addison Court were able to find housing in a market that does not have many options for them.

“We had an investment, or whatever we'd had, when Addison Court was built, putting these individuals into a home that they thought was gonna be their home until they passed and now they're going to be displaced so I do feel kind of like it's sort of something,” Kassab said. “Somehow, we have to figure out and it's gonna be tough because we all know affordable housing in the borough practically doesn't exist.”

Josh Portney, another council member said Addison Court has several connections to the organization through its work to establish the complex.

“We have 60 individuals that, in a couple years, may lose their house,” Portney said. “The borough council in 1990 shepherded this building from beginning to end. We knew about it. There was a zoning change, there was an amendment done, there was even financial support for parts of the building from the borough council. It is private development, but we have our thumbs a little bit on it.”

Portney said he found it “heartbreaking” to have to see residents be put at risk of losing housing and demanded that the council work to ensure that their needs are met.

“We have to literally look at every option and I've said this before, and I know it's really uncomfortable for us, but we've done eminent domain before,” Portney said. “I know that this is very controversial and this might be the most extreme thing that I'm proposing, and I proposed a lot of extreme things in my tenure, but we have to look at every option and if it's not that, it's promising them a place at Bellaire Court. If it's not that, it's promising them a place at another housing that's on a bus line that's located in our downtown. This is our work.”

MORE BOROUGH COVERAGE

title: State College Borough Council discusses revised Community Oversight Board ordinance
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
The State College Borough Council resumed discussions on revisions to the ordinance that founded the Community Oversight Board (COB), codified as borough ordinance 2164, during a meeting on Monday.

The revisions, which were written in response to feedback during a council meeting on Sept. 8, 2025, include the mandated training of new committee members to be completed to the standards set by the National Association for Civilian Oversight of Law Enforcement (NACOLE) with a report of this training also being required to be submitted annually.

Council member Gopal Balachandran said he was concerned with the prioritization of law enforcement training from NACOLE and their training guidelines.

“I think for the purposes of this training, there's enough flexibility here that's going to allow different sources of information but I would just highlight that, as far as an organization goes, unless we really know what their composition and their viewpoint is, it might be promoting one particular viewpoint, as opposed to a neutral viewpoint,” Balachandran said.

Balachandran said it was important to look outside of the law enforcement perspective in order to better understand the impact of policing on State College. He said he found that, while litigating the Subramanyam “Subu” Vedam case, internal oversight measures within law enforcement aren’t always successful in preventing misconduct.

“What a lot of people don't know is that there was a process in place for the D.A.'s office to be able to review old convictions which was called a conviction integrity unit and in many ways, it was meant to be kind of like an oversight process within the DA's office, sort of like an internal affairs unit or maybe even like the community oversight board,” Balachandran said. “When the Centre County District Attorney looked at the same information that I looked at, they decided there was no problem with Subu Vedam's conviction. It was completely correct. All the policing was great. There was no improper misconduct at all. Well, lo and behold, when we actually litigate the case, we find that there is a whole lot of misconduct that occurred.”

Nalini Krishnankutty, another council member, said she wanted to see an increased emphasis on anti-bias, policing and immigration within the training of new COB members along with an overview of policies detailing the training and applications for use of force.

“They are going to overview everything and the reason I want to elevate these two is because all members should really know that,” Krishnankutty said. “I'd really like to have those come up.”

After further discussion among the council, the issue was tabled for later discussion on Feb. 2, when the council is expected to make a final decision.

MORE BOROUGH COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | Penn State women’s basketball goes 0-2, continues losing stretch
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Playing with homecourt advantage over two top teams from the Big Ten, Penn State looked for its first win since early December in last week’s outings.

Instead, the Lady Lions endured a blowout loss to Michigan and suffered a close loss to Illinois, extending their losing streak to six games.

Despite falling to 7-10 on the year, there were several takeaways — both positive and negative — from last week’s 0-2 stretch.

Rise of McFadden

Despite playing in 16 games this season, 30% of freshman Nyla McFadden’s minutes this season came from last week.

The Fort Lauderdale, Florida, native was praised for coach Carolyn Kieger postgame, saying, “She’s been doing everything we’ve asked, working her butt off and staying true to the process. I really can’t say enough about her.”

In just 12 minutes against the Wolverines, McFadden scored 10 points, including going 2-for-2 from deep.

In the following game, she played a career-high 27 minutes and posted another double-digit performance. McFadden scored 12 points with two rebounds and two assists as she earned her first career start.

Standing at just 6-foot, McFadden’s quickness and toughness allowed her to guard nearly every position on the floor on Sunday, making herself a valuable asset for the remainder of the season.

Defense

Six — that’s how many times coach Kieger said the word defense in her two minutes and fifteen seconds of postgame media on Sunday. Those weren’t positive references either.

The Lady Lions gave up 105 points to Michigan on Thursday and 92 to Illinois, two of the highest scoring totals of the season.

Penn State’s offense put up 76 points on Sunday, which would’ve been enough to win half the games so far this season. Instead, the defense allowed the Fighting Illini to shoot nearly 60% from the court with 50% from 3-point range.

Different aspects of the blue and white’s defense showed up, as it forced 21 turnovers on Illinois. However, they only recorded nine turnovers against the Wolverines.

Rebounding was a similar struggle during Sunday’s game, as the Lady Lions allowed 10 offensive rebounds while recording just 13 defensive rebounds.

As Kieger said, “Until we develop this toughness and this grit to play defense, the results aren’t going to change.”

Gracie Merkle’s efficiency

6-foot-6 Gracie Merkle stands as one of the most efficient players in the country through 10 weeks, shooting 74.6% from the field.

Against both Big Ten squads last week, Merkle went a combined 17-for-23 as she tallied 42 points.

However, Merkle’s biggest highlight from the game on Sunday was her free throw efficiency. With her strong, back-to-the-basket style of play, the Mount Washington, Kentucky, native has found her way to the free throw line for 59 shots this season.

Against Illinois, Merkle shot from the free throw line 10 times, going 8-for-10. Earlier in the year, she shot under 60% from the line, but has since gone over 60%.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Josh Portney resigns from State College Borough Council
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
The State College Borough Council voted to accept the resignation of Josh Portney during a meeting Monday in accordance with his decision to accept a clerkship position within the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.

Following remarks from several council members and a unanimous decision to begin the 45-day process of electing a new council member, Portney gave several remarks reflecting on his work during his time on the council.

“This service has been really the most important thing that I've ever done in my life,” Portney said. “Now, I am doing something very, very important on Commonwealth Court, but this legislative body that I've been a part of for the last two years, I've been able to interface with local businesses, enhance local businesses, talk with people, meet people where they are on the street and really figure out their problems and how government can help.”

Portney said while his time on the council often came with “fun disagreements” and “hardy debate,” he found it important that such dialogue continues following his departure.

“When you ask questions and you maybe are that outlier, you get us to a point where it's better because now we're all in agreement and we all had conversations and we've all talked about things,” Portney said. “It's not just about us understanding things; it's about the people on the other side understanding the really important issues that we're legislating here.”

Portney finished by stating that despite his new position, he will always cherish the friendships he has made during his time on the council.

“I really, really am looking forward to the next chapter of my life, but I will never leave this place behind,” Portney said. “I've still got people here and this place will always be my home.”

MORE BOROUGH COVERAGE

title: Mayor Ezra Nanes issues proclamation recognizing Jan. 20, 2026 as National Day of Racial Healing
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Mayor Ezra Nanes issued a proclamation that recognizes Jan. 20, 2026 as National Day of Racial Healing in State College on Monday.

The day, which was first observed in 2017 and hosted annually by the W.K. Kellogg Foundation on the Tuesday following Martin Luther King Jr. Day, is meant to allow for the contemplation and discussion of solutions to heal from the effects of racism.

Nanes said the day is to “engage in honest reflection, truth-telling and courageous dialogue” in order to acknowledge past and present harms as well as mutual responsibilities.

“Our commitment to racial healing is grounded in a deep love for our community and our country, and in the belief that confronting harm, affirming dignity and strengthening our bonds, makes our nation more just, resilient, and united,” Nanes said. “The National Day of Racial Healing, observed on the Tuesday following Martin Luther King Jr. Day, provides an opportunity for individuals and communities in State College and across the nation to reflect and take action in support of healing and positive transformation, affirming that racial healing is not a single day's observance, but an ongoing commitment to dignity and justice for all.”

Following the proclamation, remarks were given by Naana Nti, the diversity and inclusion chair for the State College Chapter of the American Association of University Women and Community Diversity Group Board chair Carol Eicher.

MORE BOROUGH COVERAGE

title: ‘I’m angry, I’m tired’ | Students, community members organize to honor Renee Good, protest ICE violence
author: Jacob Godshall | The Daily Collegian
description:
Dozens of protesters gathered at the Old Main steps Monday evening to honor Renee Good and protest Immigration and Customs Enforcement's (ICE) increased presence throughout the country.

The event was organized by the Student Committee for Defense and Solidarity (SCDS) and People's Defense Front, in response to the death of 37-year-old, Minnesota resident Good, who was shot in her car by an ICE agent in Minneapolis.

Tyler Evock said protests like this are important to show that there are people all over the country who believe what ICE is doing to be an “injustice.”

“What I’m seeing from ICE, and all of law enforcement, is that they are too violent,” Evock, a Penn State graduate, said.

Evock also expressed concern that ICE is making it even more difficult to go through the proper nationalization processes.

As the protest continued, speakers from SCDS, the People’s Defense Front and Latino Caucus spoke into a megaphone to lead chants, give speeches and speak out against ICE.

Chants of “Say her name” were answered again and again by the crowd with: “Renee Good.”

As chants continued, other attendees, like Lydia and David Vandenbergh, held lit candles in remembrance of Good.

“I think it sends a signal, hopefully, especially to our congressional representatives, that they have to start standing up for this,” David, a State College resident, said.

Lydia, another resident, said she didn’t believe ICE was acting as they should and doesn’t think “justice is being served.”

After the speeches at Old Main, the group moved through downtown State College. As they marched down College Avenue, protesters raised a variety of signs, some of which read: “ICE out of Pa,” “Admin and Klan go hand in hand” and “ICE off campus.”

When protesters filled the streets, members of the organizing groups blocked off intersections. At the corner of Beaver Avenue and Allen Street, protesters blocking the Allen Street light were pushed aside as a man in a gray vehicle drove through the crowd.

Several of the protesters rushed toward the car, yelling at the driver and striking the car with their fists. The driver eventually stopped and stepped out of the vehicle briefly before getting back in and driving away.

State College police said there were no reported injuries and that no permit had been issued to block off the street.

Protestors eventually stopped, once again, at the State College Municipal Building where the group gave more speeches and led chants.

Sergio Velecico said violence from ICE is what prompted him to be a part of the protest.

“I'm angry and I'm tired that this is happening across the country,” Velecico said. “So, someone has to talk about it and we have to be out here and speak about it.”

The march concluded as protesters walked back to the steps of Old Main and gave final remarks and calls for action.

Connor Shaw expressed his empathy for immigrants, and those that have dealt with ICE.

“We're demonizing people trying to make a living here, escaping these horrible conditions in other countries,” Shaw, a second-year studying biomedical engineering, said.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling's Braeden Davis enters rankings in updated InterMat poll
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
A new ranking and a new entrant for Penn State.

After a shutout victory over Rutgers, the Nittany Lions saw a multitude of movement in the most recent InterMat rankings.

Marcus Blaze jumped one spot to No. 4 at 133 pounds, surpassing his next opponent, Drake Ayala of Iowa, who dropped to No. 8 after losing to Wisconsin's Zan Fugitt.

At 141 pounds, Braeden Davis entered the rankings, debuting at No. 7 after wrestling against Rutgers on Saturday in place of the injured Aaron Nagao. He is listed at 5-0, despite wrestling unattached at the Kauffman Open, and will likely be the starter the rest of the season after burning his redshirt.

PJ Duke jumped one spot to No. 3 at 157 pounds after a major shakeup in the rankings. This was due to Arizona State's Kaleb Larkin jumping from 149 pounds and taking down then-No. 1 Ty Watters of West Virginia and then-No. 3 Vince Zerban of Iowa State.

At heavyweight, Cole Mirasola rose from No. 13 from No. 15 after coming out victorious.

Every other Penn State wrestler remained the same ranking — Luke Lilledahl at No. 2, Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines and Josh Barr at No. 1 and Rocco Welsh at No. 4.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Mississippi State punter Nathan Tiyce transfers to Penn State
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has a new specialist.

Mississippi State punter Nathan Tiyce has transferred to the Nittany Lions, as announced in various reports on Monday and confirmed by an update to his Instagram page.

The 6-foot-5, 230-pounder spent one season with the Bulldogs, tallying 12 punts for 468 yards, which is an average of 39 yards per kick. The freshman kicked two punts of over 50 yards and landed seven punts inside the 20-yard line.

Tiyce is a native of Gerringong, Australia, where he started punting in November 2023 through Pro Kick Australia. He originally committed to Mississippi State in December 2024.

He's the second punter expected to be on Penn State's 2026 roster, with three-star recruit Lucas Tenbrock also on board.

For more updates on incoming transfers, departures and returnees.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: How does Penn State wrestling match up against Iowa? | The Mat Return
author: The Daily Collegian wrestling staff
description:
The Mat Return” co-hosts Andrew Deal, AJ Piazza and Evan Smith came together to recap Penn State’s last month of competition.

How dominant was Penn State in the record-breaking process? What wrestlers made their returns to the starting lineups in Rec Hall against Rutgers?

Following that, the group discussed and broke down the highly anticipated dual against Iowa on Friday. They assessed where Penn State could exploit the Hawkeyes’ lineup and where Iowa holds the advantage over the Nittany Lions.

MORE COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball looks to upset No. 14 Ohio State for 2nd straight year
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Entering the second quarter down by eight, Penn State stormed back and outscored Ohio State 20-9 in the quarter.

After upsetting the then-No. 9 Buckeyes last year, the Lady Lions travel to Columbus to take them on again at 6:30 p.m. on Wednesday with the same goal in mind.

This year’s Ohio State team looks very different this year, missing its high scorer from last year. With WNBA scouts in attendance, Cotie McMahon scored 19 points on the blue and white last January before transferring to Ole Miss for her final year.

However, the Buckeyes were without Jaloni Cambridge — last year’s No. 2 scorer and this year’s leading scorer — due to an injury.

This year, she stands among the top scorers in the conference and 10th best in the nation, averaging 21.2 points per game.

In addition to Cambridge, Ohio State found success with Chance Grey and Kylee Kitts, who combine for 22.5 points per game.

Besides Grey, who scored 18 points on last year’s Penn State team, much of the Buckeyes’ starting lineup is new to coach Carolyn Kieger’s squad and will get their first look on Wednesday.

For the Lady Lions, however, their three primary starters played against Ohio State last year. Both Gracie Merkle and Moriah Murray played big roles in the team’s upset, scoring 12 points each.

While Kiyomi McMiller didn’t suit up for the blue and white last year against the Buckeyes, she was a strong contributor for Rutgers, scoring 14 points in her team’s loss.

This year, that trio has led the Lady Lions on the court, averaging a combined 47.8 points per game.

Murray has been the blue and white’s leading 3-point scorer for the past two seasons and is on pace to be in the top 10 for most triples in a season, currently having 46 made shots from behind the arc.

Meanwhile, Merkle made her way as the nation’s most efficient shooter, shooting 74.6% from the court. McMiller rounds out the three with her strong ball-handling skills and playmaking, working her way to the basket when all else fails.

While Ohio State comes in towering over Penn State in the David versus Goliath matchup, the blue and white has the tools it needs to overtake Cambridge and the Buckeyes for its second straight upset and first conference win of the season.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | Penn State men’s basketball narrowly falls to ranked opponents
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State basketball started 0-3 in 2026, however the games were against three AP-ranked opponents, which boosts optimism as they move forward.

Here are three major takeaways from the most recent stretch of games where the blue and white faced then-No.20 Illinois, No. 2 Michigan and No. 5 Purdue.

Close, but no cigar

The Nittany Lions finished ten points in each of those games and even had a final possession against the Wolverines, with Freddie Dilione V just barely missing a shot on a questionable play call that Michigan easily snuffed out.

That sentiment echoes the trend of how the Nittany Lions play down the stretch, as experienced, higher-performing teams quickly derail any attempt by the blue and white to pull off an upset.

Against Illinois, the blue and white fell behind by 14 at the half and traded buckets with the Fighting Illini, but couldn’t overcome the efficiency of its foe. Against Michigan, despite the Wolverines opening a path to victory by shooting over 10 percentage points worse after the break, the Nittany Lions still shot under 40% and struggled from beyond the arc and at the free throw line.

Despite the Purdue contest marking an improved second-half shooting stretch, the blue and white dished out half as many assists and turned the ball over five times, while the Boilermakers turned it over once, again putting the win out of reach down the wire.

Tale of two shooters

In the early games of 2026, the Nittany Lions sought to improve their shooting from beyond the arc; a team that averaged 7.8 threes per game surpassed that mark in this stretch of contests. That shooting came courtesy of two main wings, Eli Rice and Dominick Stewart, who ramped up their willingness to empty the clip from downtown.

Rice posted a season high in shot attempts over the stretch, while Stewart also surpassed his averages for field goals and three-point attempts per game in two of the contests. Both the 3-and-D players posted mixed results despite their newfound willingness to shoot.

Stewart, over the three games, shot 2-for-18 from the field and committed 12 fouls, while Rice went 10-for-23 with six long-range makes.

Via Evan Miyakawa’s statistical formulas, Stewart ranks as the least efficient and worst-performing Nittany Lion with over 200 possessions. On the contrary, Rice ranks fourth on the squad in performance and posts the best defensive rating.

Introduction to injury

In two of the three games Penn State played, it did so without star freshman guard Kayden Mingo, who reportedly suffered a broken nose in practice. That absence raised concerns among the blue-and-white fanbase, as most of the Nittany Lions' on-court identity is from Mingo.

The Farmingdale, New York, native provides all-around skills: playmaking, scoring, defense and leadership, yet the difficulty without him didn’t seem to be much greater than with his services, as Penn State still posted formidable results.

It does mark the first major injury for Penn State this season, and he’s joined on the sidelines by Tibor Mirtić, who appeared on the availability report before the Purdue game after exiting against Michigan.

The last injury report for Penn State men’s basketball marked the lengthiest it’s been so far this season.

Both the guard and forward likely miss extended time for Penn State, and navigating a less-than-full-strength roster is essential for Mike Rhoades’ squad, as it looks to build a foundation and confidence on the court outside of its budding superstar.

Over the past week of play, Penn State seems to have started strongly toward that goal, which should result in a stronger team once everyone is available.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Nittany Lions in the NFL | Former Penn Staters star despite being sent home
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
The NFL Playoff is underway with wild card round action happening this past weekend.

A few former Penn State players made impacts for their NFL teams, including two players racking up over 100 yards and defensive end getting multiple sacks.

Here’s what stood out among ex-Nittany Lions.

Parker Washington, wide receiver, Jacksonville Jaguars

Wide receiver Parker Washington had a strong finish to the regular season, and he extended that into the playoffs despite the Jacksonville Jaguars’ 27-24 loss to the Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

Washington totaled seven catches for a team-high 107 yards on 12 targets, which is the most he’s seen in a game this season. The former Nittany Lion also had a 6-yard touchdown to put the Jaguars ahead 17-13 with 12:55 left in the fourth quarter.

Parker Washington gives the Jaguars the lead!BUFvsJAX on CBS/Paramount+Stream on @NFLPlus pic.twitter.com/yn2JXBuFwQ— NFL (@NFL) January 11, 2026

Washington picked up chunk yardage on multiple plays, including a long reception of 34 yards. He also had a 31-yard catch at the 7:05 mark of the fourth quarter, helping Jacksonville move down the field to eventually retake the lead.

The former sixth-round NFL draft pick ended his year with 65 catches for 954 yards and six touchdowns in the regular season and postseason combined. His regular season numbers of 58 receptions for 847 yards and five scores are all career highs for the third-year player.

Odafe Oweh, defensive end, Los Angeles Chargers

Defensive end Odafe Oweh completed his first season with the Los Angeles Chargers following a 16-3 loss to the New England Patriots on Sunday, and he set a new personal record with three sacks.

Oweh got involved in the backfield early, registering a sack with 12:57 left in the first quarter. He later stripped sacked quarterback Drake Maye, which was recovered by teammate Da'Shawn Hand.

Odafe Oweh knocks it loose!Da'Shawn Hand recovers!Chargers ball ⚡️LACvsNE on NBCStream on @NFLPlus + Peacock pic.twitter.com/YzXV08M6gu— NFL (@NFL) January 12, 2026

He ended his night with four tackles, giving him 42 tackles and 10.5 sacks across both the regular season and postseason.

Oweh was traded to the Chargers midseason from the Baltimore Ravens, where he spent the first four years of his career. With 7.5 sacks in the regular season, Oweh set the second-highest sack total he’s tallied, coming up short to his 10-sack effort in 2024.

Saquon Barkley, running back, Philadelphia Eagles

Running back Saquon Barkley eclipsed the century mark on the ground even though the Philadelphia Eagles lost to the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday, 23-19.

Barkley rushed for 106 yards on 26 carries in addition to three catches for 25 yards. He had a long rush of 31 yards, and he also had a 29-yard carry to help set up a touchdown drive in the first quarter.

First down and more for Saquon 😤SFvsPHI on FOX/FOX OneStream on @NFLPlus pic.twitter.com/v1ffV7HhvO— NFL (@NFL) January 11, 2026

Barkley finished his year with 1,246 yards and seven touchdowns on 26 attempts in the regular season and postseason. His 1,140 rushing yards in the regular season was the fifth time in his career he’s passed the 1,000-yard mark.

Jaquan Brisker, safety, Chicago Bears

Safety Jaquan Brisker was once again a leader for the Chicago Bears’ defense with a team-high nine tackles in a 31-27 win over the Green Bay Packers on Saturday.

In coverage, Brisker didn’t give up many plays as he allowed one catch for 20 yards on one target, according to PFF. This year, Brisker is up to 102 tackles in the regular season and postseason combined.

Brisker and the Bears’ season will continue with a divisional round matchup against the Los Angeles Rams next weekend.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Big Ten recap | Women’s basketball sees numerous upsets in last week’s matchups
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
While Penn State fell to Illinois to continue its six-game losing streak, the Big Ten saw several other storylines in the past week of conference play.

From top-25 showdowns to busted win streaks and continued losing streaks, many teams had their fair share of highlights and big games.

Here’s a recap of the conference action this week.

USC falls to Oregon, Minnesota

USC has looked like a different team this year without JuJu Watkins, and that was on display even more this past week.

Entering the week as No. 21 in the AP poll, the Trojans fell to two unranked teams in Oregon and Minnesota.

USC pulled into a commanding 23-9 lead after the first quarter against the Ducks, and that was extended even more to a 16-point lead at half. However, Oregon flipped the script in the final quarter, outscoring USC 26-8 to win the game.

Against the Golden Gophers, Jazzy Davidson — the No. 1 athlete in the Class of 2025 — scored 21 points alongside senior Kara Dunn’s 27 points.

The team’s bench was the ultimate letdown, however, scoring just three points.

Minnesota’s Grace Grocholski and Sophie Hart combined for 40 to win 63-62, sending USC to the middle of the Big Ten with a 2-3 conference record.

Purdue beats Wisconsin, Washington

Following three straight losses, Purdue found some hope to rejuvenate its season with a pair of upset wins over Wisconsin and Washington.

The Boilermakers had a disappointing start to the season, losing to their satellite campus Purdue Fort Worth and to Central Michigan. However, they showed signs of strength in their two wins that could carry deeper into the season.

Purdue pulled out to a commanding 18-9 lead after the first quarter to Wisconsin, and despite the Badgers closing the gap to one point at halftime, closed out the game while outscoring Wisconsin by seven points in the second half.

A big part of Purdue’s success came from the triple, as it went 12-for-20 from deep. Sophomore Nya Smith led the way with four 3-pointers, followed by Madison Layden-Zay’s three triples.

The first quarter played out a little differently against Washington, however, as Purdue entered the second quarter down by nine points.

While junior Sayvia Sellers scored 23 points against the Boilermakers, they were able to bring the game to overtime tied at 63 each.

Layden-Zay and Tara Daye put the nail in the coffin in overtime, each scoring 19 points on the game to win by six — tying USC with 10 wins on the year.

No. 19 Ohio State earns upset over No. 8 Maryland

After falling to No. 1 UConn and No. 4 UCLA earlier in the year, Ohio State earned its first big win of the year as it handed Maryland its second loss of the year.

The Terrapins came out of the first quarter shooting 60% from deep with a 24-12 lead over Ohio State. However, the Buckeyes scored 28 points in the second and fourth quarters to win by 13 points.

Jaloni Cambridge continued to craft her second straight All Big Ten season, scoring 28 points on Maryland.

Kylee Kitts, Kennedy Cambridge and Chance Grey all scored double digits as well, combining for 43 points.

Despite the loss, Maryland’s Oluchi Okananwa scored 27 points, recording over 20 points for the fifth time this year.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s basketball faces UCLA, seeking first Big Ten victory
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State started its 2026 half of the season with three consecutive ranked opponents, and was unable to claim any victories despite hard-fought battles.

Eight points decided the games against then-No. 20 Illinois and No. 5 Purdue, while the No. 2 Michigan contest came all the way down to the wire with a missed Freddie Dilione V jumper on the final buzzer, giving the Wolverines a 74-72 win. After five conference games, the blue and white sit winless.

Penn State will break the streak of facing top-of-the-conference and national opponents when it faces UCLA on Wednesday at the Bryce Jordan Center, where the Nittany Lions hold a 7-3 home record.

Although both teams play in the same conference, there are no common opponents between Penn State and UCLA so far this season. UCLA’s last two games against Wisconsin and Maryland will be Penn State's next two opponents after this game.

On the surface, scouting the Bruins, they remain a daunting foe at 11-5 overall, with a 3-2 conference record and an undefeated home streak after 10 games.

Bogged down Bruins

As the initial scouting report for UCLA presents, it doesn’t possess many flaws, with a top-half conference offense and defense. The Bruins’ +9.8 point scoring differential is a top-10 figure in the conference, despite their scoring average being the sixth lowest in the Big Ten.

These figures indicate a slower tempo and an efficient offensive approach from the Bruins, who rank sixth in the conference in field goal percentage. UCLA averages 70 possessions per game, placing it outside the top 240 teams nationally.

The Nittany Lions, who hold a slightly worse scoring offense but a much less effective defense, rank only somewhat behind the Bruins in possessions per game.

Luckily for the blue and white UCLA typically averages fewer offensive touches with the ball when they’re away from home, and is heading to Happy Valley, where Penn State ranks similarly to UCLA in their top level of play at home.

Evan Miyakawa’s formulas state that UCLA is a consistent team that plays the same regardless of the level of competition and pace. That tempo is again where a differential may emerge; however, the Bruins hold a bottom-six Big Ten tempo rating, while Penn State ranks in the top six.

The two coaching styles clash at the BJC, yet only one can prevail.

Participating personnel

Both Mike Rhoades and UCLA coach Mick Cronin’s units dealt with significant recent injuries, and that trend continues into this week’s clash.

Penn State’s star and leader on the court, Kayden Mingo reportedly broke his nose in practice and won’t play against the Bruins barring any significant change in status. The Penn State second-highest in scoring, and leader in assists, missed his second consecutive game as Penn State listed him and Tibor Mirtič on the last availability report.

Mirtič played all 15 games before his first absence this season, and Rhoades didn’t provide an immediate update on his status.

The Bruins listed senior guard Skyy Clark as out in their last contest, as well as wing Brandon Williams. Clark stands as UCLA’s second leading scorer and started in all but one of his 14 appearances, while Williams averages double-digit minutes as a valuable bench two-way contributor.

Clark dealt with a hamstring injury in the last few games, and before the previous contest, he got upgraded to day-to-day, meaning his return is inevitable and may even occur against Penn State.

Williams may also return soon, as his status is day-to-day due to leg cramps.

For UCLA, its leading scorer this season is senior forward Tyler Bilodeau, who averages 17.5 points, shoots the lowest field goal percentage out of its players who average double digits and scored a season high of 34 this year.

Joining Sky and Bilodeau are three other double-digit scorers for the Bruins, including Eric Dailey Jr., who leads the squad with 5.9 rebounds per game.

Dailey Jr transferred to UCLA after committing to Oklahoma State out of the 2023 class from IMG Academy, the same school and class that Penn State’s Eli Rice came out of and joined Nebraska before heading to Happy Valley.

Over the last four games, Rice has averaged 11.75 points per game and has reached over 20 minutes in each game of that stretch, as he puts together a breakout campaign.

Also stepping up over that stretch, and in particular once Mingo went down, is Dilione, who averages a team high 15 points per game, and orchestrates the offense with his desired tempo.
